150237784.review:
[h3][b]General Info[/b][/h3]
Among the Sleep allows you to fill the shoes of a 2 year old child and see the world from that perspective.
It takes you on a journey through a fantastical dreamscape and allows you to navigate the world in a unique and compelling way.

[h3][b]My Thoughts[/b][/h3]
Among the Sleep, while not diverging much from the walking simulator style formula, has some very interesting visuals and art design. This isn't a bad thing, I personally am a fan of walking simulator style games as a method to tell a story.

There are some puzzle and stealth elements baked into the experience, but nothing so exceptionally difficult and definitely seems to focus more on driving the story along rather than having you have to pause all that much at any given point.

I do not want to spoil too much about the game, so I won't go too much into the themes that the game tackles other than to say I was not expecting it based on how the game looks on face value.

The Enhanced Edition, which I think is the only one you can buy now, also comes with a Prologue DLC for free. You have to go into the Chapters Menu to find it, and it's a good 30ish additional minutes of game play you won't want to miss.

[h3][b]Recommendation[/b][/h3]
I thought this game was great, and if you are someone that is not against walking simulator style games as a genre then I think this game is definitely worth experiencing. It's certainly a game that has a story to tell and it looks amazing while doing it. 

[h3][b]Video Example and Shameless Self Promotion[/b][/h3]
I have a youtube gaming channel where I upload all my play through experiences, if you would like to check out the play through for this game (if nothing else to see how it looks before you buy), feel free to visit the links below. I will also out the link to the Prologue DLC play through if you're interested in that.

Main Story Play Through:
https://youtu.be/oowMcnKenFI

Prologue DLC Play Through:
https://youtu.be/t8paW266zBc

150032191.review:
Weeell this is weird one to review, one of those horizontal fingers, BUT when you think about it, it deserves the thumbs up (reasoning at the end).

So what is this? a horror game with a baby as a protagnist.  If you are well versed in litterature or a certain genre of 80-90 series/movies, i doubt you wont be able to predict the basic aspects of the story or explain to yourself the gameplay mechanics.

More specifically to the game play: this is first person horror survival platformer the likes of which only baby Ezio Auditore would be able to go through (I mean, not only the skill on this baby, his cojones must have enough mass to generate gravitational pull).  The ambiance and design are coherent with what the game sets out to give you, AND if as a child you werent dead inside and had stuff happen to you, im sure you'll be able to recognize some patterns.

The reasoning for its thumbs up takes this into account and more, namely, the games is affordable AF, very well designed, very coherent with itself and its objective (which it achieves all through the game time) AND for a game released in 2017 (when a certain social virus was well on its way to ruining all of media) portrays a reality all too common which most people in the civilized world are not ready to admit happens A LOT MORE than just isolated cases (i mean, in my experience, THAT is a real pandemic).

Could the game go rougher? yes.  Darker? yes.  Crazier?  Absolutely yes.  BUT ITS NOT WHAT THE GAME WANTED TO ACHIEVE.  in summary, a well made, surprising and affordable game which entertains you for a good ammount of hours... thats a thumbs up

149735989.review:
Wow, I loved this game. I wish I hadn't put off playing it for so long. It's short, but I think it's got good pacing. Tension and apprehension all the way through, and no moment or monster is dwelled on for too long.

I wasn't expecting to tear up during a horror game, but I guess the theme and presentation really got to me. The way they handled the foreboding atmosphere from the perspective of a toddler was really well done. I was doing so many double-takes, second-guessing whether what I saw was actually a monster or just me seeing patterns in silhouettes.

It's very much an indie-budget horror game which kind of shows through some of the jankiness, but for Krillbite's first foray into horror, I thought they did a great job.

Don't forget to play the Prologue and see the Museum from the chapter select after you finish the game. I almost missed them because they don't seem to be advertised anywhere.

[h1]My Rating: 4/5[/h1]

149102574.review:
¿"Among The Sleep"? Mejor dicho, "I Sleep", jaja, COMEDIA!!!

En Among The Sleep juegas como un bebé atravesando diversas areas tenebrosas junto a un oso teddy para recuperar recuerdos de tu madre e ir descubriendo el misterio detrás de la historia que estás protagonizando mientras huyes de una entidad que te acecha. 

Suena tenebroso en la práctica, y lo podría ser, pero aparentemente quienes desarrollaban el juego no solo hicieron al protagonista un bebé, sino que quizás pensaron que también lo iban a jugar bebés porque te dedicas a caminar, resolver puzzles que no tardas en resolver más del tiempo que te tomó caminar de lado a otro para agarrar las piezas para completarlos. 

El monstruo que te persigue durante el juego debo decir que debe ser uno de los PEORES que me he encontrado en cualquier juego de horror, no porque sea aterrador, sino todo lo contrario, siento que es muy blando, extremadamente facil de evadir, muy poca presencia dentro de TODO el juego, creo haberlo visto unas 3 veces y ya, y sobre todo, no asusta. Quizá te pueda sorprender un poco la primera vez pues toda tu visión se va al traste, pero después de eso toparselo no es la gran cosa. Simplemente aburrido.

Si apreciamos el ambiente, creo que tiene una muy buena atmosfera, me gustan mucho los sonidos, agua chapoteando mientras caminas en un pantano, el flujo de un rio, el chirrido de puertas, la iluminación, desde ese aspecto técnico creo que el juego es muy bueno, exceptuando los modelos de humanos, la madre parece sacada de la película de la era del hielo.

Encontré el protagonismo del Teddy Bear inutil, era prácticamente una linterna parlanchina cuya adición no cambia en nada el juego salvo que cuando te adentras en una nueva zona escuchas el diálogo "Será mejor que hagamos silencio....". Sé que tiene ALGO de relevancia a la hora de la escena final, pero siendo franco, podría no haber estado allí y el mensaje y probablemente el curso de la historia no habría cambiado mucho.

La premisa es interesante, el aspecto técnico es fenomenal y de hecho, el mensaje que dan al final del juego y la historia me agradan mucho, pero siento que la ejecución como tal del "miedo y terror" fallan, siendo un walking simulator con puzzles muy sencillos y con escenas menores de tensión. Para colmo, el juego solo me duró unas impresionantes 2 horas.

Si van a comprarlo, haganlo en descuentos, porque definitivamente no merece el precio completo.

145536453.review:
Un breve juego de terror psicológico que consigue enganchar con una historia decente mientras lo vemos todo desde los ojos de un bebé. Bastante turbio dicho así...Dentro reseña!

El juego durará una hora y media o dos y es bastante lineal. La historia nos presenta nuestro segundo cumpleaños donde vivimos con nuestra madre. En nuestra habitación cobrará vida un oso de peluche que será quién nos guíe hacia la verdad. Tenemos un lobby con cuatro escenarios diferentes (obligados) y cada escenario tiene ese toque que recuerda millones a Little Nightmares, donde no sabes si de verdad hay algo que nos "persigue" o solamente ha sido algo que se ha caído.

Y entra en juego la música y la bso, con unos sonidos muy pero que muy conseguidos (lo he jugado con auriculares) hasta ponerte los pelos de punta. Podremos encontrar coleccionables (dibujos) en cada fase. Como mecánicas podemos gatear para escondernos, correr, agarrar y lanzar cosas y un inventario para poner llaves u otras cosas que nos permitan avanzar. Punto a favor es que es casi imposible morir o perderse.

Cuenta muy bien lo que quiere contar, una historia adulta de la que no entraré en spoilers vista desde los ojos de un bebé. Ese toque de escuchar cosas o parecer que has visto algo es lo que mantiene el punto de terror justo. Pensé que sería muy malo, monstruos, huir, esconder. Para nada, podemos subir a muchos sitios libremente. No diré si hay monstruos o no para no joder la sorpresa, pero de verdad que hacen falta más juegos de terror light así.

En general funciona en todo (subs en castellano y voces en inglés, poca accesibilidad y letra pequeña), buena historia, buena jugabilidad, perfecta duración y espero que esta gente haga más cosas así. Gracias por leer! <3

144917147.review:
[h1]4/10[/h1]
[h3]Random game key: 2/152[/h3]
Let me be clear, this isn't a bad game by any means. However, I can't really recommend purchasing it due to the steep price for just an hour of gameplay. There's no replayability here, which means once you're done, you're pretty much done for good.

The story has a dark-ish vibe, even though it follows a predictable path. But I'm not too fussed about that. What did bother me a bit was that I wasn't really invested, mainly because I saw what they were going for once the first horror element was introduced.

Gameplay-wise, it's pretty basic stuff. I never really felt threatened by the monsters; they're quite forgiving. I understand that the focus might not have been on making it super challenging, so I won't gripe about that too much. It's worth noting that the only time I died was when I unexpectedly fell through the floor—make of that what you will.

Overall, it's not a bad game, though I wouldn't call it fantastic either. There are other games that tackle similar themes with more depth and finesse, in my opinion.

144460128.review:
This is still the only horror game I actively wanted to try for myself (I don't usually tap into the horror genre). The idea of a helpless toddler navigating a twisted nightmare world was more than enough to intrigue me, even on paper. I eagerly anticipated its 2014 release, hoping to be drawn in by its premise alone.

And this many years later, I still don't regret buying it. An all-time favorite, and not just in the Indie scene.

You don't play Among the Sleep for its graphical fidelity, or its mechanics (though the simplicity of said mechanics is still welcome), or any scripted scares. No, you play this game for its intimidating scale that makes you feel small and powerless, every step of the way. You play it for its dark, quiet, unsettling atmosphere, and unrelenting sound design that leaves you consistently anxious, even when no threat is present. You play it for its colorful, surreal, fantastical setting, with environmental storytelling that very cleverly leaves enough details to clue you in on the main twist before it even happens. And even then, it doesn't quite specify the full picture until it's sure you've seen enough.

If you're playing through this game with the intent of simply completing the objectives, you're doing it wrong. Don't just play it. Experience it. Take your time, absorb the environment, really get a feel for how tiny and isolated you are in a world so unfamiliar. Don't be afraid to look around. The visual cues will really engage you. And I don't just mean the collectible drawings. Look at the environments and see if they imply anything in particular.

This is a beautiful tragedy with a very adult message about perception, and how our choices and behaviors can greatly affect how our children see us, all told through the perspective of its victim.

Krillbite nailed this one out of the park.

144346546.review:
"Among the Sleep" este o aventură captivantă care te plasează în pielea unui copil mic, oferind o perspectivă unică și emoționantă asupra lumii din jur. Jocul reușește să creeze o atmosferă tensionată și misterioasă, datorită faptului că vei explora mediul înconjurator în timp ce ești vulnerabil și în căutarea mamei tale dispărute.

Unul dintre aspectele remarcabile ale jocului este prezentarea vizuală impresionantă. Designul detaliat al mediilor reușește să capteze esența unei lumi văzute prin ochii unui copil. De la camera de copil până la locuri înfricoșătoare, precum subsolul și alte locuri misterioase, fiecare detaliu este plin de semnificație și îmbogățește experiența de joc.

Povestea jocului se dezvăluie treptat și subtil, cu indicii și fragmente de amintiri care îți dezvăluie treptat povestea. Acest aspect face jocul mai captivant, deoarece vă simțiți încurajați să explorați în profunzime pentru a descoperi adevărul din spatele acestei povești enigmatice.

Mecanica jocului pune accentul pe explorare și rezolvarea de puzzle-uri, oferindu-ți o varietate de provocări care te țin angajat. Interacțiunea cu obiectele din mediul înconjurător și utilizarea imaginației pentru a găsi soluții sunt elemente esențiale ale experienței de joc.

În ceea ce privește atmosfera, "Among the Sleep" reușește să creeze o tensiune constantă prin sunetele și efectele sonore. Jocul te menține într-o stare de alertă constantă, provocându-ți imaginatia și simțurile în moduri care îți vor păstra interesul în întreaga aventură.

Cu toate acestea, poate exista o oarecare repetiție în mecanicile de joc, iar povestea poate fi interpretată în mai multe moduri, ceea ce poate genera dezbatere și speculații între jucători.

Pe scurt, "Among the Sleep" este o experiență captivantă și emoționantă, care aduce o nouă perspectivă asupra jocurilor de aventură. Grafica detaliată, povestea intrigantă și atmosfera tensionată se combină pentru a oferi un joc memorabil pentru cei care își doresc să experimenteze ceva diferit. Cu toate micile sale imperfecțiuni, jocul rămâne o alegere excelentă pentru cei care apreciază jocurile inovatoare și narrative.

143455790.review:
TL:DR: a short one experience you can finish in one sitting well worth it.

A lot of horror games struggle to give something that you can relate to, sometimes you just want something more simple. This game taps into something I've never experienced before, yet something everyone has felt but most don't remember. Of course the story is personal, but the small ways a child's mind twists the ordinary world is something that I've never seen explored before in a horror game. Its so well balanced, nothing feels over the top or forced, keeping things playful yet tense. There are a couple of bland parts, but the that's about 10% of the experience. The rest is something really special. The way the sounds were used, the size of the character, the visuals, it really tripped me out.

The story is also pretty good and grounded. Without spoiling anything, its something a lot can understand even if they didn't go through. And when the pieces come together it hits you hard.

Can't recommend it enough. Yes, it is a walking simulator with generic puzzles, but its the way that its presented that will keep you hooked till the end.

[h1]Our nightmares are drawn from reality[/h1]

This game is really about children's nightmares, and it's actually a child you're playing. 

Recommended by a friend, I was slightly disappointed by the time it took for the game to reveal its potential. It's only when you're being chased and have to avoid the creature that the game really comes into its own. The puzzles are well constructed and reinforce the childhood theme.

For a small price, it's well worth it. But it clearly wouldn't be my first choice.

136637548.review:
[b]*Recent playthrough completed in about 3 hours.
**Achievement notes at the end of this review.[/b]

If you're dreaming of being a toddler again and having all the freedom to go on an adventure and no responsibilities, then you've found your game. You can stop dreaming and then immediately start dreaming again, as the title implies. As an unnamed infant you're going to go and explore the depths of your own mind and memories as a means of understanding and processing what is happening in your life.

Honestly, this becomes pretty clear within about the first minute of the game before any actual gameplay takes place. The following levels really just touch on the emotional experience of it all both for the player and how they perceive it to be for the beings that they encounter. While I would have preferred the game to be a little more of a detective story, I'm not sure what one can reasonably expect to find in a game where you're literally playing a two year old.

So what's the goal here? Navigate modestly sized environments, avoid unpleasant roaming entities and figure out what the nightmare is all about - ignoring what I said before, it's fairly obvious right from the start - while optionally collecting drawings scattered around the levels.

[b]*Gameplay[/b]
AtS is essentially a stealth game but greatly simplified. Unnamed Child can open doors and hide in closets, crawl under furniture and move at surprisingly high speed when down on the ground. Running is an option but not for long. Basic item manipulation such as grabbing and throwing is possible and so is climbing up onto obstacles that are at perhaps chest height or so. Altogether this gives you enough ways of navigating the dream worlds you enter, looking for memories to recover. The foes you'll face wander the dream levels in solitude, warning you of their presence with strong visual and audio cues (distorted screen for one), giving you a chance to look for cover.
Solid Snake you are not, but the game comes with a low enough difficulty that you don't have to worry about being perfectly hidden. Apparently all you have to do is be under something to be perfectly safe, alternatively hide inside something.
There are no real puzzles in the game but you do have to go around and collect an item here or there to unlock the way forward.
If there's anything I feel I should be commenting on it's the somewhat minor clunkiness of climbing objects. You sometimes need to get the proper angle for it to work and that can be a little annoying when the game is letting you know a baddie is nearby. I don't recall it ever seriously getting in my way of progress or survival, but it's a minor annoyance.

The horror part of the game is mostly the suspense of the nightmare creatures out to find and "get" you, aided by dark areas, oversized obstacles and items like boots or raincoats. The creatures themselves, being lonesome as they are, aren't particularly scary outside of the character design aspect. As a first time player getting into this game I was very careful and slow to move around and between 'cover' (read: furniture like coffee tables and beds) because I wasn't sure about the parameters of failure: how many enemies are there, how can I be detected, etc.
You're also not completely alone through most of the game, your new best friend Mr. Bear is usually with you to provide cuddles and light - emitted from him like a small beacon when held in front of you. This mechanic isn't quite necessary for progress but it's just what a two year old needs in a nightmare.
Turns out that it's generally quite easy to get through any level without being caught out - doesn't matter if you can literally make eye contact with the monster in question, just being out of reach is enough.
Clearly the intention is for you to be able to take in and appreciate the environments the devs have crafted for you, getting through the game like you would a short story rather than a puzzle or a challenge of skill.

In conclusion, expect a fairly smooth ride all the way through. The gameplay isn't dazzling, there's no clever mechanics or clever gimmicks but when you see it as more of an interactive little story it's rather decent. Story-wise, it doesn't REALLY end up going anywhere helpful. There's also a prologue level available that sets up the main game but again, no ending. Is it something the game absolutely needs? No, I suppose not. But it still would've been nice, barring any kind of sequel.
So, have you got this title sitting in your backlog, collecting virtual dust? Dust it off, have a go at it and check it off your list in a few hours time!

[b]**Achievements:[/b] Perfectly in line with just beating the game itself, acquiring the achievements for Among The Sleep is quite easy and can be done within a single (your first, in fact) playthrough. All you have to do is literally play around a bit in the first playable part of the game, beat the game and find all of the drawings scattered around the levels. Naturally you can find their locations in steam guides but with the levels not being huge and complicated, you likely won't need a guide at any point. Just be sure to look in every corner. Most of them are in plain sight, lying under furniture, in a closet or something like that. Find 10 per level and you're done! Start looking for them after night falls and from then on in every level, including the prologue that's available from the main menu. Happy art hunting!

***

135036188.review:
I remember there was this one time, about 10 or so years ago, I was discussing random video game ideas with a bunch of people. And of the many things being pitched that day, the premise that stuck with me the most was that of a child and his teddy bear braving unknown horrors, with the teddy bear assuming a more proactive role to ensure the child's safety. When I was made aware of Among the Sleep's existence, my initial assumption was how this game would fit that bill.

Unfortunately, I was wrong.

Rather than a horror or adventure game, Among the Sleep turned out to be a very boring walking simulator. The game tries to creep you out pretty early on, but doesn't really follow through with its threats. Contrary to what the teddy bear warns you upon gaining access to new areas: you don't really have to be quiet, you don't have to avoid lingering in any one particular area. And most importantly: you don't have to be scared, because nothing ever happens.

The game is unbelievably linear. The game starts at your house, a couple of story elements compel you to explore, you inevitably end up in an otherworldly hub from where you travel to a small number of linear worlds in a specific order. In each world, you go on a fetch quest to unlock the exit that allows you to return back to the hub to travel to another linear world to perform another fetch quest. Rinse and repeat.

The game nails the atmosphere down, but it doesn't make any creative use of its elements. The only thing you get out of being a baby is a unique camera angle, and when the teddy bear isn't acting as the game's guide/narrator, he serves the purpose of a glorified lantern to light up dark areas.

The game is boring.

And I could keep rambling on, but I feel confident that "boring" really summarizes well my opinion on Among the Sleep.

En Among the Sleep, te conviertes en un bebé que tiene que buscar a su madre en un mundo lleno de pesadillas y misterios. Y aunque el juego puede ser un poco aterrador, es realmente divertido. Me encanta que el juego sea en primera persona, porque sientes que estás viviendo la historia como si fueras un bebé de verdad. Desde el suelo hasta los muebles, todo se ve gigante y está súper detallado. Además, la música es genial, te mantiene en tensión pero al mismo tiempo te hace sentir acompañado.

133262062.review:
Among the Sleep es un juego indie de terror en primera persona bastante original e interesante. Ese punto de singularidad se lo da el hecho de que tomamos el papel de un niño de dos años, y lo cierto es que le sienta de maravilla, ya que consigue hacerte sentir la vulnerabilidad y el miedo del pequeño.

Con ayuda de nuestro amigo, un osito de peluche que habla (esto ya lo he visto...), vamos en búsqueda de nuestra madre (la cual da miedo, todo sea dicho). La verdad es que la ambientación es una gozada. Esa mezcla de elementos infantiles y tétricos es un gran acierto. El tipo de gráficos también ayuda a crear esa atmósfera.

A pesar de que dura poco (unas 3 horas), y aunque en lo jugable es simplemente un walking simulator, me ha parecido un soplo de aire fresco en el mundillo del terror. Si te gusta el género, es bastante interesante.

(*) Los logros no funcionan en Steam Deck.

132993240.review:
Not a super long game (can be longer if you hunt for more collectibles), but I thoroughly enjoyed finally getting to sit down and play this all the way through. 

Among the Sleep on the surface appears to be another horror game done through a child's eyes, but without giving too much of the story away, it goes far more than its initial appearance. 

I enjoyed the atmosphere, the voice-acting and the storytelling with few words. I wouldn't say it's the "scariest" horror game I ever played, but there were a couple times I did get genuinely startled/spooked. It just felt like a great, semi-short experience that left me with questions at the end and wondering why I didn't give it a shot sooner. I bought it for $5 on sale awhile back, but depending on how you look at it, $17 full price isn't too terribly bad for the dollar/playtime ratio. 

The only warning I'd give to anyone looking to play this is: Not everything's as it seems.

132163983.review:
This is a tough game to recommend, I didn't dislike it, but the length and clunkiness really do it in.
I'd rate it 5.5/10
If you can get this game on a very deep sale and you like short horror games, then I'd say check it out, but for the average person I'd say you can skip this game off.

Pros:
The game is very immersive and you do really feel like a helpless child in the game.

The enemies are decently scary.

The game's story is pretty well told for most of it.

Cons:
The enemies lose their scariness after you master the game's mechanics

Movement is very clunky and I clipped through the map a few times when going from standing to crawling.

The story is well told and I love the uniqueness of the concept, but the ending feels rushed and abrupt.

The story is very short, around 3 hours. Normally I prefer longer games, but I wouldn't mind a 5 hour game, this however is just much too short.

There is extra content, but it is just a single level with some chases and puzzles, not really anything to write about.

Final Score: 5.5/10 Not worth buying unless you are very interested in the concept or a big horror fan.

131613961.review:
[h1]Muchas pegas[/h1]
Sé que nadie va a leer esto porque es un juego que tiene bastantes años ya (2014) y ya lo ha jugado elrubius así que no tiene sentido que la escriba, pero aún así daré mi humilde opinión.

Por empezar con ventajas, para su época tuvo que ser un buen juego: la idea central está muy bien para la óptica del terror, y tiene algunos conceptos muy interesantes, como los monstruos, el gatear/estar de pie, etc. Los gráficos debían de estar bien para la época, lo suficientemente gloomy para despertar los miedos infantiles.

Pero el juego se hace repetitivo y aburrido... Las mecánicas no están bien equilibradas (No merece la pena cambiar entre uno y otro movimiento, basicamente te obligan a hacerlo); la tensión no te consigue mantener en el juego lo suficiente, la mayoría de "sustos" son lejanos y no impactan, no hay un peligro tangible, y la dificultad es inexistente durante todo el juego, que no es muy largo. Y es que ese es el problema principal, para el precio que tiene (18€ en el momento de la reseña un juego de hace 9 años) su duración es de 3-4 horas aproximadas, y no es tan interesante. 

Si buscas una idea original, con una historia sencilla pero directa, ligeramente emotiva, puedes darle una oportunidad cogiéndolo en descuento. Si buscas un survival horror, en cambio, es mejor no buscar aquí.

Story-wise, it is a meaningful story-telling, anyone who has children can relate to how real it is.

131477036.review:
[h1]Night Terrors[/h1]
This is one of my personal favorite horror titles of all time. While it isn't extremely scary it has a great atmosphere. I cant say too much without spoiling the story but I will point out a few things I enjoy. The perspective is very smart and well executed. Having you play as a child allows the game to scare you in ways they couldn't otherwise. Its not just a gimik, its pivotal to the story. 125641260.review:
Among the Sleep is on the surface a cuter horror game about a child that gets lost in a nightmare with his teddy bear and must find his way back home; do NOT be fooled, don't worry no spoilers here, however it is truly a deep game. Story wise, the dev's are absolutely brilliant in the use of symbolism, a child's POV, and incredibly complex situations. I admit, I was not prepared for this story when I streamed this game. I absolutely applaud the writers of this story and how well it was executed with subtlety, finesse, and just enough of a push when needed to "see" the reality of the situation.
Gameplay, art and sound design was fun and enjoyable, in matching with the storyline and the overall feel of the game, a child in a nightmare landscape, you are walking through a nightmare solving puzzles. There were a few instances in gameplay that were frustrating, I personally struggled a bit with the field of vision as it just felt a bit off, however it was a minor inconvenience at worst. The swamp area was very maze like and easy to get lost in, again though, minor inconvenience at worst. The art design in most levels were simplistically stunning in some levels, i.e. you never play as a toddler, this POV provides a fresh challenge, and the art design builds around this POV as opposed to just "lowering the camera."
Final thought, Among the Sleep is a gem of a game and I would highly recommend grabbing it. While Among is a bit on the shorter side, it can be completed fairly quickly in about 2.5 hours, it delivers an absolutely brilliant and emotional gut punch from a unique perspective, AND it is still most certainly a horror game which, at least in my perspective, makes it that much better! 8/10.

124735880.review:
I first saw this game somewhere around 2012-2013. Ever since, this game kept going in and out of my head but i could never find it. I had such vivid, but very few and specific memories of it. Once i found the game, it was new to me again. I knew nothing about it, despite having seen and loved it before. The part that i remembered so vividly was the library. I remembered the bookshelves and the monster, but that was it.

I didnt expect this game to take the dark turn it took, i kept thinking to myself "This is all in the protagonists head", but it was so much more than that. Everything here was amazing, but a tinge too easy. The parts that were scary were really frightening, but the parts that werent were a bit too common.

I have to give props to Krillbite Studios for something that most people probably wouldn't pick up on, and thats the fact that you're completely helpless. You have no weapon, you're slow and small, the only defense you have is being able to hide, but you cannot run.

I got this game on 75% sale during the Steam Halloween 2022 sale, but i would have paid full price for it. In fact, i was going to pay full price, but it just so happened that this game was on sale right as i was about to buy it. Even if its not on sale for you, i would fully recommend getting this game anyways.

The game is short and doesnt overstay its welcome, just when you start thinking "Is it over soon?", you're right at the end, both for good and for bad.

The gameplay and story is 8/10. Objects can feel a bit encumbering, but after all, you are a 2 year old baby.

120381691.review:
This review is specially made for those who like to get all the achievements and have this game in their backlog (minor spoilers ahead).

[b]Description:[/b]  
Among the Sleep is a 3D platformer game with simple puzzles and object finding with a horror theme. You control a lost toddler and with the help of your teddy bear you will need to find your mother, while avoiding the monster that is chasing you (similar to the new Resident Evil 2). The level design is solid and varied and the story is compelling, and a little sad when you find out what the monster is.

[b]Achievements:[/b]  
[b]How many:[/b] 10  Achievements, you’ll need to find some hidden collectibles.
[b]How much time:[/b] Around 4 hours, with a guide for the collectibles.
[b]Game difficulty:[/b] Easy. The puzzles and platforming are simple and you’ll only need to run and hide from the monster in some of the levels.
[b]Achievements’ Difficulty:[/b] Easy. The harder achievement will be getting all the collectibles, that would take a lot of time without a guide since there are a lot of them, but there are guides to help. The prologue has to be picked from chapter select, it won’t load either before or after the ending.

[b]Overall opinion:[/b]  
It’s a horror 3D platformer where you play as a toddler. It has a compelling story and solid level design and ambiance. Both the platforming and puzzles are easy and you'll go through the game at a fast pace.


[b]Join and follow my group Ribbon Hunters for more suggestions and reviews of easy indie games to get all the achievements: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42556190-Ribbon-Hunters/ [/b]

119866231.review:
I rate Among the Sleep: Enhanced Edition 3/5. OK. This is a pretty creepy, very tense and very short game with only one ending. Including its prologue, it only took me 5 hours to play through, so get it during a sale.

+ Great graphics which strike a perfect balance between a childlike cartoon style and an absolute creepfest of terror. What should be fairly ordinary, common, house-hold objects take on terrifying aspects.

+ But really, it’s the fantastic sound that makes this game as good as it is. I have never heard a heartbeat sound effect done so well and so subtly in ANY game. All the other ambient, environmental sounds also combine to create one of the most tense, foreboding atmospheres I have ever heard in a game.

+ Great idea to make your character be a defenseless 2 year old child. I have never felt so weak or helpless in any game. The consistency with which this game presents that first-person perspective is excellent. You walk poorly. You crawl faster but then can’t see as well. Everything is tall and most things seem hopelessly out-of-reach. You wind up constantly looking for things to hide beneath, just in case.

+ There’s no gore in this entire game but I found it to be one of the more creepy games I’ve ever played. Although this game is about a little kid, this game is not intended for little kids I think.

+ Don’t forget to play the ‘prologue’ in the level select menu. It is possibly even better than the main game However, it might be best to play it after you play the main game.

+/- This game features unlockable making-of extras in the form of a 3D museum of sorts. I think it would have been better to have ALL included background information about this game unlocked by default instead of hidden behind a requirement to collect various children’s drawings during the game. Why hide your work?

+/- The key bindings menu recognized my additional mouse buttons. However, the controls can be clunky at times. It is overly difficult to climb onto objects or to lift your feet over short changes in elevation. Sometimes you cannot easily get into cabinets or onto shelves which should be (and appear to be) easy to get into or onto.

+/- Dying isn’t scary. Being in danger of dying is really scary but actually dying isn't scary. This can cause dangerous situations to lose their sense of danger and this is one of the greatest challenges facing horror games; how do you maintain a sense of danger without making the game frustrating?

+/- This is, ultimately, a fairly easy game. The puzzles are usually straightforward though they do involve several basic fetch-quests. However it can be hard to know exactly where the game wants you to go. 

+/- There is perhaps too much mystery in this game. Until you get to the end of the game you really don’t have any real clue as to what is really happening.

+/- The end is poignant and meaningful but it is also somewhat unsatisfying. You might feel like you, as a game player, went through a fairly anxious, stressful and tense game for not much of a reward. But perhaps that makes some sense too, given the game’s ending circumstances. This game's ending has important messages.

- There is only 1 ending for this game and the events in this very short game are so memorable that there is little reason to ever want to replay it. Hence, this game has no replay value. 

So what we have here are 5 possibly overpriced, (unless you get this game on sale) fairly stressful, creepy hours of quasi-fun before you get to an ending which is so serious in its tone that, while it explains the game it also, in a way, spoils any sense of fun it previously had (and you might even guess the ending before you get there). This is all presented with nice graphics, truly excellent sound effects and from a very unique first-person perspective. 

If Among the Sleep was a little longer and allowed more freedom to get different, alternate endings I’d almost certainly rate it higher (if its greater length didn’t also make it repetitive). As it is though, it’s merely OK but, if you get it cheap, it's certainly worth playing through once.

7.5/10 This game is good, I really like the idea of playing as a 2 year old and experiencing horror as a kid even though the real situation is not as scary as the kid sees it. 117547788.review:
(spoilers ahead)

Among the sleep may not seem like a horror game, but I think id categorize it more as true horror. because you play as a toddler and the imagination and fears of this baby are alive. makes someone no matter how old creeped out. Along with the child protag. it's a small detail but anything that has lettering is gibberish, which adds to the whole you are a child. 

The game play itself may be short, but it's still worth your while. I love this game to bits. I played when I was younger I'm a bit older replaying and I didn't understand much then, but now there's so much. it honestly makes me tear up it's sad once you think about it. To start teddy which is gifted from your dad to you has the voice of your father, which he guides you through and helps and makes you feel safe. the main game itself is great in my opinion, the perfect amount of cute, creepy, and heartwarming in a way. I like the idea you go through your house and find memories with your mom when she's the monster. 

The prologue was great, it's short and it made me sad :( I DIDN'T GET THE LAST STUFFED TOY AND HE'S LOST IT IN THE SNOW :(. 


Overall id give it a 10/10 there's one bug in this game I ran into it's not game-breaking you reset the checkpoint and it's 100% fine. This is in my top 5 for horror games. brings a lot of emotions out.

I think it is neat to see a game in the future like you're grown up and teddy is with you, or you play as teddy. just something that crossed my mind.

anyway thanks to the devs for making this game, truly was a great experience. <3.

117539105.review: I'm a pansy, so you probably won't find this as scary as I did. That said, you probably will find it as sad as I did. A little bit short, grab on sale if possible. Overall, a solid 7.5 out of 10.

117454225.review:
Aventura de terror con una historia brutal.

Somos un niño de 2 años acompañado de un oso de peluche que, en una pesadilla, tenemos que buscar a nuestra madre que ha desaparecido, y todo se basa en traumas que tiene el pequeño por cosas ocurridas en su casa y con su familia, y para ir pasando capitulos tendremos que ir resolviendo puzzles para nada complejos.

El control del bebé es una maravilla, podemos andar o gatear con el a nuestro gusto. Los escenarios del juego son fascinantes, y la ambientación sonora hace que realmente se te pongan los pelos de punta en ocasiones.

Me ha encantado el juego y lo recomiendo 100%. Ha sido de las pocas veces que me he llevado sustos con un juego y me ha mantenido bastante en tensión la mayoría del tiempo.

Una vez terminéis el juego recomiendo entrar en la sección "Museo", donde el oso de peluche nos va haciendo un recorrido turístico a través de como fue desarrollado el juego.

117119496.review:
This game was a while back my first ever Horror Game and I can recommend it. I wouldn't suggest this game for beginners as someone is actually chasing you and you have to keep track to not be too long in the dark, can end pretty badly and you ain't be able to continue properly.

Overall, the design is good, its well made. The view is out of a baby and you get basically to know how the world for a small toddler can be, it can be scary sometimes. I would include a Trigger Warning for people who suffer from alcohol abuse as *SPOILER* in the end you see the Mother being drunk and consuming alcohol *SPOILER END*

The graphic, the soundtrack and the overall feeling of the game are something what will truly amaze you, for people who play with controller...the support is incredible. I played controller and keyboard, the controller is as smooth as keyboard. If you wanna support a creator I would recommend that game. It deserves more attention. If you are scared you need definitely over 12h to complete it (as mentioned...I started my horror gaming carreer with it and it took me 10h to complete as I constantly stopped, hid and didn't wanted to continue without someone call with me on discord)

if you are further into horror you usually can complete it in 2 - 3 hours. So yeah, overall this is a win if purchased, I am unsure if 17€ are justified given you complete it in 3 hours, but the price is justified if you are scared and play it the first time as you end up over 10h.

114305376.review:
[b]"Among the Sleep" has an interesting concept, as you control a clumsy two years old baby inside an imaginative, surreal world. Unfortunately it fails to deliver a complete and strong experience. Right from the beginning it doesn't give you a purpose. You just wonder expecting something new to happen. The plot has no continuity and the entire game is an abstract, random turn of events. The gameplay feels unresponsive and the puzzles are completely uncreative. Also the visuals seemed to me a bit clunky. Yet, I'm upvoting it just for those few parts that managed to give me some atmospheric, really creepy moments.


Manometer: 5/10[/b]


The good
- It's an interesting concept to control a two years old baby that barely walks, trying simultaneously to be stealthy.
- Well designed, imaginative world. Nice atmospheric lighting through the entire game. It looks really surreal at some points and with the change of scale it strongly reminds me of something like "Alice in Wonderland".
- Some parts look like nightmares. They're really creepy with strong, dark atmosphere.
- A few nice mechanics here and there (like hugging the bear to fear less). Also it's interesting that crawling is faster and more steady than walking. You are a baby after all.
- Ultra-wide camera initially seemed to me extreme and a little bit tiring. But it worked well on creating an impression of deformation along with a stressful feeling.
- It talks about some serious social issues, although it does it in a shallow way.

The bad
- There is no continuity to the plot and it gets too abstract or symbolic at some points. You don't know why all these are happening. I get it that a baby wouldn't understand too but you need a reason, a purpose to play. The entire game looks like a random turn of events. A random world after another without a profound connection to each other. You don't even know what and why haunts you. You just walk and explore without a purpose just waiting for something new to happen.
- Gameplay feels heavy and not fluid at all. Ok, you're supposing to control a clumsy baby but you cannot enjoy the game with such unresponsive mechanics. Also puzzles are extremely simplistic and childish. Something more creative or challenging would be nice.
- Mediocre visuals. Everything feels clunky from the models to the low resolution, blurry textures. It just feels unpolished. They could have followed a more minimalistic approach if they hadn't the budget.
- Sound design is excessive. All the time you hear distant sounds, screams, creaks, voices and more without a profound reason, when nothing really is happening. It tries to create a spooky atmosphere but most of the time audio doesn't fit to the game's pace and on-screen action.
- Voice acting is not that convincing. It was ruining the vibe I was into.

114234675.review: years ive waited to play this game and cant say im disappointed besides the fact that im finished with the game now :/

113869010.review:
I watched markiplier play this when I was younger, so playing it myself after several years gave me a lot of nostalgia for simpler times. It's still just as creepy and intense as I remember, with effective suspense and a constant sense of dread for what monsters might start chasing you at any moment.

The graphics are okay and still hold up decently well (though the model of the mom is...yikes). The lighting and atmosphere is well-done and the gameplay is really good. It's fun and scary being limited to crawling or awkwardly walking as you play as a toddler, which enhances the feeling of helplessness and horror.

The story itself is...tragic, and sadly true to real life for a lot of kids growing up. Play it yourself, and you'll find many references to the issues in the kid's life represented in simple child's drawings, objects scattered casually about in the environment, and even the monsters themselves. I won't give away what it is, but the symbolism is hardly subtle and you'll probably figure it out quickly.

113268708.review: I'm going to rate this as a buy, but not at full price. Man it feels like I write some variation of that sentence a lot reviewing games lately. It's a walking simulator with only a bit of very light puzzle solving. It's not really a horror game as the only thing that ever made me feel like I was in danger was falling into water. I don't want to go into spoilers, but anyone with a keen eye will know where this is all likely headed after the introductory scene. There was one minor twist, but even that was telegraphed about one third of the way into the game. Technically it was fine. I didn't encounter any bugs and that's a minor miracle with the current state of gaming. It has some collectible busy work that as far as I can tell is just to get some achievements and adds nothing to the game. Why it's even there is a bigger mystery than the game ever presents. So why am I rating this as a yes? For a couple dollars it wouldn't be a bad way to spend a couple atmospheric hours, but the prices for these types of games are often ridiculous and this is no exception. If you enjoy these types of games and can get it cheap during a Steam sale, I'd say it's worth a go, but I'm so close to a downvote and I feel my tolerance for these "games" is getting lower with each one I play and I just hope that doesn't make me unfairly judge something down the line out of pure fatigue for the walking sim genre.

Interesting view from the eyes of a baby on a very usual problems in family.
Great thing shown here is how an infant can try to interpret behavior of parents, their problems and arguments using just a small experience and knowledge about life.
Nobody is perfect, life situations can be not strictly good and bad, but more complex.
And when young family decides to have a children, already having problems in their relationship - this often leads to trauma for the kid.
I like such indie games, because they can ask hard, serious questions. And can show the consequences of our possible errors.
I enjoyed Among the Sleep. And can recommend you to do the same :)

It is, however, short which stops the game from dragging on. Would recommend if price drops or if the game is on offer for 50% off or more.

107107218.review: Fucking hell that teddy bear is scary

106963100.review:
It really has a unique concept that explores it for a total of 15 minutes then becomes another generic walking simulator. It has no sense of peril and all the "sad story" comments/reviews/accolades are lying to you. Its short and does not deliver on its unique concept. If you are a seasoned horror game player, chances are you will find this game lacking. if you are a newcomer, there's a million other things you should play instead. Scares are laughably easy to predict and have been done before. I can not recommend this game.

Pros
- art style is decent, nothing fantastic, but good for a small time indie developer, even considering its 4 year old age. 
- there is a GOOD sense of atmospheric horror throughout. 
- its a unique concept. Not many games have you playing as a toddler, but the concept is explored very briefly
- the first few minutes of the game are fantastic
- tying in with the atmosphere, I enjoyed the sound design. It adds to tension
- great companion in the game. Teddy is fantastic

Cons 
- length. It's a short game I was able to complete in 3 hours. It's full price is almost $17 dollars. 
- it does not deliver on the concept of playing as a toddler. After the intro and a small amount of time afterwards, you can replace the character with basically anyone. This is a real shame, how great would a horror game be if it expressed childhood fears?
- the atmosphere is tense, but you soon realize there is really no sense of danger minus a few parts
- there is no story. I mention this because many reviews praise its poignant story. There's 2 wham scenes that one could consider emotional. Otherwise, there's really nothing besides "grab plot coupons".
- the puzzles are among the simplest you can expect in a horror game. The gameplay boils down to find an object, plug it in a hole. 
- the environments you explore are uninspired, linear, and nonsensical. There is not an overlapping theme to what you are exploring, nor a connection to the story. It would be the same as Resident Evil going from a mansion, to a desert after entering a door, then the ocean after another one.
- lack of scares. There is good building up, but again, you realize that nothing but a door slamming or an object falling awaits you when the tension reaches its peak.

106941432.review: Overall, a charming, well-constructed game with great atmosphere/tension and lovely visuals. Excellent sound design really makes this game. However, the controls can be absolutely infuriating, and the sections where you have to throw things come close to ruining the game.  Well worth a play,  hope to see more and more polished things from this dev in the future.

106340934.review:
A quaint little atmospheric horror game that has no business being so intriguing, considering you play as a baby. 

I wouldn't consider it drop-dead terrifying, but the horror of this game doesn't feel cheap either; there are cues to tell you when its time to hide, and sometimes I feel like I barely made it to safety at all. There is no gore and no petty jumpscares, either. This game could make for a pretty decent first horror game for anyone looking to get scared, but still be able to sleep at night.

The atmosphere is very good too, although I never had much time nor patience to look at it all, especially when its usually too dark to look at the finer details, but the levels are straightforward and unique.

I didn't find the story all that interesting. It leaves a lot to be desired, although it does help you understand what the poor kid is going through, and can feel like an interesting interpretation of childhood trauma. 

I'd say the game's strongest point is ironically the fact you play as a baby. You don't speak, only babble when frightened or climbing, and if you run too far, you fall over onto all fours. You move faster by crawling, and the whole world feels massive thanks to your tiny size, which makes using boxes and drawers to climb up high feel like a big job sometimes. This kid is more of a gymnast than any 2-year old I've ever known, and considering he's the one witnessing all these horrors around him, you sometimes feel just as vulnerable and scared as he probably is.

105478195.review:
I did not know what I was getting into when I started playing the game.
I saw the cute logo, and the screenshots - and it looked like a nice walking simulator with puzzles, which you play as a little kid.
Boy, was I wrong!

The game literally made my skin crawl!

Now I'm not sure that a true horror game fan will like this game.
Horror games have become longer and scarier in recent years, and people playing them become desensitized - needed bigger and longer portions of horror to enjoy.
This is not the case here.
The game is relatively short.
And much less scary than Outlast and the likes.

But for someone like me, not used to horror games - it was scary AF!

One negative thing I do need to mention about the game - is the nausea it causes (to people susceptible to it).
Most modern first-person games don't cause nausea, as they run pretty smoothly.
The last game I've experienced nausea in was "Black Mesa", being on an outdate/unoptimized game engine.
Unfortunately, Among the Sleep suffers from the same issue.
Somehow the jerkiness, and the climbing, just did not sit well with me. And I couldn't play it more than 1 hour at a time.

Other than that - it's everything the other reviewers mentioned.
And you should at least check it out (if you enjoy these kind of games).

103304252.review:
This is...a pretty amazing game. It was trying to do something ambitious and interesting, namely simulate what it's like to be a toddler going through something scary, and it pulled that off surprisingly well. There are some amazing game-mechanics decisions, such as the fact that you can crawl to go through tight passages and whatnot, but it's also your fastest form of movement. Because, you know, you're toddler. Standing up has advantages like being able to climb stuff, but it's not how you really GET places. And to get light, you hug your Teddy Bear, because it makes you feel safer.

Not everything totally worked, and the story, while good, felt a little unfinished. Just a tad. I feel like it needed just a bit more at the end to fully make the experience satisfying. Still, an amazing, creative, and brave idea, done very well!

101199362.review:
EDIT. I tried to get a refund on this crap and but because I left the game on once, it had clocked up 9 hrs playtime. You can only get a refund if you have played up to 2 hrs.  I already have it uninstalled and want of rid of this junk permanently. And now my review...

1 Don't buy this (or at least not until you read point 3)
2 Don't trust star ratings or go by the first few hits on Google 
3 ***Do read proper reviews***  

Apart from the sheer sense of time wasting you get when plodding around looking for tokens, the play is clunky and annoying. It is one of those amateurish games where a company had a lovely idea and then screwed it up by not being able to turn the dream into a reality. They have effectively stolen a cute and creepy idea through poor execution and lack of imagination. Which is a pity, because a baby based horror could be great. 

Tips/Spoiler alerts. 
You are practically invincible. Turn down the sound and up the gamma. you might as well let a toddler play this. You are told, literally TOLD, by the talking teddy what to do. Which is just as well, because it it easy to end up pointlessly stumped,

Mostly though you can just ignore the teddy - especially when it says to be quiet. Don't bother. There is nothing there that will harm you. It's all sound effects. You are creeping around and hiding for nothing. Cheap game dynamic. One you see through the trick you can get on with playing in invincible mode.  

Anyway, to finish - my life is too short to throw good time after bad money and finish this. I've heard it improves, but it would have to a massive, massive jump in quality for me to continue playing. I have been tempted to do so.. just to see.... but I suspect it will be yet another fools errand. So, no thanks, 

As I say, do read other reviews too. Apparently this was a student project. It certainly feels like it. Yuck. This is low--level stuff.

96356688.review:
This is a very interesting concept for a game.


==Spoilers Probably==

You play as a baby who just turned 2 years old and received a teddy bear as a birthday gift by who we later find out is our father, the game shows the baby going through various phases and fears because well, babies don't know better, the monsters in the game and the weird scenarios we're in are nothing more than the perspective of a 2 year old child, our parents just went through a divorce which makes things extra scary and the apparent fact of our mother's alcoholism makes us portray her as a bigger monster than what she is.
One of my favorite scenes is after the main game when you unlock the "Prologue" chapter and you have to go down to the basement to pick up one of your freezing toys, there the boiler comes to life and starts chasing after you, I really liked the creativity behind that.

All in all, it's an interesting concept but too linear and short, which is fine for the kind of game it is but this could've been explored further and they could've made the teddy bear not so darn creepy since they were supposed to be our friend. >:(

96345643.review: It may have only been 2.6 hours, but it was a truly brilliant 2.6 hours, the storytelling, sound and visuals all lead to an immersive experience that had hairs on my neck constantly raised. If you have limited funds, wishlist this one for purchase during a sale. To everyone else, I think it's worth the nod to the developers to buy at price. Short, not sweet, 10/10

95894930.review:
Curioso juego de exploración en primera persona con ciertos toques de terror. Encarnamos a un niño de dos años en busca de su madre desaparecida una noche. Para ello, contaremos con la ayuda de nuestro fiel oso de peluche que nos ayudará ligeramente en nuestra empresa para encontrarla: permite iluminar zonas, mantener a raya a los enemigos temporalmente al abrazarlo, darnos conversación para indicarnos lo que deberíamos hacer...

El juego posee una atmósfera sobrenatural que sigue a nuestro protagonista de manera muy lograda; en base a ciertos recuerdos, sin salir de la propia casa, hay todo un mundo dentro ciertas habitaciones, armarios, muebles (zonas boscosas, pantanos, montañas...) que debemos atravesar si queremos encontrar pistas de la localización de nuestra madre. El toque de terror (algo escaso) lo ponen los pocos enemigos que nos encontraremos, con sus correspondientes jumpscares y persecuciones en un pequeño área.

En eso el juego flojea, ya que teóricamente era un juego de terror. Al final, es más bien un juego de exploración con un ambiente muy logrado, sin apenas terror.

La historia está bien contada, ya que aparte de lo que nos vayamos encontrando en nuestra aventura, nuestro osito hará las veces de narrador, dándonos pistas para los puzzles o contándonos cosas de nuestros recuerdos/vivencias que ayudan a que comprendamos mejor qué es lo que pasa a nuestro alrededor.

Como último punto, destaco la duración de forma negativa: es un juego MUY corto. Se puede acabar en unas dos o tres horas. Aún así, lo recomiendo pillar en una oferta, ya que es una experiencia distinta a un juego de terror como lo conocemos (al precio normal me parece caro para lo que ofrece).

95216677.review:
Great in some parts, lacking in others. 
The Story revolves around a 2 year old child looking for his mother when he is woken up in the middle of the night. The story surprisingly has a great twist at the end which changes the players whole outlook on the events that lead up to that point. The character of Teddy is fine, nothing really made him stand out as anything special except for being an in-game mechanic that i will mention further down in this review. The mother is fine as well but isn't really relevant or shown any characteristics until the end of the game. 
The setting of the child's imagination is so creative with different sections like the playhouse and the park being twisted into this dark imagery that works in favour for the game. 
Graphically, it's a great improvement from the original, however the design of the mother still looks really off (and more scary than the monsters that you encounter in my opinion!!!) and some textures regarding the areas or objects still look a bit dated. The design choices of everything that would be associated with a child such as bedtime books, parks and playhouses are done up in this twisted, nightmarish way and it looks amazing. This definitely helps with some of the dated textures to blend in more. 
The soundtrack wasn't really that present and when it was i never really noticed it which was really disappointing. Audio in this game is great. From the simple shuffling of the child to doors creaking, it really made the overall experience that much more immersive. The only time where the audio really bugged me was when the monsters were near the player which made this really annoying white noise-esque sound. It felt like the game went for a loud = scary approach.
In terms of gameplay, it really let me down. The main premise of this game is to collect all the objects for the different areas that the child has to venture to, to reach his mother. While i'm not expecting any crazy game mechanics, it just didn't feel like there was anything to do except crawl about areas, grab an object and place in a certain place and move onto the next area where while it may be a change of scenery, it ultimately leads to rinse and repeating what had just been done. While the mechanic of hugging Teddy being this light source and reducing fear is a good idea in concept, the execution really fell flat as he was never really needed. The monsters that you encounter as well weren't really that scary or intimidating either. In fact I actually found it really easy to evade them and move onto the next section. While this game may be a 'horror' game, at no point did i feel scared or even tense during my playthrough. 
Overall, while Among the sleeps' storytelling and design may be the focal points, it really lacks that intense gameplay that a good horror game should. However, i do believe that you should experience at least one playthrough of this game as it may resonate more with others than it did myself.

95179834.review:
I wish there was an option to make a mixed review...

The game was good, the concept was great, the atmosphere was good and the gameplay was pretty damn fun and not too hard to figure.
but the game itself has so many problems and some of them are even for being a horror game.

Let's get straight to the point. if it is one of your first horror games or you are generally pretty easy to scare, this game will do the job for you and you probably won't even finish it as it's getting spookier each faze you are going through.

but if you came here after finishing outlast or something, you might as well keep looking for a new horror game to play.
let's get into some spoilers here so stop reading if you are into the game.
the game as they let you know at first sight is about a mother that celebrates her little baby his birthday.
The baby managed to pull his BD gift out of the box and it was a teddy bear, surprisingly a talking teddy bear.
something is after them as much as we know and it isn't explained to us what is this thing, just a big darkness thing.
they are going into the closet and entering a wired looking world that summed up to a little cabin that has a certain amount of doors I'm not sure how much, each door leads the kid to a new location with some cool puzzles he has to solve, all that while a "creepy" looking ghost tries to hunt him down. **I'm going to talk about the ending now and it's a very good one so please if you haven't played the game or watched the full gameplay please stop reading**.

When you finish the game you get to know that the ghost that tried to hunt you down was an implication of your mom's behavior as she was a drinker that mentally hunted you down as you are playing a baby and you couldn't really realize what was happening around you clearly. then your father picked you up and took you away from her as she was mentally ill. 

The ending is rough, great, and went extremely well with the whole game and left me supremely satisfied, and that is the main reason why I left a positive review.

Cons:
-The game constantly made some floor textures invisible and teleported me under platforms when I was simply tried to explore the place a bit. which completely ruined the experience of the game for me.

-It simply ruined the scary vibe it created. the ghost that hunted you was god awful modeled and worse than that it acted worse than a Skyrim NPC. It is such a shame that those five minutes that I had to deal with her were the thing that almost made me review this game negatively. 

After all, it is not a bad game, and I would recommend you to try this game if it is at a discount or being sold for at least under 8 dollars.

btw: as you can see I've managed to finish the game and refund it on time, so if you are not very easy to scare don't worry about your money

93487613.review:
1. [u]Graphics and story[/u] [i]9/10[/i] ([i]Among the sleep[/i] is a game about the story of a little boy who lives with his murky mother. A divorced mother with alcoholism problems. For she fears that will be separated from her son. But the boy still doesn't understand the mother's situation and the game offers understanding from the infant experience. Despite being a short story, we immerse ourselves in surreal landscapes as a little boy. The landscapes are quite artistic, between surrealism and expressionism with vivid colours and contrast lighting. From that point of view, we can see something simple like a piece of furniture transform into a creepy creature that prowls in the gloomy places of the rooms. The character develops in the story and we'll see how he sees things and situations with strong expressions. Furniture, objects and places have undergone a metamorphosis from reality to the experiential understanding of the little boy. The only friend and guide is his birthday present, a teddy bear. A character who will help the little boy to return the memories of love between he and their parents. The adventure of this game takes place at night, in the dream of the boy and his bear in a sullen world.)

2. [u]Playability[/u] [i]10/10[/i] (The dynamics of the game is in the first person. The character movement is guided according to the children movement ability, crawling and slow walking. The game consists of exploration and solving some simple puzzles to progress through the story. And each object for the puzzle, in reality, is an important object with a sentimental charge. It has a meaning. There is also a visual narrative through drawings that show the emotional states between the little boy and his mother. These drawings allow a better understanding of the story. The character can interact with some objects and his teddy is our storyteller. A narrator who will tell us what to do in such situations, how to overcome an obstacle, as well as the implicit meaning of the objects to open doors. The adventure is a learning of the character and an experience of what he lives.)

3. [u]Music and FX[/u] [i]9/10[/i] (The soundtrack is composed of ambient music. Dark ambient sounds accompanied by drone ambient. Music often creates tension and mystery. Other times it appears as if it were all a dream. We'll not listen to lullabies, but rather a dark form of the tension of the little boy experience. Sound variations of objects, creatures, ambient tones. Like the surreal sound of the saxophone like the cries of his mother or brief sounds of the chimes of the bell accompanied by a background of rain sound. Music offers impressions of things and scenarios. Each thing and object has its music. The feeling that the developers have created with the music, is the involvement of the varied sounds and accompanied by the narration and the essential moments of the character. Variation of tensions from calm to anxiety. All those variations capture our impressions, as well as the image and the narrative. Music is the representation of the little boy experience and according to how he sees around him in his situation. The music also narrates his adventure.)

4. [u]Duration[/u] [i]9/10[/i] (Unfortunately, the story is short. But it's a story with a solid narrative structure. The journey is linear, but with the possibility of exploration. A prologue was added, where it indicates the way to play and an introduction to the story: a winter before the separation of the son with the mother. One can start with the prologue to get acquainted with the plot and dynamics of the game. Know the boy perspective and how he understands his home from his point of view. The game offers a different perspective, how children see everyday life.)

[h1]Recommendation: 10/10[/h1]

93385602.review:
I have never written a review for a game before, so this will be my first ever review. I wanna try and keep this simple and spoiler-free, as I do not like to over-complicate things, nor do I like spoiling games as I want/like others to get a full experience. Though, This review may be a little long.

Now, let's get into the actual review; I ADORE the game and story. It's concise, easy to understand, and I am sure many (including myself) can relate to it in some way. Not everyone of course, but I am sure many can. Though, I want to reiterate is that the story is easy to understand and say that it is not a bad thing at all! (Personally) I do not like stories that are all big and bulky, where one must unravel many strings—from an entire ball of yarn (heavy, long lore). Especially, considering someone like me as I am neurodivergent and have trouble with comprehension, most notably with stories and plots. I also love the subtle hints given; whilst they are not too subtle, they are enough to get you thinking and speculating about what is going on. It is a short game (about two hours and a half) but the experience is enjoyable.

I do enjoy the visuals, I do. The colours fit for what part of the story (or level) you're on and help the theme, as colours can make or break a scene's "feel". I feel the child-like viewpoint was nailed right on the head, as children have a real talent with their imagination and how they view things—and it can get a bit wild! Yes, this is a puzzle/horror game, but it's very fun. Most times, I find puzzles to be boring! However, this game did make them feel fun, maybe because of the childlike-lense we are seeing through and that they're fairly simple.

To be honest, I can't particularly think of things I dislike about this game. I guess I don't particularly like "SMALL CHILD IN BIG SCARY WORLD" or something along those lines, but, I don't know if I can fault it for that since I think it was a pretty popular/common theme at the time of the original release in 2015 from what I can remember. Plus, it deals with the subject in question pretty well in my opinion, and it doesn't have the same plot as other games with a similar premise of "SMALL CHILD IN BIG SCARY WORLD". As for the controls? They aren't bad at all, they're alright for the most part. I encountered a minor annoyance maybe once or twice, but that's okay. As long as it is playable, I'll roll with it. I do wish there was a bit more to the game's story, just a bit more! Although, I am happy with the story for the most part; STILL love that it's concise and simple.

Overall, I would recommend this game if you are interested in it, want a short game to play, want something easy to understand if you have troubles similar to mine, or even if you're just bored and want something to do. Sorry for making this so long, but I do appreciate it if you have read this far; it means a lot. With that said, I wish you a wonderful morning/day/noon/evening/night, or whatever time you are reading this review!

(P.S. Make sure to set a keybind for throwing objects! You won't need it until the very last level or so, but I figured this would be a good note to add in here at the end. I set mine to G, but do whatever is the most comfortable for you. By the way, Happy Pride since it's June at the time of making this review!)

92437444.review:
[b]Among the Sleep[/b] es un breve juego de terror en primera persona, donde el mundo es contemplado a través de los ojos de un infante. La historia esconde tras una fachada infantil, una temática adulta como lo es la separación de los padres y sus consecuencias. Sin embargo, hay que estar despierto en el trascurso del juego para ver esos detalles, cosa no tan simple porque a ratos se hace pesado y tedioso [strike](¿Lo entendieron? ¡porque tiene un Oso Teddy!… da bum tsss)[/strike]

El apartado visual esta bien conseguido, no destaca para ser del 2017 aunque abundan los detalles. Los modelos dejan mucho que desear. El sonido esta bien conseguido al igual que las voces. Pero su mayor problema es la jugabilidad donde a veces el personaje no hace lo que le pedimos, sobre todo cuando debe de trepar. Los constantes movimientos de la cámara, en lo particular, me generan [i]motion sickness[/i]. El FOV alto no ayuda en lo absoluto. 

En contenido, la mayor parte del tiempo nos la pasamos buscando objetos para poder avanzar. Los puzzles son escasos y no requieren pensamiento complejo. Eventualmente se vuelve [i]hide & seek[/i] pero en sectores concretos del mapa. 

Es un juego recomendado por su historia. Puede que a mas de uno le llegue la temática. Se aconseja comprar con descuento dada su duración de 2 hs. Se puede jugar con mando o teclado y mouse.

92369074.review:
Unlike most of my friends, I can't get enough of horror games. I loved Dead Space, I played the Forest and trolled the cannibals until they were about as threatening as a Chihuahua. But my god, was this game terrifying.

It's a pretty straightforward horror game - get from point A to point B and back again, with nothing but jump scares in between. But the environment is genuinely surreal, and I love it. There's nothing more terrifying than wandering around, only to turn the corner and see one of the baddies lumbering towards you. Playing as an infant gives you a neat sense of scale that's only built upon by the otherworldly environment.

So, if you're looking for a neat horror game, or just happen to like shitting your pants, Among the Sleep is absolutely worth a playthrough.

92286898.review:
Among the Sleep, del 29 de Mayo del 2014, es un juego de Terror Psicológico, donde interpretamos a un niño de dos años de edad, que está teniendo su fiesta de cumpleaños en casa con su madre, pero la celebración es interrumpida por un visitante que se oculta a nuestra vista. La historia sugiere inmediatamente que es nuestro padre, del que nuestra madre se ha distanciado… Todo comienza cuando despertamos en la madrugada, y comenzamos la búsqueda de nuestra madre, a la que creemos desaparecida, a través de los ambientes creados por nuestra imaginación, junto a la aparición ocasional de monstruosas y espeluznantes criaturas. En todo el viaje se encuentran botellas de alcohol vacías que implícitamente dicen que la madre tiene un problema con la bebida…
Tiene un DLC (a manera de prólogo), donde podemos ver que la madre comenzó con su problema de alcoholismo a causa de los malos tratos que recibía por el padre del jugador. Como el padre del jugador también tiene apariencia de monstruo podemos entender que el bebé también sufría los abusos de éste, cosa que deja a la imaginación del jugador la identidad de la luz de la historia principal o si el juego tuvo un final feliz.

92281179.review:
It's short but sweet; I cautiously recommend it. 

---

I found this game captivating, endearing & enriching. 
Incredibly simple concept but very well executed.
The game's strongest feature; is it's core idea & setting. I felt enriched after finishing it and to this day rather unique. 
Without bringing any technical innovations or novel mechanics, it still manages to gently poke at the borders for what horror is, and by premise and abstracts alone. That in itself is worthy of praise, in my opinion. 

Those who highlight the game's price in conjunction with it's game-play duration (which is on the shorter side) is absolutely right and their arguments are legit. Among the Sleep's tag is fairly steep for the somewhat short game and I guess most players will finish it faster than I did (~3,5 hours). 

One more point worth mentioning is the bugs and jagged edges that normally come with independently developed games. 
[spoiler]This is something that [u]may[/u] have been addressed in the Enhanced Edition, but I am not sure! [/spoiler]

All in all I really liked it. 

Unrelated note: [spoiler]The teddy bear made me disproportionately and extremely uncomfortable[/spoiler]

90266055.review:
Among the Sleep is a short horror adventure in which you see the world through the eyes of a toddler.

The story starts with a toddler and his mother celebrating his birthday.
They are about to eat his birthday cake when they get disturbed by someone knocking on the door.
Things start to get grim and he gets scared when he hears her yelling towards that person.
Eventually she returns with a big gift box with a teddy bear inside, which becomes his new best friend.
At night he wakes up because his bear is getting taken away so he decides to climb out of bed to go find it.
Its dark, the house looks terrifying and his mother is missing now too.
After reuniting with his teddy bear they agree on exploring the sinister home on the hopes of finding her.

Solve puzzles and explore a surreal environment that feels like a dream world,
accompanied with your teddy who guides and comforts you.
You also need to hide from a terrifying monster that haunts you while you try to collect items that represent memories associated with your mother.

The atmosphere is perfectly executed, it looks like a twisted world and it feels very tense.
I have to say that this game is very dear to my heart, it was very emotional and I had a hard time writing a review for it because whenever I think about the game it reminds me of my own past.
The ending makes so much sense and the story is truly heartbreaking. 

In all honesty, I don't think my words can do it any justice and describe how amazing this game truly is.
But for me it's an unforgettable experience, that touched me deeply and left me speechless.
