I just finished this game, and I highly recommend it!
It's scary and spooky, but despite being a horror game, nobody dies in it.
And I just want to say I'm really happy to finally see an [b][i]anti[/i][/b]-woke game!  

[spoiler]
Not that it's okay for any parent to be abusive to a child, but it's refreshing to finally see a game that's [b][i]not[/i][/b] sexist and doesn't repeat the stereotype that it's always the father who is abusive.
[/spoiler]

Unfortunately, it does have technical issues.  I have a pretty high-end machine and GPU, but I was only getting about 10 FPS.  That didn't interfere with game-play but it was noticeable.   

But the prologue was worse, getting about 2 to 3 FPS.  Most of the time, the game was still playable despite the jerkyness, but it was a struggle to make fine movements like when picking up small objects, the hand would just jump around the item without being able to grab it.  

The museum was unplayable.  I was getting about 0.5 FPS -- i.e. 1 frame every 2 to 3 seconds -- despite having a high-end rig. I had to give up because I just couldn't move.  Sad, because I had to watch You Tube videos in order to explore the museum.  I would have liked to explore the museum on my own.  

In summary, the core game was really good and the moderately low FPS wasn't really a problem in playing the game, but they just didn't bother to optimize their DLC levels in any way whatsoever, which is a huge shame.

87372048.review:
What a strange game…
---

It would be very easy to dismiss this as a part walking simulator, part puzzle game; but the truth is it's presenting a narrative perspective that you just don't see very often and while the difficulty balance waffles around and doesn't curve as you'd expect there's still a compelling reason to push through.

You play a toddler (2 years old) searching for their mother in a dream. The (childish) nightmare fuel birthed from fear of loss (dad left) and confusion (mom's an alcoholic) creates a landscape of dark twisted pathways and eerie noises while your only companion is your teddy bear, animated by your imagination.

Fear and comedy are both subjective and the game advertises itself as a horror game. For me I can't claim it was actually scary but it was definitely creepy and while I'm immune to jump scares there are a few that I'm sure might catch some people off guard. A few darkly humorous moments create a stark contrast to the dreary ambiance your child-mind is forcing you to explore.

If you play this frivolously in broad daylight and treat it as just a simple puzzle game, you might not really appreciate it. Play this at night in the dark and truly put yourself in the mind of a toddler who misses their mother and you might actually find yourself exploring your own imagination and not just the one the game gives you. Crawling from one dark corner to another, peeking around furniture and squeezing into the tunnels of your own mind.

Maybe it's not the best game in the world and I don't know if you'll enjoy replaying it for all the collectibles, but it's certainly a memorable experience if you allow it to be.
---

Bottom line: Toddler Simulator ~ Nightmare Edition. Stand up and explore at your own risk, or crawl back under the table and hide.
---

EDIT: After spending more time with the game, in particular the post-game bonus material. There's an additional level: The Prologue which takes place before the main game and gives some more setup.

And for anyone with an interest into game design you will find a treasure trove of discussion hidden in "The Museum" which is a maze-like experience that lets you explore early ideas and discusses the evolution of the game during development. It's an impressive amount of detailed documentation hidden into secret rooms and tunnels of a museum to explore. It's a lot to find as the game began as a student project and continued to change all through a Kickstarter campaign and even after release when the final prologue sequence was added as a free DLC 

"Enhanced edition" refers to the inclusion of the prologue and the museum content.
---

85554899.review:
Among the Sleep is a horror walking simulator with a very unique perspective.

You play as a toddler. Everything feels quite ordinary, you have a loving mother, a magical living teddy bear you got as a present. Things are bright and colorful, you've got plenty of toys, it's all good in the hood. As you fall asleep, you dream some really fucked up shit. There are monsters out to get you, the house is all twisted and crooked. You keep hearing your mother's lullaby through the darkness, guiding you to nice memories from better days. As you progress, you start to realize that things are not that great in the real world.

Game mechanics are quite simple, you can walk quite slowly and wobbly, crawl really fast, pick/drop/throw items, open/close drawers/doors/lights and climb on things. You can run for a short distance and then fall and keep crawling. These combined with being able to view your character model in its pajamas when looking down, or climbing, add a LOT to an already immersive experience. You do feel like you're inside a toddler's body. The game has "parkour" (very limited since character cannot actually jump forward), puzzle solving and stealth sequences.

Level design, graphics, sound design, voice acting (especially the bear) are surprisingly great. AtS does get your heart rate up a bit at times (the atmosphere, the background noises, the dark twisted world, the monsters), and at other times it melts your heart with just how cute it is. Wish more games explored dreams, this totally brought me back to my childhood, playing through Max Payne 1 & 2. While the art style reminded me a lot of Dishonored 1.

I loved every moment of this short (3-4 hours) experience, wishing for a full AA/AAA sequel. Due to it's short length, I'd suggest getting it on sale.

84954352.review:
[h1]KitKat Reviews #9[/h1] 
[h1] Among The Sleep [/h1] 

[h1]Game Plot:[/h1] 
Set in the 1990s, a toddler is having his second birthday celebration with his mother. The celebration is interrupted by a visitor at the front door who is hidden from the player. The conversation is muffled and partly kept from the player. The mothers angry tone frightens the player, whose fear is presented as blurred vision. Quickly, the mother returns with a gift, but she doesn't say who the gift is from. Instead, she carries the player and gift upstairs to the child's room, a place of bright, warm colors and streaming sunlight. Before the present is given to the player, the telephone rings, and the mother leaves the player in the bedroom to play alone. The gift is revealed to be a sentient teddy bear, who climbs out of the box and hides in the chest until the player finds him. The bear introduces himself as Teddy and the player is taught how to play the game with a tutorial within a dark closet filled with dark black coats.  The small adventure inside the closet is ended by the mother finding them. The player then wakes in the night to find Teddy being taken by an unseen force. The crib overturns, and he escapes. The player then leaves the bedroom and rescues Teddy from a washing machine by unplugging it and opening the door. Teddy says that something was not right and that they have to find their mother.
The search leads them to discover a slide that takes them to a small playhouse within a cavern that is presumably under the house, and the door found inside it leads them into a journey through several surreal environments, consisting of an underground playground, a dilapidated mansion that has merged with a marshy forest, and a bizarre series of caverns created by hundreds of closets. Teddy instructs the player to find four memories he shared with the mother that will lead them to her. The memories take the forms of four objects. Throughout the search, the player is pursued by a large, feminine, troll-like monster and a creature with glowing white eyes, who has a coat as a body like the ones in closet earlier.
Together Teddy and the Player are bound to find his mother and return back to the warm and colorful nature that isn’t the journey they are set out to encounter. 

[h1]Personal Opinion About Plot:[/h1] 
The is a very dark plot and without any spoilers, I say that the reality the game will take you would be like the mind of a child in a very dark place. Of course, somethings in this would wont make sense and are a bit outlandish because we are the child. 

[h1]Game Gameplay:[/h1]
Among the Sleep is a first-person exploration game seen from the view of a toddler. The player can move the cursor to walk or crawl around, the latter of which is faster and is required to slide through obstacles blocking the way. Running is also an available option, though the player will fall down if it is done for too long. The player can interact with and push objects, and open doors and windows. Sometimes, the handle to open doors is too tall to reach for the player, in which case the player will have to push and climb chairs for additional height. Other than chairs, the player can climb boxes, tables, and various things to reach otherwise unreachable ledges and heights. Certain objects can also be held as well as thrown away. Others can be stored to the inventory and taken out again for later use.

For most of the game, the player is accompanied by a sentient teddy bear named Teddy. The player can hug Teddy, who emits light that helps the player navigate through darker environments. The light will wear down after a while, but will recharge if left unused. If the player drops Teddy, which always happens whenever they arrive from sliding through pipes to a new level or environment, they will have to pick it up first before advancing again.

Throughout the game, the player is followed by two monsters: a feminine figure that haunts the first three levels, and a trench coat-wearing figure that haunts the final level. The monsters' appearance is indicated by the blurring of the vision, grating sounds, and in the case of the feminine figure, a slow lullaby (Trollmors Vuggesang [sv], "Trollmother's Lullaby") hummed about. There is no way to fend off the monsters; if they appear, the player will have to run away or hide under tables or chairs until they go away. If the player is not quick enough to evade the monsters, a short cinematic will show the monsters taking hold of the player, which results in a game over, followed by a continue screen with a pacifier. Clicking the pacifier restarts the game from the last checkpoint. The player can also get a game over by other means, such as falling into water or chasms.

The game is largely linear and involves going from point A to B, though the expansive environment with multiple obstacles may induce the feeling of being lost. After some time exploring the player's house, the player is taken to a dreamlike location with a gingerbread house-like hut that serves as a sort of hub level. The house contains a circular door that leads to a new level, surrounded by four containers where "memories" obtained from each level are stored. After the player finds a memory and heads to a tube at the end of the level, they will be returned to this hut. Once four memories are stored, the player can insert Teddy's right hand below the circular door to return to the player's house.

In the extra DLC level, instead of exploring dreamlike locations, the player is taken to another house with the objective of finding and thawing five frozen dolls by playing music or turning on the TV. The gameplay is still the same, with the feminine figure haunting the player, but the player is also confronted by a fireplace monster in the underground section that advances and closes in through an aisle.

[h1]Personal Opinion About Gameplay:[/h1]
Overall the mechanics for the game is much like any other horror game, but much like Amnesia’s movable objects and running away tactics. 

[h1]Personal Opinion on Graphics:[/h1] 
Having been a Indie game and being supported by many followers I agree that the graphics given to this game suit the situation they where given. The lighting in the game give it more of an aesthetic vibe more that attention to detail. Of course I could say that it is suppose to be through the eyes of a child which would also make sense. 

[h1]Personal Opinion on Sound Design:[/h1]  
The sound design is a bit, eh. Of course the sounds are repeated in some locations and the music is for a baby but ill give it like a 6/10 for the aesthetic feel of a dark feel to what should be a babies tune. 

[h1]Things needed to be Fixed like Bugs:[/h1]
Having made such a game does have some bugs, but for this game I seem to have done about everything that could have broken a game. The physics are just right and you can rarely get stuck on anything. 

[h1]Final Thoughts:[/h1] 
This is a great indie game that definitely deserves the medals and the comments it received. If you’re looking for a scary horror indie game, this is a must!

84370019.review:
I couldn't be more conflicted than I'm now, trying to decide if Among The Sleep deserves a thumbs up. 

In one hand, it's a unique idea. It's an adventure game where you roam a nightmare world as a toddler, with really creepy atmosphere... and surprisingly strong horror elements. Really strong, I must emphasize that.
In the other hand - braindead puzzles, undeveloped mechanics, few missed opportunities ..... and it ends so quickly, it'll ruin your whole experience. 

I'm fully aware of today's standards and I'm rarely mad at games length. "Walking simulators", story driven adventures, often wrap up in 3 to 5 hours of gameplay and that's understandable. It's important to maintain momentum, not overstay it's s welcome and offer a consistent storyline, when gameplay is somewhat limited. 
[b]Among The Sleep will take you around 1,5 hour to complete and that's really disappointing. [/b]
Still, it's an intense time, with some really chilling moments. 
That's why I'm really torn. I love the idea, but it feels like a little vignette, not a complete experience. There's no incentive to play it again, excluding collectibles, if you're into that sort of things.

I'm giving the thumbs up. Nevertheless, i can't recommend buying it for a full price.
Among The Sleep frequently appears in various game bundles - thats the way to get it. 
[b]Great, little horror game. Wish there was more.[/b]

The game starts off pretty nice, it has a nice atmosphere and is overall a pretty scary game. you play as a two year old child, and the idea of being this tiny kid who crawl most of the game, so that you see the world from a perspective of someone small and insignificant, is quite thrilling.

The first part is nice, and has you wondering in a playground looking for a memory. This part shows, that even though nothing is chasing you, and there's no monster, a game can still be scary just from the atmosphere.

And then comes the second part and throws it out the window
A weird woman figure starts following you around. although the idea is nice, and I'm sure it fits the story somehow (I just couldn't manage to finish the story since I got so bored) the way it's implemented is just bad.

The creature comes out every 10 seconds, and you gotta hide or it takes you and you lose. problem is, every time you hide, you gotta wait like 10 seconds till it stops following you and disappears. so what started off nice, is now a game of me crawling from underneath one bookshelf to the other, and having to wait 10-15 seconds under each of the bookshelves just so I can progress without dying. A part, that should be just the ending of the forest level, took me around 2-3 minutes, in which I was on my phone the whole time waiting for the monster to disappear. I just couldn't continue the game after this.

So yes, the game is interesting, the idea of being in the baby POV is thrilling, but at some point they just decide "hey! let's add a weird monster that you just gotta wait till it's gone! you can't enjoy anymore!"

If you really wanna know the story, I would recommend watching a youtube video. I do think the story can be nice, I just can't recommend anyone to play it if it gets boring halfway.

Game interactions felt awkward and clunky but I do wonder if that was a deliberate design choice since physics and interactions are awkward for toddlers in reality, after all. Despite being only a short game that you can knock out in an afternoon and being frustrated every time you encounter a door or a draw, I do still recommend this game because it's immense depth of imagination and creativity make up for any shortcomings. As someone who has endured a life long mental illness the surreal visuals and settings brought up a range of feelings and memories for myself and made me wonder if the creator of Among the Sleep has similarly endured such blight of the mind. If not they have done an impressive job of tapping into and illustrating such a mind (even if they only intended to portray a nightmare). That kind of creativity is rare and is worth the price of admission in my opinion.

79575816.review:
Before I start on this review I have to say it's been years since I played the game and when I did it wasn't the enhanced Edition, so I can't remember if this new enhanced Edition is better than the original one.

Among the Sleep - Enhanced Edition is a pretty good horror, adventure game, so the story.  On a dark and stormy night as a little baby has lost his mother, his only companion is his bear as they both look for her.

So what’s to like about the game. The atmosphere in the game is pretty good definitely spooky as you wander is strange nightmarish world and jump at every sound.

Graphics are nice and pretty detailed. The levels are very creepy/fun to explore and look at like chapter 3. The game does have some pretty good scares like the introduction to the swamp witch. I like the reason we are given that we can’t fight back against the monsters, Like in other horror games when a person is running away from a monster you're wondering why they don't fight back. In this game it makes sense because we are a baby.

The music in the game was very good and helped with the game’s horror feel. The story very good and that's all I'm saying about it.

I like the prologue chapter/level it really helps with the main game’s story and the toys are very cute. I really like the museum area/chapter/level in the game and finding out how the game was made and the stuff that was cut, honestly the stuff that was cut could be made into a whole other game.

So what’s to dislike about the game. Well game is on the short side you can beat it in three hours if you're planning on not going after the achievements. There are some bugs, but nothing game braking. Lastly the game’s price is a bit too high for such a short game.

So Among the Sleep - Enhanced Edition is a pretty good horror, adventure game. With a pretty good atmosphere, creepy/fun levels and a very good story. 

So if you're looking for a good spooky horror game to play I recommend this game, but I think buying it when it's on sale will save you some money.

79436395.review:
What's scarier than being a little kid among monsters? I always thought that stealth-based survival horror was scarier than the shoot-'em-up horror variety. No offense to the Doom and Resident Evil series, which I love, but when you're a veritable superhero armed to the teeth, it's hard to really get scared. 

The scare factor for Among the Sleep isn't that high, but when the scares come, they feel genuine. That's partly because you're a toddler doddering around trying your best not to knock things over to avoid drawing unwanted attention, which keeps you on pins and needles. But it's also because the scares are intertwined with the storyline. And even though I saw the ending coming, it still left a mark. 

If you like stealth-based survival horror (honestly, it's more of a thriller than horror) with a creative premise and a satisfying narrative arc, Among the Sleep might be for you.

My one gripe is that the stealth-based mechanics toward the end got annoying after a few consecutive deaths, but that's more about stealth dynamics in general.

79349570.review:
Creepy visuals and a neat atmosphere! I love the idea of a horror from the perspective of a 2 year old. Pity that they couldn't be bothered to make a game for it. The experience is very linear, puzzles are of the variety that just tells you the solution immediately, or at most requires you to look around to see the path to walk down. Playing the game gave me this distinct feeling that at one time there was a game here, but that someone with authority came in and forced them to strip everything out. As it is, the game feels like a joke told by Mac from It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia, "Do you get? Do you see the answer? Here, let me explain it to you..."

It's also glitchy.  If you save and quit items from your inventory can be deleted. This permanently bricks your save. The final item in my inventory (the fourth and final memory) got deleted from my save, so when I got to the end of the game and needed to use it I was just stuck in the playhouse. So that was a big let down.

Honestly, just looking at the screenshots allows you to experience 95% of the game's content. Steer clear of this mess.

79321518.review:
This game is basically just a very short horror walking simulator that's highly overrated due to streamers playing it. If you've never played a horror game, you'll probably enjoy it, as was the case with my friends who played it, but if you've played horror games before, you'll probably think it's a waste of time and money.

I feel like this game got a lot of media coverage from streamers because there is a certain novelty to playing a game where you play a child and everything is bigger and scarier, but objectively the game isn't really that great: it's short for the price, the graphics and controls are janky, the enemies pose little to no threat and the plot feigns depth.

All in all, the game has an interesting premise, i.e., playing as a child and seeing through their eyes, but poor execution.

If you want to ease into the horror genre, I would recommend starting with this game, but if you've ever played any game that was remotely scary, you'll find this game wanting.

By the way, the controller support isn't very good despite the game claiming to have full controller support; I initially wanted to play this game on my xbox controller, but it doesn't work automatically  like most other games and seemed like too much of a hassle to set up.

78251574.review:
Among The Sleep es un videojuego de terror/sigilo con puzzles que recuerda mucho a juegos como Amnesia: The Dark Descent o Slender: The Arrival el cual trata sobre un bebe de 2 años que en su cumpleaños conoce a su pequeño amigo, un oso de peluche llamado Teddy el cual por la noche es arrastrado por una entidad desconocida y al rescatarlo ambos emprenden la busqueda de su madre mientras se adentran a mundos de pesadilla y ensueño.
Procedemos con los "pros" y "contras" que contienen spoilers no tan graves pero si pueden arruinar la revelacion final asi que cuidado.

+Una historia curiosa [spoiler] con un topico muy real y lamentablemente algo comun entre niños/niñas con padres en conflicto o con problemas de adiccion.  [/spoiler]
+Mecanicas en la jugabilidad que me llamaron mucho la atencion, pues al ser un bebe tu velocidad de caminata es lenta, al correr te puedes tropezar, gatear es mas rapido, no puedes interactuar con objetos si tienes las manos ocupadas o estan fuera de tu alcance, etc. Ademas lo de taparse los ojos al dar pausa me gusto mucho e incluso se utiliza en el juego como mecanica (solo una vez, pero aun asi me gusto mucho ese detalle que pudo usarse mas creo).
+Las voces estan bien logradas apesar de solo ser las de la Madre y Teddy pero son agradables de oir.
+El soundtrack cumple apropiadamente con lo que se quiere transmitir junto al entorno aunque la musica de distorsion en las persecuciones puede molestar un poco.
+La mecanica de las botellas que si se rompen hacen enojar al monstruo fue curioso e interesante.

-Potencial desaprovechado pues se siente que se pudo hacer mas con la historia.
-Una duracion extremadamente corta (maximo 3 horas junto al Prologo)
-No tiene mucho "terror" como tal ya que los encuentros con los monstruos son casi como un script y que encima solo te los toparas unas 3 veces contadas y no estoy bromeando.
-La IA de los enemigos es muuuuy simple, con eso me referia a que parecian scripts pues solo se reducen a dar vueltas por el escenario y si los ves simplemente correran hacia ti por lo que si no los ves en absoluto o te pones debajo de una mesa te ignoraran de inmediato. Hubiese estado mejor que se aprovecharan cosas como el esconderse en armarios o debajo de las camas.
-Los graficos estan aceptables pero se nota mucho cuando chocas con objetos o con el mismo Teddy que se "hunden" entre si viendose muy raro.
-Literalmente no veo nada, hay muy poca iluminacion si es que se pone lo que el juego te recomendaria y si le subes obviamente anulas la "tension" aparte de que se ve medio feo. El uso de Teddy es casi inutil pues me parece que oscurece mas todo en vez de ayudarme a ver adjunto a que su radio de iluminacion es muy patetico asi que conviene mas tenerlo en la espalda asi tienes mas campo de vision junto a que puedes interactuar con el entorno.

6/10
Cortito con nula rejugabilidad, algunos errores con colisiones u objetos que se hunden entre si, no mucho "terror" como tal y algo de potencial desaprovechado. Aun asi es un producto disfrutable y entrañable si lo consigues en alguna oferta generosa.

Among the Sleep is a great concept for a horror game. Because I am a wimpy baby when it comes to these things, I fit right in playing as a toddler gripping his teddy bear for comfort.

77003267.review:
[h1]First impression [/h1]
[b]When I started playing I was expecting something like a better version of the game [i]‘Five nights at Freddy’s’[/i], but with a storyline. This turned out not to be the case. Instead, like the summary suggests,  you play as a baby that gets trapped in a ‘nightmare world’ where you'll try to find your mom while trying to survive.[/b]

[h1]Pros[/h1]
- Design looks is okay
- I think ‘the nightmare’ is a good addition to this game (up till that point I got bored, but after ‘the nightmare’ appears in the game, it gets a lot more intense/horror like).
- If you die it’s not that big of a deal, you won’t lose much progress

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- I didn’t like the controllers (also no point using ‘shift’ for running, the toddler keeps falling anyways and tends to get stuck on higher doors while attempting to escape ‘the nightmare’)
- Everything is too dark to actually explore in detail. The maps are built to focus on just the main-story.
- Multiple errors and crashes. At some point my entire pc crashed, though I don’t want to go as far to claim beyond any disputable doubt that it was just because of this game. The crashing part of my pc might have been a big coincidence, but other than that I had to restart the game a couple of times and stuff like this happened occasionally:

https://imgur.com/a/0wPDzCx

- My final point is a moral question. Do you, as developers and/or publisher, think it’s ‘fair’ to simply change the $ sign for an € sign as price for this game for EU-citizens? Though the prices that are suggested in the trailer are not entirely correct (the game currently costs €16,99 on Steam in the Netherlands, without discount), I still can’t help but wondering if we are still getting screwed because of stuff like this:

https://imgur.com/a/J7O9829

[h1]Overall[/h1]
[b]Interesting game, not what I was expecting, but it does have some critical bugs and control issues. Because of this I would not recommend this game.[/b]

76531857.review:
Let's begin by saying that i recommend this only if you find it on sale. Although the game itself is very well made, it isn't worth the price. I finished it in less than 3 hours, taking my sweet time exploring the environment. One thing to note is that the devs clearly took a lot of inspiration from Amnesia, all the way down to the screen shake animation when the monster is nearby.

The Good:
Krillbite absolutely nails the world building and mechanics, making everything huge and out of reach. Even the most basic actions like walking over a small step requires you to press a button and climb it.
Hugging the teddy bear gives off a faint light to help you navigate a little better, but prevents you from performing any other action (except walking of course). Moreover, by making crawling faster than walking, you are required to choose whether to prioritise speed or visibility.
Overall, without going into too much detail, the devs did a great job making the player feel powerless.

The Bad:
This game is really just a story you are carried through. The world is extremely linear and there is no real challenge.
On the other hand, the controls are quite frustrating a times. Climbing over objects isn't always smooth, opening doors (which is by far he most common action) could have been made easier to perform.

In conclusion, a very interesting idea that I wish would have been developed a little further. This is, however, a great title to introduce a non-gamer to the survival horror genre.

The default setting, which looked good at the beginning, didn't allow me to see some dark areas where I was supposed to find some key items for the puzzles. When I realized that I was already halfway to the end and increasing the brightness allowed me to see not just those items, but also how bad and linear the level design was. I agree that the concept is interesting on the paper, but considering we're talking about a kid watching the world with his own eyes and imagination it could have been done much better. Tutorial makes a good job introducing the story and the clunky controls, but after a while the game becomes just like any other bad horror walking sim. Hide from the monster, find items, solve the puzzle. Easy. Needless to say, it's not scary at all. Most of the time monster spawns are scripted. You hide, he disappears, you're free to go. The story itself is really basic, while the ending is dull, predictable and clearly rushed. Overall the whole experience was boring.

Playing this right after Outlast was probably not the best idea. Least to say Among the Sleep is not a very scary horror game. I played the alpha / demo years ago when the indie team just started and now after having the game in my Steam account since years (I got it in a bundle) I thought I'd give it a try.

What can I say, the idea was always good, but it is a very short atmospheric spooky game. Horror, not really. It has a few jump scares, and there are a few ways to generate a game over, but it feels very "soft" after playing stuff like Outlast etc.

Taking in the amount of time and hard work of the dev team, watching at the result, I'd say it's worth a try if you want a very atmospheric "horror game". It's not that scary at all, so maybe give it a try if you are not sure if those games are for you. Kudos for making a horror game that can live without gore, sex and all that psycho stuff and actually tells a mindful story.

Still it is rather unfitting for those of you that are eagerly waiting to piss in their pants.

After my first playthrough I thought it was a nice game with a great and bold story you don't find very often in gaming (the ending is amazing). That alone justifies the purchase. The reveal adds a lot of replay value to catch all the hints included early in the game, but still I kind of felt that the overall lenght of the game was short, some animations were a bit rough/old and the mechanics and puzzles were rather simple and not that great. So my first impression was good, but not that good.

Then I played the prologue and went to the museum, where you get to see all the behind the scenes, developers comments, thoughts, initial art concepts and discarded material, among other content. Silly as it sounds, this simple feauture adds A LOT of depth and value and takes the game a step further. After a brief visit to each area of the museum you can get a very good idea of the development process and understand why the game is the way it is and why most if not all of the decisions made were the right ones. The narration of the story they wanted to tell is so impeccably well executed that I really don't mind if the animations are not superb or the puzzles are simple.

A truly beautiful short game.

72923168.review:
[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*] Innovative story and scope of a game (A two year old!)
[*] Nice use of childhood fears into gameplay features
[*] Dark environments and ambient sound makes for a scary game
[*] Realistic movement for a two year old
[*] Simple puzzles, the likes of what a two year old could solve
[*] Interesting story that touches rarely spoken issues
[*] Easy achievements
[*] Looks pretty good for such dark game
[*] Art style is on point with the objective
[*] Has a museum with lots of artwork, ingame models and extras
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*] I had textures and models pop in and out of existence
[*] I had the terrain completely disappear from me once
[*] I had a bug with a sound being played indefinitely
[*] Game crashed on exiting it
[*] Auto saves that don't really save your progress, nice
[*] Game is surprisingly graphics intensive...
[*] Extremely short play time, 4 hours while doing everything
[*] Expensive for the play time you'll get out of it
[*] Extremely easy, I finished the game without dying once!!
[*] I only saw one of the 4 enemies, this is how easy it is!
[*] Apparently, Teddy was always your friend from the beginning
[*] Teddy's introduction makes it look like the obvious enemy
[*] Story's cohesion to gameplay and maps is non-existent
[*] Many game elements seem totally random
[*] Walking simulator
[/list]

[b]Overall:[/b]
Expensive and short, high quality but low enjoyment, original but dull. It's a half-good game that unfortunately fails on the most important parts, fun and engagement. I was gifted this game, but if I had bought it, I would consider that I had made a serious mistake. It's not worth it. Good, but not good enough. I consider 2$ the most you should pay for this experience, and still, not sure it's worth playing at all.

[b]Veredict:[/b] 4/10 - There are better ways to spend your cash

We should have good reviews in the store page, not jokes. Thank you![/b]

72057889.review:
It's a really good game. It does feel a little dated, with animations and models feeling a little off. But looking past that, everything still manages to look great. I really recommend this game. It's not a very long game, maybe 2 to 6 hours at most, and it's more of a game that you play through to experience the setting and the story, than it is for the gameplay. Like others are saying, it's pretty much a walking simulator. So if any of that bothers you, get the game on sale. 

Playing as a 2 year old child, the game is more about going through a set of linear levels, solving small puzzles and figuring out how to progress. While there are only 6 levels, each level is very distinct from the others, and none of them feel too short. 

There are scary moments, but the game seems more about creating a scary atmosphere. It does certainly feel more scary as you are a slow and defenseless child. I was constantly making note of any small closets and crawlspaces I found in case I had to quickly hide from anything that tried to chase me later. There are some jump scares, but I think they are done fairly well here. None of them are really out right in your face, and you never lose control [spoiler]except when you are caught by one of the monsters(?)[/spoiler], so it's easy to turn your face or hide when you feel like something is about to happen. This really helps with the immersion as it's what you would expect most children to do when they see something scary: look away. 

As for the story, it's a simple story. You are a 2 year old child wandering through a house at night trying to find your mother. You aren't entirely alone, however, as you carry around a talking teddy bear that can glow when you bring it out. He will comment on various things, and sometimes move on his own and help progress the game forward. There are also these [spoiler]shadowy monsters[/spoiler] that occasionally appear, sometimes chasing you. As you go through the game, you collect a "memory" at the end of each level, which is just an item that reminds you of your mother. And the levels are very different from eachother, such as a [spoiler]house, playground, and even a forest[/spoiler]. Playing through the game, with the monsters, the memories, the strange locations, I started to wonder anything that was happening was even real. But when you combine all that with the voices that talk during the memories and the strange drawings you might find, the story becomes something much deeper that might hit close to home for some people. 

Well, let's get to the flaws. They were pretty much all fixable for me, but I'm going to mention them anyways. 

1. The game is a bit linear. There are some levels that are completely linear and some that aren't at all, but I still think it works just fine. I put this as a flaw for those who don't want a linear game. There's not really any backtracking and you can't go back to previous levels unless you select them from the main menu. 

2. The lighting. It's fine and everything looks great, but some places seem way to dark for how dark they expect you to have the game set at. The worst level was level 2, which requires you to search a large area ( [spoiler]a playground in a forest?[/spoiler] ) for these small [spoiler] owl statues [/spoiler] and if you are going for 100%, the collectibles. But it's easy to get lost in all the [spoiler] foliage [/spoiler] looking for these things, as you don't get any hint about where they are, and at the proper light level, it's nearly impossible to see. This may have only affected me. Maybe the room I was playing in wasn't dark enough, but it is easily fixable by just raising the brightness a little. 

3. Jittery movement that is fixable. The game doesn't start out in a 16:9 aspect ratio. But after setting it to that, moving in the game felt really jittery. Its extremely subtle, but it made me nauseous and I almost decided not to play it. But I discovered the problem become almost non-existent by adjusting the FOV. I think I had to lower the FOV by 10.

On an extra positive note, I actually really enjoyed the museum in this game. Probably the only game where I did enjoy the museum. It isn't just a collection of things to look at, but also a ton of concept art and design, with commentary and text to read from the developers. It really gives a lot of insight into what they were going for and trying to achieve.

71203210.review:
[h1] Why try to innovate the horror genre, when this game can't even handle the basics? [/h1]

Ok, these positive game reviews really bog me out, because not only is this game mediocre at best, but it is unfinished as well.

- The story is basic, at par with with mediocre/bad horror games
- The environment/ambient doesn't push you in. I don't even demand this game to be scary, but nothing drove me into this world
- Abrupt ending, where nothing is explained, demonstrating its unfinished state
- Art style and graphics are mediocre
- I saw other reviews state something that is not true at all - that this game is bugless. Actually, it has a lot of bugs!
--- In level 1, if you go against the edge of a door, surprise, surprise, you can see through walls!
--- In level 4, i found that if you crawl against dossiers you move hyperfast. 
--- In level 4, found a wall that let me through to fall out of the map, to my death. Interesting enough, when you fall of the map, you go through the death menu to 2 times
- All levels have invisble walls
- AI is non existent and feels scripted. It isn't neither scary or presents a challenge and also spawns and unspawns in front of you...ffs...
- It just wasn't fun to play...and after all, shouldn't this be the sole reason for someone to play a videogame?
- 2 hours of gameplay for a game that costs 17€? Really? I would be fine if this cost 5€, but this game is purely and simply overpriced.

Overall, this game was a disappointment. Just because it tries to bring something new to the horror genre, it doesn't mean it should be free of any criticism.

[b] Overall: 3/10 [/b]

___________________________

Play this game if:
- You want to get moved emotionally
- You want to experience the the world and it's traumas through the eyes of a toddler
- You want to get stunned by beautiful and playful surroundings, at the same time as getting scared to shits

Do Not play this game if:
- You are no fan of walking simulators
- You are looking for hardcore horror


Verdict: 9/10

70411261.review:
Yeah I'm sorry I can't recommend this. One of the few positives I can give is that the story is okay and the other is that the levels are actually very well designed, you won't get irritated by the level design here as you do in many other cheap horror games on steam.

Unfortunately the story is doled out way too seldomly (a bit at the start and then just close to the end). Because of that the levels don't have any purpose, you're just playing to play. The levels are okay and some are even fun. But since there's no context for the level itself it doesn't hold your attention. You get one "memory" after each level, which is a line of dialogue and that's it. That's the extent of story progression you get until right at the end.

The game is very cute and very competent compared gameplaywise compared to other horror games, so I would like to recommend it. But it's just not scary. I played it with my two nieces, 14 and 17 years old, and the youngest one got scared once. Once through the whole game.

So you have a horror game where the story doesn't string you along and the scares don't string you along. The only thing left is gameplay and some actually good gameplay. I never felt lost except when it was intentional, and even then it wasn't to the point of frustration. I really have no complaints about the levels, just that there was no context for playing them.

I would only recommend this to people who like levels for levels. Maybe if you treat is as a platformer-lite or something. They are cute and they have some puzzles (even though it's mostly just collecting puzzles). But don't expect a horror game.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review [/h1]

Among the Sleep is a game developed and published by Krillbite Studio

The game offers some nice graphics, although some ugly glitches here and there, it is pleasant all the same

Among the Sleep overall, however, is a fun game to play albeit short, and it does get boring if being played for a long time, but is a good-ish horror adventure game to play in short bursts!

68660426.review: I really enjoyed this game. There was a nice blend of atmosphere, suspense, and overall creepiness. It was refreshing playing as a toddler, and seeing the issues from that small perspective, especially when it comes to the mother. 68486184.review:
Among the sleep did something few other games have done for me in the past.
When I first launched the game I had no real idea of what I was getting myself into, only knowing the fact that I was playing as a toddler searching for my mother. Through each "Chapter" you need to collect memory items, which in turn brings you closer to finding your mother. There are collectables in the form of drawings scattered all over the place, at first it just appeared as mere drawings to me and with the achievement hog I am, I had to find all of them. But with each drawing I found I noticed something "Small".

The drawings were also telling me a story, giving me more insight to my current predicament. Which in my opinion is a genius way of writing a story, see games lose touch with collectables having it as a mere past time filling out a game with useless junk to make the game appear much longer than it actually is. Among the sleep took a unique take on this offering more "story" with each drawing.

Now you are probably wondering, is the game scary? Yes and no. From a toddlers perspective it is quite terrifying, but I never felt any "real" danger from the game. My first hour playing I encountered a shadow or two that spooked me, but didn't present any real threat. So it wasn't until I completely let my guard down, that I got a fright. There was this level with a well lady (trying not to spoil too much here) and I never saw her, going about my merry way collecting the items to further progress. There was this lock on a white fence gate that I needed to get to, so I moved an object to get closer and insert the key, right at that moment this well lady spooked the crap out of me by grabbing me off the chair. 

The story is well told and the game looks good, for me it was well worth the play. Keep in mind that it takes roughly about 3 hours to complete the entire game, so it's up to you to decide whether the price tag is worth it or not.

65644939.review:
[i]Among the Sleep (Enhanced Edition)[/i] is a short walking simulator played from the perspective of a 2-year-old. It only includes ultra-light puzzling elements and nearly no story at all. Graphics and animations are nothing to write home about, especially for an enhanced edition that supposedly includes 'improved visuals'. More importantly, some bugs remain in this enhanced edition, most notably clipping issues which force you to restart the chapter because you're hopelessly stuck.

All things considered, [i]Among the Sleep[/i] isn't a bad walking simulator, but if you're not a megafan of the genre or if you have plenty of good walking sims in your backlog, you're good and can safely skip this one. This conlusion, coupled with the fact that the regular price for this game is just plain ridiculous for such a short experience, made me decide to not recommend [i]Among the Sleep[/i].


[h1]Story[/h1]

Since I want to avoid spoilers, I can't talk about the story, as the entire story can be perfectly written out in one short sentence.

Suffice it to say the developers have created a world for you to explore, which they believe may represent how a 2-year-old would interpret certain actions by his parents that don't make any sense to a toddler. 


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Gameplaywise, [i]Among the Sleep[/i] is a run-of-the-mill walking simulator, although maybe I should say [i]crawling[/i] simulator because the toddler's walking speed is very slow, whereas his crawling speed is an acceptable speed to not get annoyed by slow movement speed, which some short walking simulators use as a way to artificially increase playtime.

You have to find your way through the game, which is divided into four chapters. Each chapter has a slightly different type of setting, with everyday objects sometimes looking eerie from the perspective of a 2-year-old. 

The puzzling aspect of the game is limited to finding your way in the (mostly dark) game world or finding a keylike object needed to continue. So I don't have a clue what the promise of 'enhanced puzzles' in the developers' description of the enhanced edition means.

Often, you're required to interact with objects by clicking and dragging, for example to open doors or move a chair to a cupboard so you can climb the chair and then climb onto the cupboard. The game handles these interactions in a very clunky way and therefore they often get frustrating to perform. Sometimes I saw an object I thought I should climb onto but my gurgling avatar refused. After looking around for a while and finding no alternatives, I went back to the same object and found out I [b]was[/b] supposed to climb it, but it only works when I face the object from a certain angle.

In the second half of the game, you'll sometimes encounter a ghost/wraith/spectre that you need to avoid or it's game over. This is a mechanic that a lot of walking simulators use to add a horror element to the game. While I've come to hate games that only revolve around avoiding a 'game over monster', its sporadic use in the case of [i]Among the Sleep[/i] didn't bother me at all. The only time the creep actually caught me was when I got stuck due to a clipping issue. I got stuck several times while playing [i]Among the Sleep[/i], even when I was two minutes in, and the only way to solve that situation is by reloading, which means restarting the chapter or a large part of it.

I'm glad [i]Among the Sleep[/i] allows the player to rebind the controls. You can also adjust mouse look speed, which definitely is a welcome option because I found the standard mouse look speed ridiculously fast, something which a lot of players have written in reviews and on the forums. I'm glad I didn't need to fiddle around with my mouse's dpi settings, which would have discouraged me and maybe I wouldn't have bothered to play the game at all.


[h1]Graphics and sound[/h1]

Since the developers boast that the enhanced edition of their game has 'improved graphics', I would not have wanted to play the previous edition of [i]Among the Sleep[/i]. I definitely don't consider wonderous graphics one of the main requirements to enjoy a game, but [i]Among the Sleep[/i]'s graphics are basic and often even crude. Animations aren't very smooth either. 

The soundtrack is a much better aspect of [i]Among the Sleep[/i]. I don't remember hearing any music, so either it was forgettable or there wasn't any, but the constant eerie ambient sounds and creepy sound effects are great and they add a lot of atmosphere to an otherwise mediocre experience, which is probably the main reason why this game doesn't completely feel like it deserves a 'not worth playing' tag. Though I do understand that some people have an issue with the game [b]constantly[/b] playing eerie ambient sounds, even when there is no danger at all.


[h1]On Steam's extra features[/h1]

[i]Among the Sleep[/i] has 6 Steam Trading Cards. You'll get 3 while running the game.

For me, the Steam Achievements turned out to be a necessary addition to [i]Among the Sleep[/i]. Six of them require you to find a collection of drawings that are scattered throughout each chapter. This meant I had some sort of goal the whole time besides simply crawling and climbing towards the finish line. I don't think I would have finished this game without its Steam Achievements, which is something I don't think I've ever felt before. I'll also add here that this game has zero replayability as far as I'm concerned, especially after having unlocked all of the achievements.

Besides the collectibles, there are three achievements that require you to perform some completely optional tasks in the game and one final achievement is awarded for completing the game, bringing the total to 10 achievements.

65518937.review:
I didn't think much of this game at first. But, I'd missed the window to return it so decided to give it another go. Early levels are a little creepy, but relatively easy. More atmosphere than actual threat. Looking around the environment feels a little disorientating. Moving the mouse slightly produces quite a quick 'swing' in vision which feels headache-inducing until you get the hang of much smaller, slower movements.  

The game eventually takes a turn, and you're in a weird universe trying to complete a series of challenges. Still, the hardest part is just peering through the darkness trying to make out shapes. True fear kicks in once you realise that, no, you weren't imagining that movement. And, yes, babies can die in this game. I literally had to close my eyes at one point. A teddy bear just wasn't going to cut it... and, I wanted my mummy!

In what was rapidly turning out to be the worst birthday ever, I'd been stalked around a library, and was hiding under a bookcase shaking like a leaf. After a death and two near misses, I closed the game with shaking hands.

Five stars.

64467133.review:
It seems that the game is reviewed as a very positive and highly recommended product.

To be honest, it seems that the developers offered a lot of love to the game, and they tried to be very ambitious with the original scope and direction of the game, but they couldn't deliver it on the technical front (as they solely admit in the Game museum) and maybe some internal issues occured.

I found the original idea and scope of the game a higher and more engrossing product than what Among the Sleep is now. Even if the developers are proud of the current game it seems that they also would have liked the game to keep it's original premise and promises.

Unfortunately, for me, the current iteration, while is a serviceable 3 hour game, or an alternative to watching a movie, it is not a product I enjoyed.
It is a game that it's memory from your brain will fade in the nether, but it has a really nice buildup which fails to deliver on what I expected to be and in what it also tries to achieve.

There are some interesting moments in the game but overall I find it week and forgetable. I would have liked it to reccommend it to at least the young audience, but I honestly believe they won't get it.


It is a kid's scary game in a kid's world but which adresses serious issues like misshandling of babies, marital problems and how can 2 people who don't love eachother inflict traumas on the baby.

AGAIN, this is not a bad game, it's a game I just don't recommend.


Reading again what I wrote, it seems the review doesn't explain what else is wrong about the game, than the plot.
Again, while being serviceable, the game just isn't that special gameplay wise, there is nothing really unique, and it sometimes posseses issues with moving and crawling in the environment. Having to change stance to move over a small objective, interactive a bit too much with the traps, even if you don't touch them, annoying circular movements, that seem to not react well to the mouse and keyboard setup, but better to the control ones. The drawers and objects seem to not be thinked to be operated by a baby, altough door handles do.
Some cases of bad illumination, textures and environments not loading, or clipping in trough scenes.
Over use of scary music, when there is no danger, a bit of mouse sensivity issues, and slight motion blur even when turned off.
Exageration of camera daze and shake when looking at an enemy.
Poor diversity of objectives. Most of the game is either collect an object and place it into a specific spot, then go to another chamber and collect another, and when you do 3 you can advance.

It trully feel that a demo, that got transformed into a full game after someone had 180 plot change. I think they tried to do something to not fail the kickstarter fans, that pledged on the original game, and tried to offer a workable product.
Let's not forget that Among The Sleep was in Early Access for quite some time, and it really looked as abandoned at times.



Some setup spoilers.
[spoiler]A huge part of the game is in the baby imagination, the universe in which you travel are memories pleasant, and unpleasant from their life.
The baby tries to find solace by searching for the mother. In his search he deforms the world and also experiences some of the fears we all had as young ones, imagining enemies and assigning people to monsters.[/spoiler]


Serious spoilers underneath.
[spoiler]The most interesting and unique thing in the game, is that not the father is at fault, and the father is actively searching for the son to save him, and the mother is the real monster the kid should run away. This happens when the mother gets mad at the baby and starts drinking.
In the end, while the baby tries to build and reinforce the positive memories of his life, it becomes more and more clear that the mother, while surely loves the baby, cannot keep him safe and happy, thus the baby is given to the father and child services.
 [/spoiler]

62029066.review:
This game starts out extremely strong! It gives you a whole new perspective, one that I at least had never experienced before, that of a toddler... ok maybe technically I have but whatever. 
It does that great thing where the game encourages the players mind to create much of the danger, and the first level had me filled with absolute dread! The sound design is excellent and a constant source of creepy ambiance. 
The games style of "exaggerated realism" complements the story perfectly and everything looks beautiful throughout.

58860738.review:
Short but fun. Gameplay wanders between survival horror (running from monsters that are there) to walking simulator (plus running from monsters that aren't there, it was just the music getting spooky for a sec).  Or perhaps crawling simulator - crawling is faster and steadier than walking, a brilliant touch that brings you into the two-year-old main character's point of view. 

The story is simple, but the game tells it well.  The atmosphere and set design are great.  The music is definitely trying to scare you, but it works with the gameplay.  Some of the middle feels a little more consciously like a video game, going through linear levels to get items to get to the next level.  The monsters are scarier when they can't get you.  Once you're used to the scare for getting caught it's more frustrating than frightening.  But the end of the game is very well executed and redeems the middle, and the whole game only takes about four hours.  (It might take you less; that included pause time and a lot of getting lost.)

The game was a little glitchy, but not too bad: I had to reset from checkpoint once because I got stuck behind some scenery and once because the screen for resetting after you've fallen/been caught/otherwise failed wasn't letting me click to reset. The checkpoints are pretty generous, so neither of these was a big issue.  The little kid hands below you when you look down mostly work well for immersion, but it's a little odd to see them still held by your sides while you move an object (hey, maybe you're a telekinetic toddler.)  None of these problems really got in the way of the game.

55592292.review:
This is one of those games where I see how much other people enjoyed it and I just don't get it. I'm sorry, but the game sucks, it really does. It especially sucks considering it's a 3 hour game for $17. I know all the fans are like "3 hours for $17 is still good as long as you're getting a good experience". Maybe I could agree with that, if it even gave me a good experience.

This is more like an atmospheric walking simulator than anything even closely resembling an appropriate horror game. Honestly, there are only two points in the game where there is even any threat of all of actually being attacked, and it's very brief. Even then, as long as you're not standing directly out in the open or either refuse to move or even decide to walk towards the monsters, there is no chance at all that you're going to be caught. Most of the time this game creates the illusion that there is danger, but once you realize that's not true in the slightest you're free to run through all the levels freely. The one and only time I was ever scared in this game was when I jumped at my own shadow. I actually ran TOWARDS an enemy at one point just to see if it could even kill me!

At the end you get to visit the museum and see the original concepts of the game... which strangely sounds way better than the actual game is. Most of the comments is just what they wanted to do and decided to cut out for some reason. At the end there are unskippable credits that run for about 10 minutes long (you can press S to speed it up, the game doesn't tell you that though) and all I could think the whole way through it was how bad I feel that so many people backed this game for it to end up so badly and no where near the original concept of the game. This game has more backers than most other actually good indie games I've played, and it's one of the few games I've given such a bad review to.

1/5

Honestly, look through my reviews and you'll see I think there is maybe one other game I've given such a bad review for and that's it. This game is seriously boring and tedious the entire time, extremely short for it's price, and overall just plainly sucks.

54802278.review:
Overall Rating: 3/10

Among the Sleep is basically a visual novel without much of a story. Tagged as "horror" and "adventure" but I would not call it either. I had high hopes for this, and the price tag is pretty high for what I eventually played through.
You play as a toddler, trying to find his mother. Along the way the story isn't developed at all until the end and the very underwhelming "twist" is revealed.

Though the concept of a toddler's view of the world where things can transform and monsters can be seen anywhere is interesting, this game did not do it justice. The game tried a couple jump scares, and creating an atmosphere of tension and fear, but it just didn't work. I did not get scared once, and I am really a wimp. There were no puzzles, just crawling and climbing through a lackluster world with a lackluster story to reach an inevitable and somewhat predictable end. Overall I spent 3-3.5 hours playing this game to get 100% (including the DLC). There is no replayability. I give this game a solid "Do Not Recommend, even if it's free."

Graphics: 4/10
Story: 1/10
Mechanics/Gameplay: 3/10
Price: Much too high

54791855.review:
I really liked how this game was simultaneously adorable & scary at the same time. Especially helpful being played from the perspective of a toddler. I really liked the subtle attention to detail, things like the baby's breathing, waddling, falling over if you run too long & the size/scale of the environments compared to the child which effects the gameplay. It was funny having to move objects like chairs or stools around to open doors. Or opening drawers & arranging them like stairs to climb up onto something. There are puzzles which aren't extremely difficult but this fits the player character a lot (I wouldn't expect a toddler to be able to solve extremely difficult puzzles). The gameplay is kind of rudimentary but given the nature of the game I felt that was perfectly fine & expected. 

It was scary enough for me, but I don't really play many walking sim horror games mainly because I'm not a fan of the whole "here's a scary monster/demon thing that you can't attack and your only option is to either run & hide or die" those generally irritate me. I enjoy more the likes of FEAR or The Suffering. I felt Among the Sleep could have done a bit more, however I was satisfied since I felt pretty much on edge nearly everywhere in the game. It did exactly what I wanted it to do; it brought me back to those times when I was a little child trying to get from my room to the bathroom in a dark scary house that felt like it was the size of the world. Hiding & peaking around corners, keeping my back to the wall all those kinds of silly things.

I liked the visuals, it wasn't too dark but you could adjust that if you wanted, and the art style looked really good. I loved being able to see the kids hands & feet and the way some of the animations worked, it was really amusing. The atmosphere conveyed by the visuals was pretty on point. The scary areas were dark & had shadows that could play mind tricks. Then the bright areas made you feel calm & settled with all the colourful stuff around.

The audio was good, definitely a big part of what kept me on edge. There's always some sort of ambience and it was scary, creaking trees, doors swinging back & forth, floor boards creaking etc... they all came together really well & complimented the suspenseful music. My biggest issue with audio though; there's an option to enabled 5.1 surround sound but doing so seems to make the audio sound significantly worse & assuming my ears weren't playing tricks, all the audio felt like it was coming through 1 speaker.

The game is a bit short, though I only paid about $4US for it, so I'm pretty satisfied with value. Overall I'd definitely recommend this game if you're looking for a balance between horror & nostalgia. I think Krillbite Studio did really great with this and I'd actually love to see a few sequels that gradually get more and more horrific as they go on. A sequel where you're playing around the age of 6-10, another around 14-16 and another when they're an adult, all with different perceptions & varying degrees of horror.

54701674.review:
When this game was originally released, I saw a play-through of it online done by some obscure youtuber. After finishing it, I thought it was quite excellent and I was surprised that the critics gave it a relatively mixed reception. Now that I finally sat down to play it though, I can understand the mixed reception it got as a few aspects to it could've been refined a bit more.

As for its story, I thought it was good, but it also felt underdeveloped and not fully realized. Before I get to my issues with it though, I'll first state that the general outline of the plot (which I won't reveal due to spoilers) works fine. Its story comes with a fascinating opening and ending which are quite interesting and compelling. As for the rest of the game though, while the areas you wander through are certainly filled with all kinds of bizarre, sometimes generic imagery, what they lack are many specific items which could be used to convey meaning. Sure, a couple set pieces did this, but they weren't nearly enough, so the story strangely felt like it was taking a backseat throughout much of the game. A greater emphasis on carefully chosen props rather than reality warping and creepy and often indescribable environments would've benefited the story quite a lot.

As for the gameplay/level design, I was also a bit mixed on it. I quite enjoyed the first level where you wander around your house at night as, even though it contained very little absurdity, it was made scary both by your size and the shadows in it. It was easily the best of the four main sections of the game. The second level had some promising level design as it took place in a playground, so this left a couple doors open to some various paths which could've been ventured down. Unfortunately, the gameplay felt pretty lacking in this section as it consisted of a scavenger hunt where you wander around the environment and look for several objects which enable you to progress in it. This was a rather uninteresting and, at times, tedious way to spend this level. The third and fourth levels were probably the weakest in terms of level design as this was when the reality warping and the indescribable environments took full effect (this was especially the case for the fourth level). As a result of this, the level design in the final two stages felt more creepy than terrifying.

The final two stages were where the enemy encounters appeared. Like Amnesia: The Dark Descent and Outlast, you couldn't fight the enemy and had to run and hide from it. While I thoroughly enjoyed the enemy encounters overall, they could've been a bit better. I liked how the enemy wasn't overused as this kept its appearances effective throughout. I also thought it was built up to quite well throughout the game as it would first appear briefly in the background until its presence kept on getting more and more prominent as the game went on. As for the run and hide mechanic in general, in order for it to be truly memorable, a game needs to have its singular voice which distinguishes it from other games which use it and make the mechanic its own, not a variation of someone else's. For instance, the sanity bar in Amnesia distinguished its mechanic from other games. Also, the night vision effect in Outlast distinguished it from other games as well. As for this one, the fact that you're a toddler should make it seem like it's a unique variation of that mechanic in theory, but after a bit, it just felt like I was playing a familiar mechanic at a slower speed. It did a bit to distinguish itself, but ultimately not enough for it to find its own singular voice. Overall, I'd still say this is one of the better aspects to the game though.

In conclusion, even though this game could've been better in many ways, I still enjoyed it as it had enough things to like about it that I enjoyed my time with it. I wouldn't recommend buying it at full price, but if it's on sale, I'd recommend picking it up as I'm sure you'll find value out of it as well.

54253465.review:
*Some Minor Spoilers*

I don't do very many reviews but I feel compelled to do this one.  This game tries to describe how a child is processing the terrible things happening around them.  Particularly a broken home and a alcoholic parent.  Having two children myself this game his particularly hard for me because when I was a child I grew up next to a family that was destroyed by alcoholism.  You could see the effects in hindsight that it was having on the child at the time. 

People tend to forget that a mind of a child is NOT like an adult or even a young teenager.  They do not understand the things going on around them.  So they are processing them in nightmares or night terrors which is what this is is an interesting take.  The game also does a good job of pushing a sense of scale.  I recall quite clearly being a child and thinking the home I lived in was a huge house but in reality it was just a standard 1800SF house.  But to a toddler who is barely 2ft tall a house can look immense and simple every day tasks like getting on a chair could seem overwhelming.

Children are programmed to view their parents as the source of comfort if they are scared.  Particularly their mothers.  So you're trying to find your mom while your mom is actually the reasons for your nightmares.  Quite the interesting dynamic.

Never had a game that made me want to hide under a bed and hold my teddy.  Like for real.  It has some seriously eerie moments.   The game will take you about 2 - 3 hours to complete depending on how thorough you are.  The game is worth the price of admission.  Well worth the three hours and it will stick with you.  One of the marks of a great game is if you talk about it afterwords.  My friend and I both did for a good hour or so after we beat it.

54232982.review:
Damien Hirst was an artist who rose to popularity in 1993 and again in 2007 for his piece "Mother and Child Divided". He was awarded the 1995 Turner Prize by the Tate Gallery for it and said that it symbolised the duality of body and mind while also expressing the "fragility of life" and as one critic said "Hirst presents a mother and child not only forever separated from one another, but also fatally severed in themselves. The impossibility of achieving or retaining an idealised (lost) unity (often coupled with a fear of fragmentation)". 

This is of course.... complete nonsense and since Mother and Child Divided was actually something as stupid as two cows, bisected and preserved inside of 4 large fish-tanks of formaldehyde. But does show that its possible to muster up enough hyperbole to justify even the most half-baked attempt at social and existential commentary. Among the Sleep's developers were clearly inspired by Hirst since the game itself is a half-hearted attempt at entertainment which contains more pretentious nonsense than a toddler on a sugar rush could shake a teddy at. Allow me to explain.

In short, this is a 3 hour game with an hour of a half of 'suspense' building before anything actually happens. At first I thought it was simply cutbacks due to limitations on indie developers but their 'museum' which is made available in-game explains that what started out of as adventure game ended up being this mess. Furthermore, they deliberately paced the game to give the 'illusion' of being safe. So this illusion of safety is maintained for half the game while you walk around environments opening doors and takings 'keys' to 'locks' in order to progress. Tedious doesn't even begin to describe it. Just as you're about to give up from sheer boredom however,  there is a stab at a half-hearted attempt at Alien: Isolation or Monstrum where you need to 'hide' from a monster which is patrolling the area. The AI of which is so basic that it actually causes the monster to glitch out and spin wildly if you happen to be on a raised platform out of reach and has no ability to actually touch the player if they are crouched under any object.

The game's attempt to provide some deeper meaning is utterly undermined by just how blatant the game is towards trying to explain it's symbolism. So much so that the developers started to forget that a game is actually a form of entertainment and fell into the trap of 'this is art'. Sorry, but games can be both art and entertainment but it takes more effort and creative direction than these developers could muster. To be fair though, the 2nd half of the game is atmospheric and varied despite the glaring flaws in the gameplay but it really needed to be that good all of the way through.

In summary though, this is not worth taking a look at. There is nothing here which is especially noteworthy or memorable and the replay value is absolute zero.

53619432.review:
Among the sleep is a puzzle game in like a dream world where you play as a toddler. This concept provides a limited array of actions that the character can take but some can be quite unique. While in the fantasy world this toddler must team up with his stuffed teddy bear to find his mom and escape the monsters. Simple concept but the question is whether this makes the game good or bad. I will be reviewing the game in a pro/ con style and end with my conclusion.

Pro:
      The level design is great. Not only is the art style a dream/ nightmare like but the designs of each level does not cause the player to get lost. Mainly just moving forward means your progressing the level and there are plenty of unique landmarks that are easy to notice and know where you are in the level.

        The music and sound are fantastic. Now I will say that the game is not scary but these sound effects really do try to be scary. It does create a substory of what is suppose to be interpreted based on sound cues and level design or invoke some sort of lingering fear for the player. Sometimes the sound cues make you think there is a monster around when the monster isnt introduced till a later section or level. My favorite moment was hearing something coming out of the water and seeing the monsters head pop out to stare at me. Finally the music is good but they are few and more atmospheric but they do add a layer of depth to the mood or the overall level design.

         Puzzles are simple. This is good because first of all we play as a toddler. In theory it is a good practice to ask what kind of puzzles would a toddler somewhat be able to solve which for a good amount of puzzles here you can see that thought process. Another way at looking at that is you dont want to make the puzzles hard since you dont want to make the puzzles too much of a focus when the big concept of the game is the story and design. The puzzles do somewhat contribute to the story but mainly to add gameplay to what can mostly be considered a walking simulation.

        Some unique actions are well unique. I mainly want to focus on the sprint feature, pause menu, and the teddy bear hug. When the player sprints they can only sprint for a short period of time till the character falls over. That is normal for a toddler since they dont normally have an excellent balance at a young age to be running/ moving fast. The pause menu pops up as the character puts his hands in front of his eyes like he is scared or playing peekaboo. Finally the teddy bear is a unique feature since normally at a young age children think non-animate objects hold life and are living friends. When you use the teddy bear he lights up to make things "less scary" which is a normal reaction when a child is scared and is hugging their favorite stuffed animal. These small features really add a layer of depth for the game and ground it with realistic concepts of a toddler and how they act under some specific situation or the fact they have limited mobility at a young age.

Con:
      The frame rate has some issues. Through the game there were many moments where the frame rate bounced around alot which is odd for an indie game that is pretty short. From time to time the game will freeze for a second to drop to like 5fps till it leaps to 60fps again to drop to like 45fps. You get the idea, the frame rate was not really consistent.

Conclusion:
         Among the sleep is an amazing short game. There was so much passion put into the game from the developers especially listing to the dev commentary. Some of these small features like the limited sprint really made the game feel somewhat grounded in realism but contradicted with the dream like atmosphere. It was a blast to see the story from start to finish to learn more about the mom and the family. I do think seeing a sequel would be nice to learn more of the father since we learned so much of the mother in this game. I would recommend the game to anyone interested in this game, I dont doubt that people would find something in it that they find an enjoyable experience.
