52177462.review:
Minor spoilers ahead. I don't go into much detail about the story but I do talk about a few things people might prefer learning on their own.
---
For an indie product, this is quite a competent and well polished game. I've found the graphics, sound design and voice acting to be pretty good, even great at parts, and I haven't come across any major bugs. I have no complaints when it comes to the technical skill on display here.

Unfortunately, as a horror game, I think it leaves much to be desired. It definitely looks creepy, but it doesn't "feel" creepy, and during my playthrough I was able to pinpoint some of the reasons I felt so: lack of urgency and of a substantial threat, the knowledge from the get-go that nothing you're seeing is real, and the presence of Teddy, your talking teddy bear companion in the game.

Out of those three issues, however, my biggest gripe is with the third. Teddy acts as a comforting presence, which aligns with the idea you're playing as a toddler, but that feels precisely at odds with what I'd want from a horror game. He speaks often, points to events and objects in unwelcome and ham-fisted ways and fails to serve as the catalyst for anything interesting. I'm not entirely sure of the developers' intentions behind the character (or at least the version of him that made to the final product), but as it stands, his presence only adds whimsy to the game, robs the player of noticing and pondering things on their own and reinforces the idea that nothing there is real. I feel the atmosphere of the game suffered greatly because of this.

In terms of gameplay, it's a mix of puzzle with exploration and hiding from enemies, not unlike games such as Amnesia and Outlast. Here, however, these elements are severely underplayed, possibly due to the extremely short length of 2 or 3 hours. No enemies appear until you are well into the game, and when they do show up in an actual threatening manner, there's very little challenge to avoiding them. Puzzles are also similarly basic and are most often a matter of finding an object to open something. Finally, being a toddler means you're not very agile and you have to crawl to move faster, but that's about it; the gameplay is otherwise very similar to other first-person view horror games and most of the relevance of your character's age lies in the aesthetics and plot.

The story is a metaphorical one, where things you see are really just a representation of what is truly happening in the real world. As stated before, I felt this too was a detriment to the horror aspect of the game as it gave me little reason to worry for the well being of any of the characters involved. There are ways to incorporate this sort of symbolism while still having high, tangible stakes, but it was not done so here.

All in all, this is a game that intrigued me with its premise but failed to execute it in a satisfactory manner. There's a concept room you can visit after beating the story that showcases a lot of the art, models and ideas behind the project, and I have to say, the final result doesn't do all that concept justice. They even had an original, much darker ending, showing that at one point their vision for the game might have threaded quite a different path.

Ultimately, I don't think it's unreasonable to expect a horror game to be more than just a game whose visuals happened to be too dark for it to fall into any other genre and, in this sense, it didn't work for me. However, I want to reiterate the game from a technical standpoint is perfectly fine and I believe the developers are well equipped to make more games in the future. Whatever their next project is, if any, hopefully I'll like it much better.

52175034.review:
What made the experience unlike others was the perspective. Remember, the world is how the child sees it and that means everything feels much bigger than you. And more threatening. Even the teddy bear made me feel a little unsafe when picking it up since it was so close to my face with those eyes of its.

Crawling, toddling, and climbing are your main methods of locomotion. You can hold the bear to light the way in the darker areas. Keep in mind that you can’t sprint toddle and hold the bear at the same time. And you will be sprinting unless you like being caught. There are some very light puzzles that can consist of finding an item and then using it or figuring out how to climb up to reach a doorknob. Most of the game is spent navigating the levels.


The game relies much more on tension, atmosphere, and the feeling of being pursued by a big ol’ monster. I didn’t know overcoats could make me feel anxious like they do in Among the Sleep. They really look menacing and not very friendly.

The main game isn’t that long. You’ll probably spend around two hours with it.If you’re looking for a short horror experience with an interesting perspective and no fluff, Among the Sleep might be a good choice for you.

51238854.review:
Developed and published by Krillbite Studio, an indie team from Norway, Among the Sleep is a unique take on the puzzle horror genre. You play as a toddler that just turned two years old; in the middle of celebrating your birthday with your mom, a stranger shows up at your door bearing a gift for you. Of course, it's your very own Teddy. You end up going on the adventure of your lifetime with your new best friend, who serves to help keep you safe from the ever-looming malicious entities of the worlds you're about to explore.

Saying a lot about Among the Sleep would be giving away all of its secrets, so this review will be kept fairly brief. It's impressive just how accurately Krillbite Studio were able to nail the mechanics of being a barely walking toddler. You move faster while you're in a crawling position, but you can still run if you're standing and walking; running for too long makes you fall down, however. You also have to push and pull objects to create paths to climb up, using items such as chairs and ottomans to crawl up to unlock doors. Rather than a flashlight, you can remove your Teddy from your back and hug him to have him cast a warm, safe light around you. One really cool small detail is that every item that would have words on it has them written in gibberish, since obviously a two year old doesn't know how to read yet.

There are five levels in total, with four of them having to be explored to find memories of your mother so that you can make progress towards finding her. Most of the puzzles simply involve making your way through the level, while climbing drawers, dressers, chairs, and ottomans to reach items that you need such as keys and glowing shapes. There are also drawings dispersed through each location, and although they do nothing but give you achievements if you happen to find all of them, they do add some incentive to explore the game to its fullest. For the most part, exploration doesn't feel like a chore since you're not constantly being hunted, and the environments are well detailed with a unique feel to each of them.

In the end, there is an unexpected plot buried within the puzzles and mild walking simulator gameplay that Among the Sleep carries. In the hundreds of horror games that I've played, I cannot once recall playing as a toddler; that in itself is a unique feature worth checking out, especially since it's so well done. Even though the story isn't totally spelled out while the game progresses, there are drawings on walls and other subtle hints to help guide your mind along what is happening. It's a slow burner for sure, and one that some players may find dull, but one that's worth carrying on with if you like a unique experience.

51190921.review:
Wow, this one game really got to me a bit. 
Let's say my family didn't have a peachy relationship either, so i kinda get what the devs wanted to explore by doing this game . Didn't really scare me a whole lot , but the atmosphere is really nicely done , i can definetly see how it can spook some people. Since these kind of themes aren't really explored in video games, the devs wanted to show how family conflicts can get to a kid ,and what impact they can have on him from a very young age. All the monsters you see are a hyperbolization , things seen as scary through a child's eyes. You have the game itself with several chapters, the "prologue" which was added as a free DLC , and a "museum" which is an area with dev commentary where they explain the gist of the game and what concepts were scrapped along the game's production. 
The game itself isn't really long, but this is a formula where "quality over quantity " worked really really well. I recommend getting this on a sale or in a bundle if you can, it's totally worth a play, even if there's not much in terms of replay value , it's a story that is going to stick with you.

I don't usually write Steam reviews but the Linux version of this game is so broken it deserves a negative review. Sadly I activated this game with a key so it wont count into the total but I hope it will serve as a good warning to anyone planing to play it on Linux.

Specs:
i9 9900K @5,1GHz
32GB RAM
GTX 1080Ti
fully updated Linux Mint 19.1

so well within the requirements.

What I assume are just Linux related issues:
[list]
    [*] The game runs at 250-300FPS but it feels like it is running at 15-25FPS
    [*] Even on full blast the sound is extremely quiet, low quality and feels like it is coming from 50 meters away.
    [*] I had to finish the playground chapter 3 times before it registered it as completed and it didn't make me repeat it again to progress
    [*] The mouse movement when moving objects around is very very janky and when you have to rotate an object (the valve of the thing you put the memory objects in and the handle of the well) it likes to (3/4 times for me) completely break the game to the point that the only thing you can do is to force close the game (you can still move the mouse around, but you can't open the menu or click on anything) which of course corrupts the autosave and you have to restart the chapter from the beginning.
    [*] At least the "Strike" achievement seems to be broken. I can't comment on the rest since I was unable to finish the game on Linux and had to switch to Windows where the achievements worked fine.
    [*] Does not work with SteamPlay (Proton version 4.2-5), it just opens to a black screen and nothing happens afterwards.
[/list]

General issues:
[list]
    [*] It gave me motion sickness, most likely due to the FPS issues
    [*] I get scared very easily and generally don't handle playing horror games very well, but I did not find this game scary at all.
    [*] The store page claims the game has Steam Cloud. It most definitely does not.
    [*] The falling down when walking mechanic is nothing but annoying,
[/list] 

The one and only good/redeeming thing about this game to me is the teddy bear. And I can not recommend this game under any circumstances, especially not on Linux.

[u] Gameplay [/u]
Among the Sleep is a first-person survival horror action-adventure video game, seen from the view of a toddler. For most of the game, the player is accompanied by a sentient teddy bear named Teddy, a birthday present from the toddler's father. The player can hug Teddy, who emits light that helps the player navigate through darker environments. Throughout the game, the player is followed by two monsters: a feminine figure that haunts the first three levels, and a trench coat-wearing figure that haunts the final level.

50485161.review:
Let me express something before we get into this: I am a pansy. I have yet to completely finish the first Amnesia. I have a backlog of horror games (including some point n' clicks) that grows every day. Because I have a problem. I LOVE horror games... but like an ice cream enthusiast who happens to also be lactose intolerant, horror games do not love me. So there you have it; that's the score.

Now that being said, I'm going to power through this one to completion. Know why? Because it's that good. Oh man is this game good. It is a testament to why horror games are so great... and why even now, in a market saturated with action horrors and tired old tropes, you'll still find an "Among the Sleep." This game is horrifying. Care to know why? What's the biggest issue plaguing the horror genre? That's right: termites. And player empowerment. Sometimes I'm a big, brave guy lugging around a shotgun. Sometimes I'm running around with a camera. Sometimes I might as well be stark naked. But I always find myself on equal ground with the baddies. Sure they're menacing, but I'm faster. And smarter. And sometimes more heavily armed. And suddenly we're not playing a horror game anymore. So how do we remove player empowerment, a hypothetical developer might muse? How do we make the player feel like a babe lost in the woods? We turn them into a ♥♥♥♥ing babe, right down to the wobbles and coos and imaginary friends.

And when I tell you that makes this game immersive and terrifying, I'm not kidding. When you pause the screen you cover your little eyes. When you move at all, AT ALL, you make adorable little sounds of struggle. And when you, the player, gaze into that mother♥♥♥♥ing abyss, that sucker stares right back. Every shadow hides a menace, every sound betrays a would-be threat. Everything is so big and intimidating. The whole environment just mocks you as you explore it semi-impotently. Because you're a baby. A smart baby, yes. But a baby. And that big, scary world is out to get you.

I'm not remotely done with this game. I know I have a ways to go. I'm already freaked out - in a good way! If you have a passing interest in horror, you won't be disappointed. Now I'm going to go clean the boom-boom out of my pants and press onward.

50376465.review:
Among The Sleep gives an interesting take of a creepy game in the eyes of a toddler. While it's not necessarily a horror game, those who have childhood memories of being a little kid will have some nostalgia.

Graphics:
The graphics and atmosphere are beautiful in this game. There are many shapes and interesting stages that are warped around a child's mind and feeling. The design in some stages are on the playful and creepy side. It gives me a Yoshi's Story vibe from N64.

Controls:
The controls are a bit wacky, but still playable. You can toggle between crawling, walking, and running. However, you can't really walk and run for too long. You can press ESC to cover your eyes and pause the game, press a button to hug your teddy bear, and interact and throw objects. Just a heads up, you may want to set the controls once you start the game to default. When I started, there were no keys assigned.

Story:
Where's mommy? What happened to mommy? Is mommy okay? I am looking everywhere for her with my teddy bear, but no sign of mommy. Why is she humming? Why is she crying? Why are there scary things out there?

Voices:
While there isn't much characters in game, the voice acting is great. The mother's voice is what I pictured: loving, caring, and struggling to keep a straight face in front of the baby. The baby's acting is natural...well of course straight from a baby. The teddy bear's voice acting is kinda creepy. In a child's ears, it sounds comforting. To us as adults...well...let's just say it's someone we don't want to hang around with our kids.

Gameplay:
There was a good bit of glitches and bugs in the game, but otherwise I was able to move around it. The good news is there isn't much of a consequence when it's game over. Instead, it spawns you a bit back to where you were. There were cases like In the forest where I was following a bridge that ended up leading to no where except off the stage. I thought it was part of the game so, of course, I fell off and it was game over. When I went back, the way spawned up. Another area is the closet, where in some cases you can see throughout all of the stage in some areas. Again, sometimes I walk through those areas, thinking it was part of the game...and I fell off the map. Another case is where some of the voices and lines don't pop up as well. In the closet, I played through it a few times to find the drawings, and some lines I never heard the first time popped up. Last case was at the well, where I was stuck and I could not even open the game menu and have to force close it.

That aside, the goal of the game is to collect objects to open the path further to finding your mom, and there are optional drawings you can collect and small objects to interact with for achievements. You just need to have an explore-like mindset to get through the game. There is a limit to walking and running, of course, since you're just a baby. You can get easily spooked in some areas and snatched up by creatures.

Horror?:
This game is categorized as a horror game, but it's not really a horror game. Think of it as a 4 out of 10 on the horror scale and categorized as creepy. This game is suitable for preteens or people who don't really like horror games. If you're looking for a game that is creepy like Amnesia: The Dark Descent or Slender: The Arrival, this isn't that category.

Overall:
Despite many bugs and glitches, Among The Sleep still earns itself as a unique and enjoyable game that can be played by preteens and up. With a switch from the normally-used  teenager or adult protagonist to a toddler, it shows the limits and imagination of the child through their eyes. With beautiful graphics, great atmosphere, and unique maneuvering to get through the game, this game is a unique gem of modern-day gaming. While it's not really a horror game, it's still a game that should be played and will be enjoyed by many.

Pros:
-Beautiful atmosphere and graphics.
-Good voice acting.
-Unique gameplay.

???:
-Not really a horror game.

Cons:
-Glitches that can interfere gameplay, but moved around with.
-Weird controls at times.
-Bugs that may require you to restart the game.

50327579.review:
This game was part of an indie bundle that I purchased through Humble Bundle. Although I'd ultimately recommend the game, I also have to admit that I'm pretty disappointed with it. I feel like this is a really unique and interesting concept - after all, you don't assume the role of a baby in many games out there. However, it's poorly executed and marred by horrible controls. I used both the keyboard/mouse and a PS4 controller; each was awful. So alas, there's really no escaping it.

The story was interesting, albeit a bit predictable - especially in terms of the ending. Graphics are decent/generic. Voice acting is nice, but nothing special. Pausing the game results in an animation where the baby (player character) covers their eyes, which is pretty cute/clever and fitting. The game itself isn't very scary - there are a few minor jump scares, but that's it. I developed more anxiety during one of two short stealth "puzzles", but even they weren't terribly difficult.

If you can get the game on sale and you're willing to deal with the terrible controls, then Among the Sleep is a fun and slightly different experience. I wouldn't go out of my way to play it, though - which is a shame because like I said earlier, the concept itself is pretty neat. I feel like they could have done a lot with the player character being a baby (helpless, limited in the way they can interact with their environment/surroundings, etc.) and the game's half-hearted execution left me feeling disappointed. I'm rating this as "recommend" but really I wish there was a "shrug" or "meh" option, for the reasons stated above.

49940826.review:
Among the Sleep is a unique experience.  It's a short game, but that gives you the type of experience you would hope all games could provide.  You are a toddler.  You can walk or crawl, crawling being faster but with limited view, or you can run but for just a short while before you fall and crawl again.  You can climb up on chairs, drawers, and other platforms as well.  During the course of the game you will go through 4 chapters collecting memories and from time to time you have to hide or not get caught by a monster who lurks in just about each level.

The overall story that this short game tells, the graphic style, the sounds and music all make for a very enjoyable complete package.  As a horror game, or at least an intensified adventure experience, it actually does really well too.  The lighting creates a great atmosphere and mixed with the sounds and the music, it does create some haunting situations.

Overall, I really liked this game, came back and completed the achievements which has you mainly collecting drawings made with crayons.  If the price is below $10 bucks, definitely worth the time to load up and play.  It's not perfect, nor is it too difficult or physically intense like a shooter would be.  It's very well constructed walking simulator with a few platforming puzzles mixed in, but the overall message and storyline will truly make you think.  Great game, pick it up.

49887550.review:
I wasn’t sure what to expect with Among the Sleep. I just knew I’d be playing as a toddler. To my surprise, I found myself enjoying the game. Well, more like the atmosphere did a decent job of making me feel creeped out and uncomfortable.

What made the experience unlike others was the perspective. Remember, the world is how the child sees it and that means everything feels much bigger than you. And more threatening. Even the teddy bear made me feel a little unsafe when picking it up since it was so close to my face with those eyes of its.

The story starts off somewhat normal with no horror elements until after the game lets you learn the moves. Crawling, toddling, and climbing are your main methods of locomotion. You can hold the bear to light the way in the darker areas. Keep in mind that you can’t sprint toddle and hold the bear at the same time. And you will be sprinting unless you like being caught. There are some very light puzzles that can consist of finding an item and then using it or figuring out how to climb up to reach a doorknob. Most of the game is spent navigating the levels.

There are only a handful of jump scares. The game relies much more on tension, atmosphere, and the feeling of being pursued by a big ol’ monster. I didn’t know overcoats could make me feel anxious like they do in Among the Sleep. They look menacing and not very friendly.

I can’t say much about the story without spoiling it, but I thought it was handled well. It’s a somber tale being told and a moment that made me shake my head with sadness.

The main game isn’t that long. You’ll probably spend around two hours with it. There’s a prologue chapter somewhere, but I didn’t have an urge to play it. I was content with what I’ve already played. If you’re looking for a short horror experience with an interesting perspective and no fluff, Among the Sleep might be a good choice for you.

49882052.review:
Initially I thought this game was going to become a mix of Silent Hill: Shattered Memories (storytelling, gathering items and switching between story and action parts) and Amnesia (atmosphere), yet the further I played, the more I realised this game stands on its own. 
The mechanics and puzzles are simple: you walk and crawl around, solve puzzles which are very basic (move a crate to climb on it, remove something to retrieve an item or place an item to a specific spot), which make the gameplay very fluid. Story is simple as well, yet very effective and displayed in areas and characters. You play as a toddler and face all his fears, while carrying a guardian teddy bear, which provides you light and safety in dark. The game is very creative and plays with every day items and locations, shifting and twisting them into obscure and unfriendly environment. The sounds are amazingly made, bringing eerie atmosphere and suspense. Another great feature is that the game contains museum chapter, a place where you can find all the info about the game contents and the development. It's interesting to see the path of creating the game, the ideas which were thrown away or redesigned, characters which got changed with time and story, etc. While the game has a plenty of strong sides, some parts may seem weak if you look for a game which takes a plenty of time to beat it, complicated puzzles or tough enemies. The game already offers a fine challenge, to test your senses and fear while crawling in the dark, surrounded by items and creatures perceived by toddlers.
 All in all, the game was a very pleasant experience. The approach is characteristic and executed very well. The game doesn't take much time to complete (2-5 hours), I'm sure it will be worthy of your time.

49739782.review:
[H1][b]ANÁLISIS DE "AMONG THE SLEEP: ENHACED EDITION"[/b][/H1]

Versión mejorada de Among the Sleep, que ofrece mejoras gráficas, libro de ilustraciones digital, la banda sonora integrada en el juego, posibilidad de cambiar el pijama del personaje, mejoras en cuanto a jugabilidad, nuevos diálogos y el nivel del museo, ideal para cuando terminamos el juego y queremos conocer todos los detalles en profundidad de cómo se hizo el juego, material eliminado inédito y artworks.

Para los que no sabéis mucho acerca del juego, a continuación os explico un poco de qué va: 

[H1]Historia:[/h1]

Para los que no hayáis jugado el original, se trata de una aventura de terror en primera persona, en la que controlamos a un niño de 2 años a lo largo de lo que parece ser una pesadilla en busca de su madre. La aventura se basa en los recuerdos y los traumas que tiene el niño protagonista. Para no destriparos más el argumento, no entraré más en detalles para dejaros que seáis vosotros los que los vayáis descubriendo mientras jugáis. El juego está traducido al español. 

[h1]Jugabilidad:[/h1]

El control del bebé es muy realista, pudiendo correr poca distancia y cayendo al suelo si lo hacemos durante mucho rato, siendo más fiable ir gateando a los sitios. Podemos manipular objetos, lanzar pelotas, arrastrar sillas para alcanzar pomos de puertas...

El juego se basa en avanzar por los escenarios y explorar en búsqueda de los dibujos, solucionar pequeños puzles, abrir puertas y conseguir objetos. En ocasiones tendremos que escondernos de "cosas" que ya descubriréis por vosotros mismos. La ambientación es muy buena y nos llevaremos unos buenos sustos. 

Muy recomendable jugarlo con mando, aunque con teclado es perfectamente jugable también. Yo lo he jugado con el mando de Xbox 360 y responde bastante bien (salvo algún que otro problemilla) y tiene vibración, lo cual nos ayudará a meternos más en la ambientación.

[h1]Gráficos:[/h1]

El juego luce bastante bien: escenarios muy variados y llenos de detalles, multitud de objetos, buenos efectos de luces y sombras... el problema es que tiene multitud de bugs gráficos, como fallos de clipping, haciéndonos atravesar objetos constantemente, texturas que aparecen y desaparecen, etc. Estos fallos se hacen especialmente evidentes si intentamos acceder a zonas del escenario que no estaban pensadas para ello, pero choca bastante que sean tan habituales siendo la versión mejorada. No me quiero ni imaginar la cantidad de errores gráficos que tendría el original...

[h1]Sonido:[/h1]

Este apartado cumple perfectamente, el sonido ambiental está trabajado y hace ganar enteros en cuanto a la experiencia, pero no tiene una banda sonora que destaque especialmente.

Mi lista de pros y contras a modo de resumen: 

[H1]PROS:[/H1]

- Mejora la versión original

- La ambientación

- Nos llevaremos unos buenos sustos

- El diseño  y la variedad de los niveles

- Gráficamente luce muy bien

- El nivel extra del prólogo

- El museo

- Los coleccionables

- Tiene logros Steam

- Se puede encontrar a buen precio en épocas de ofertas

- Está traducido al español

- Es rejugable gracias a los coleccionables de los dibujos que tenemos repartidos por todos los escenarios

[H1]CONTRAS:[/H1]

- Muchos bugs: fallos de clipping y popping en determinadas zonas

- Problemas con los saves en ocasiones

- Muy corto, explorando al máximo y no yendo a lo loco no dura más de 5 horas (incluyendo el DLC)

[H1]Conclusión:[/H1] 

De oferta es un juego muy recomendable a pesar de la gran cantidad de bugs que tiene. Gran experiencia. 

Si mi análisis te ha gustado o te ha servido de ayuda, agradecería que dejaras tu valoración positiva. ¡No dudéis en dejar vuestros comentarios! Un saludo y gracias por leerme.

49588260.review:
An excellent, well thought out game by developers who obviously planned, playtested and were not afraid to cut and tweak content as they went. I say 'game' loosely. This is more of a psychological journey into how the mind of this 2-year old perceives, and is affected by what goes on in their life. The mechanics were perfect, turn the crosshair off unless you get frustrated trying to centre the screen to interact with things, go into the controls and make sure they are all assigned as for some reason, 'throw' wasn't on mine, then turn the lights off and play! (This is not just a jump-scare-mageddon, do expect the unexpected, and do push through the harder elements and finish the game in one go, it will reward you with narrative.)

I recommend playing through all in one go, don't use any guides as the occasional time I felt lost, it didn't last long. Then visit the museum and play the Prologue chapter afterwards, as unlike most behind-the-scenes content, it is actually really interesting and rewarding and adds more depth to the game and a great insight into the developers minds! 

The only negative is there is not really any replay value. There were drawings to collect as I went but it didn't let me know how many I found or reveal anything for doing so. Maybe alternate endings would have helped, or a hardcore mode where you only get one chance, with relevant steam achievements attached to spur on players to replay. It will sit in my steam library and I would probably play it again in 5-10 years, but for what is essentially a one-shot game, the full price is quite high, its a perfect price if it supports the developers to keep producing high quality work like this, but if you have not got much cash spare, wait for a steam sale, play the game in its entirety, and enjoy!

I look forward to seeing what Krillbiter Studio produce in the future!

49572179.review:
Baby's First Horror Game.

Among the Sleep is a walking simulator horror game that has some light puzzle elements.

You play as a baby who's awoken during the night and who has to find his mother. Along for the ride is your new teddy bear that you got for your 2nd birthday. The voice acting for the bear is really appropriate and well executed.

Since you're a baby, you know the game will do the whole "new perspective" thing on the environments. They don't do anything creative with the new viewpoint though, but it's nothing too bad either. The environments are pretty middling at best. 

Over the course of the game you figure out more of the story behind everything as everything slowly unravels. And then in the last 30% of the game, the whole point is more than revealed yet the game still has the need to beat your over the head with the message that it showed. It seems the developers forgot that only the player's character's a baby, not the player themselves. Overall it's a good story and I was fine with the conclusion. If the game didn't obviously hit you over the head with the conclusion for a good chunk of the game, it'd be on par with games like Layers of Fear, which kept things more vague for a longer time. 

The visuals are alright. It's relatively colourful and there's darkness aplenty. Though luckily it's never too dark to not see. Don't expect top tier texture quality or amazing visual tricks. 

The gameplay's very basic. You're a baby, so you're small. Interact with the environment to make up for it. Open drawers to create makeshift ledges and Mirror's Edge your way through a kitchen or some other place. The game makes you find certain things and that's pretty much the entire gameplay loop. You enter the level, you need a certain item from it. To get to that item, you have to complete a treasure hunt to open the route to that specific item. Later in the game, you'll have a baby's first Outlast aspect, where you hide from the "big bad". It sees you, you hide in or under something, wait for it to go away and you keep moving. The game's forgiving with the "big bad". Often it makes it disappear or just walk the wrong way, which makes it more easy, but also way better overall. Nothing's more annoying than having to wait 15 minutes to get through a 5-10 minute long level. The level design's well made and I didn't get stuck once. Everything was intuitive and nice to go through. 

There's also a small DLC level, called "Prologue". It's overall a good level. It doesn't have the teddy from the main game for obvious reasons and I do think the level suffers because of it. Overall though, it's basically a level with 5 extremely simple puzzles. Do them and you're finished. It's definitely way better than the over-the-top, pretentious artsy bullshit that Layers of Fear's Inheritance DLC, so you'll probably have a fair amount of fun with it if you liked the "dumb man's metaphor simulator".

Overall the game's worth giving a shot if you can get it for a cheap price. The game's pretty short though with around 2-3 hours with the DLC included. 
If you're a broke kid who can afford a single game every once in a while with hours on end of free time, then maybe pass this game up until it inevitably gets given away for free on Humble Bundle. 
But if you're a person with limited time who has some spare money, then I recommend you give this a shot. The game respects your time and gets to the point pretty quickly.

49451647.review:
[i]Among The Sleep[/i] is one of those experiences that I wish I enjoyed more.
There's really nothing wrong with the game itself. Krillbite lists [i]Among The Sleep[/i] as a survival horror game, but really I would call it more of an atmospheric stealth game. I found myself less scared of the threats themselves and more of being caught and having to start over from the last checkpoint. Luckily this rarely happened and when it did, the checkpoints were so closely stacked that it was less than a 30 second run back to where I was.
There really isn't much game here: I finished the game and collecting all the achievements in about 2 hours.
[b]I wouldn't recommend this game for everyone[/b] but if you're interested in atmospheric horror, you should give it a chance.

49407770.review:
I was really excited about this one, so I pounced on the humble bundle that had it at the $1 tier.

It was OK, but particularly at the price point I'd say pass on this one. Full price is $17, and I completed the entire thing in less than 2 hours. It's closer to a lackluster movie than a compelling video game.

It was honestly just uninspired. I thought that the premise of horror from a child's perspective was super intriguing, but the actual implementation was a combination of a fairly predictable story and repetitive gameplay.

I can occasionally get behind a walking simulator, but it's got to have a little more meat to it.

I recommend you skip this game and instead:
-Play Psychonauts. The aesthetic and most of the mechanics of Among the Sleep are a lesser version of it.
-Play Little Nightmares. It does a much better job of capturing the "I'm small and I'm scared" vibe.
-Watch The Babadook. It's a much better version of the same the story.

After I finished the story and played through the Museum bonus level that shows development tidbits, I was just super disappointed that they scrapped the fun "cliche" ideas that they started with and went for an even more derivative "deeper meaning" approach.

49402063.review:
[i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/35145066/] Feel free to follow my review page![/url][/i]

[h1]The gist of it:[/h1]
Among the Sleep - Enhanced Edition is a short creepy/horror game where you play as a very young child that experiences from her own eyes the nightmares surrounding her.

👍 [u]The good parts:[/u]
+Creepy story.
+Decent atmosphere.

👎[u]The bad parts:[/u]
-Not very scary or very little moments that may panic you. 
-Very short and basically just a walking simulator.

[h1]Story[/h1]
It's a very short game so going into details regarding the story without spoiling is hard but I'll try to be as evasive as possible. The game puts you into the shoes of a two-year-old where you start to experience and see things that are not natural. As you progress through several nightmares or levels with the help of your Teddy Bear, you start to figure out what exactly they represent, up until the end where it all makes sense. 

I kinda figured it out as I was playing but overall it was a decent story, one that may reflect with some players.

Story rating: 7.5/10

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Among The Sleep is basically a creepy walking simulator. You basically have to traverse several levels, find some keys to progress, find some objects and short moments where you have to avoid the monsters. It's basically the baby version of Amnesia but a lot less scary and no difficulty at all. 

Movement felt kinda janky and going from crouching to standing or climbing and using your light was at times very cumbersome. 

Gameplay rating:  7/10

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The game's audio is quite well done. It does help a lot in creating a very creepy atmosphere and the soundtrack impacts that creepiness level as well. There's also some voice acting, which was all decent. The overall sound design is probably and should always be one the most important aspects of a creepy/horror game and I think it does a good job here. 

Audio rating:  8/10

[h1]Graphics, performance and tech analysis[/h1]
The atmosphere is okay most of the times and varies somewhat from forest areas to weird indoor locations. It's mostly very dark so you can't really tell or admire the levels. 

Performance is as you can imagine, really good, no issues running the game and I have not encountered any kind of bugs. 

Graphics, performance and tech analysis rating: 7.5/10

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Overall Among the Sleep is an okay horror game or not even horror but mostly just a creepy experience one that ultimately does pay off, at least for me. Some may not find the conclusion that interesting but I'd say at this point if you still didn't get the game on the endless sales and bundles, go for it when you get the chance. 

[h1]Final score:  7.5/10[/h1]

A fantastic game I didn't know I needed in my life, Among the Sleep is an emotional and dark journey into the psyche of a toddler. By no means a very lengthy game, it more than compensates with innovative level design with incredible attention to immersion and imagination. 47939317.review:
Among the Sleep takes childhood horror and family troubles and turns it into a masterpiece of a horror game. Something that an adult wouldn't find terrifying is filtered through the eyes of a child and turned into an absolute terror. While it is a short and rather linear game it's a unique experience that no other horror game has properly covered prior or since, and it's done beautifully. 

It's your second birthday party with just you and your mother, when a man arrives at the door with a present for you - a teddy bear that can walk and talk to you. After you've had your cake and are getting ready for a nap, your teddy is stolen from you and your mother disappears. You and your bear crawl out into the darkened house to find her, traveling across several dark and twisted worlds to discover the story of what happened to her, and to you.

Playing from a toddler's perspective puts a twist on everything we're shown as adults, obscure hints at the story come out as seemingly obvious to us. Even from the start we're given context as to what the life as this child is like, and what happened to our family. Symbolism through all the levels gives clues as to how the ending plays out, but it never fully clicks until the last half hour of the game. The subtle hints and the gentle guiding toward the deep and darker meaning behind it all is done with the right balance of hand holding and throwing you into the story that most would make sense of things right away, and see the underlying messages for what they are.

Most of the game is based around collecting items or solving puzzles to unlock the next area, having you crawl through small spaces to find new areas or pulling yourself up on drawers to reach areas higher up. There are collectables to find through the game, different drawings that provide more clues toward the story and give you achievements for taking the time to find. Most of the gameplay feels very appropriate for the setting, and semi-realistic for the capabilities of a toddler with a sentient bear guiding him along. Paired with the environment where coats look like monsters and furnaces can come to life and chase you down, Among the Sleep does an amazing job at playing on and bringing to life all our worst childhood fears just in the gameplay alone.

Visually, the game has a tone that reminds me of a "dark vibrance", where a lot of the child-like items such as toys and plushes are very bright and colorful but muted by the horror tones of the game, giving them an eerie quality. It does have some optimization problems and the lower end graphics glitched/stuttered at some points on my average laptop, but the visuals are still beautifully done and only add to the immersion and fantasy-based storytelling. It feels very much like a child's nightmare, and everywhere you look is something that reminds you that you're not only playing as a child, but you're supposed to be scared.

Among the Sleep is a unique horror game that lovers of the genre should appreciate. It reminds us all of the things we were scared of as children, and brings them to life in such a way that can scare us all over again as adults. Anyone who enjoys unique indie horror games should add Among the Sleep to their library.

47385110.review:
Well, where should i start from...this game isn't scary or an "horror adventure" as it's being described. It's a very average kind of puzzle game (quite literally) that poses no challenge whatsoever. 
While it could be interesting as a concept, it is flawed in its premisis: it isn't exactly much fun and it doesn't have a story good enough that will draw you in...the level design is not the most boring but at the same time it doesn't really have anything special to offer to eyesight. You get to walk or crawl across a few levels that, to be honest, are quite linear and are truly set on rails. You don't have much to do other than follow the storyline/path and make sure to avoid the monster triggered by the scripts when you perform certain actions or hear a certain soundtrack. 

It also isn't particularly fun because, for the most part, it is designed with height and platforms in mind, BUT you get told from the start that your best choice for moving around should be by crawling instead of walking, and the game does indeed make that annoying by literally causing you to fall on your face once every few steps if you decide you'd rather walk and see stuff. Also, you're often supposed to vault on furniture or other items, and the whole animation is something you cannot control, it is both unnerving and unpleasing to me. Why the heck we can't jump? It's not a game designed with realism in mind, for God sake.


Last but most important, this game is boring because it is so damn repetitive: you're supposed to look for 4 different items from the start, and aside of that being so clichè, old school and whatever you can call it, they really didn't try hard to make it enjoyable or that interesting at all. Actually, several areas are nearly literally a copypaste in the way they play and feel. 
The final level is perhaps the only one that somewhat truly redeemes the whole game as it becomes more of an actual dream-like experience and less of a rational or plain scenario with the odd bits and pieces here and there, it actually tickles your mind a fair bit and has elements that could well belong to "Alice: Madness returns". 

Oh, and the bugs. You sometimes can get stuck, or happen to fall into water because you slipped 2cm within the closest river. A particular corner in one of the scenario has an issue where you can literally see the whole skybox through the room. And i could replicate that bug really easily! Why they couldnt fix it in the first place?? 

Overall this game isn't terrible. But it isn't expressing its full potential for sure. The gameplay lacks so much depth...the story seems to offer interesting suggestions here and there, but not that much is getting delivered. The feeling i got is that this game wanted to be a tale for adults while the main character gets shown as a baby and is treated as such, basically cutting the premisis short of its (many) possibilities. It is a compromise that should've been treated differently.

wow.....this little game deserves a great review. so a first a few cons:
1. no way to save your game. it saves at checkpoints, and this is one of my pet peeves that usually result in my not recommending a game (but i'm overlooking it in this case, as the checkpoints aren't too badly spaced. still, this was my major gripe with the game.
2. i encountered what i think were 2 bugs, where i got physically stuck in parts of the terrain. but i was able to quit and continue at my last checkpoint, which wasn't too bad.  the game does "seem" to save, but honestly i'm not entirely sure where i was going to come back to after a quit.

now the good parts:
1. very unique 2 year old avatar you crawl or barely walk around with. he has a teddy.
2. the game starts a bit slow, and i felt kind of foolish playing as a 2 year old in his pajamas, but i stuck with it and after the intiial slow part, the game picks up nicely with fabulous graphics and storyline.
3. movement could be a bit improved, but it wasn't bad. few keys to learn and it does have an "invert y axis". another major pet peeve of mine is when a game does not have that.
4. a very good ending. very surprising. the last minutes tie together everything you encounter during the game. a really nice touch. the child faces demons during the game, yet i never realized what the meaning of the game was until right at the end. and it surprised me how this little game actually had some very serious life lessons. 

i read other reviews that said it was a quick 2 hour game. so it took me like 10 hours to finish it, but i actually did with no walkthrough, unusual for me! it wasn't hard, but hard enough for me.

thanks to the creators, great job. i'm giving this game 5 stars our of 5 (i wish Steam had a 5 star system!).

45727927.review:
Usually, if I feel like it, I'll write lengthy reviews (probably more than people want to read), but looking back at this game, there's not much I have the feeling to say.

Although the idea of [i]Among the Sleep[/i] is different, in that you're controlling a baby/toddler in what turns into a weird dark fantasy world, I didn't find myself getting that scared in it. I play dark/horror games to get creeped out and drawn into the scenario, but for this game, it was mostly just a short little time with no lasting effect.

I think the fact that you play as a toddler and experience from that point-of-view that the game wasn't really scary to me, because they designed it off of the common cliches of what little kids get scared of: noises at night-time; darkness or shadows; objects much bigger than them that they can't comprehend; etc. As said, the idea is more unique, but because of that point-of-view, it doesn't do much. I'm not going to get freaked out when I see what they're trying to make as a living jacket/coat, for instance.

Despite that, some of the environment design is pretty nice and bizarre, including the area with the paintings. But the end result didn't pay off much for me.

I was playing chapter 3, the Forest House. It requires that we find 3 puzzle pieces to move forward. It's long and tedious because the walk speed of a 2-year-old is, well, slow. Anyway, on the second puzzle piece, my game bugged out and the character was stuck. No problem, I said. The game was "saving" periodically, so shouldn't be an issue, right? Wrong!

The game actually does not save at all and the chapter restarts. I said, no issues! Let's try again. Same issue in the same place. Now, I'm not going to restart the section again. Sure, it may take less than 10 mins to reach that spot, but it's not guaranteed that I'll not encounter that bug again & tedious as hell.

Somos un bebé en el día de nuestro segundo cumpleaños, no encontramos a mamá y tenemos que salir buscarla. Este es el punto de partida de Among the Sleep, un juego de terror desde el punto de vista de un bebé. Para mi su punto mas fuerte quizás sea este, el echo de ponernos en la piel de un niño tan pequeño, es algo que no había hecho en ningún videojuego antes.

A poco mas de medio metro desde el suelo vamos descubriendo la historia (muy buena aunque poco desarrollada), dónde esta mamá y que está pasando, a través de escenarios muy bonitos y detallados, resolviendo puzzles muy sencillos que en algún momento se hacen repetitivos. En ningún momento nos quedaremos atascados, el juego es muy lineal y fácil, simplemente hay que avanzar.

Los primeros 15 min estaba muy emocionada porque conseguía ponerme nerviosa y al fin y al cabo es lo que busco en un juego de terror, a medida que avanza el juego esta tensión desaparece para volver otra vez un poco antes del final. Es un juego bastante corto, yendo tranquilos y explorando todos los rincones se puede acabar en unas 3 horas.

Aún así vale la pena jugarlo porque es algo diferente dentro del genero de terror.

45487205.review:
Among the Sleep is an interesting perspective on the first person horror genre, with your views and perspectives given from a low perspective, making everyday items spookier or creepier by default.

The storyline releases itself piece by piece, and for me, the realisation seemed to dawn on me about two thirds in as to what was actually happening/happened, althought smarter people may notice quicker.

The game is pretty stylish, although graphically, although not offensive, it's also nothing to shout about.

Controls are simple yet effective, and with the game being relatively short at just a few hours, the lack of new commands or abilities never becomes a problem. With your character being faster whilst crawling, but suffering from restricted views, it's interesting that you feel vulnerable in different ways in both available stances.

For me, the only problem that can be thrown at the game is the fact that the main enemy only becomes prominent and invasive near the end of the game, and as the AI/mechanics of this enemy only have a single mechanic, the fear of said enemy is drained from the game as soon as you have been caught once. The effects though, are still well executed from this, with lighting effects being a particular highlight.

Overall, this game will never be the most inventive, difficult or scariest, but once all together, it's still a pleasant experience, as much as being chased through juvenile nightmarish environments from the evil incarnation of your own mother can be....

Best for: Adventurous toddlers with a love for light up teddies!

45456014.review: Among the Sleep is a pretty unique take on horror, but it is pretty short. I recommend getting it during a sale.

45392348.review:
Amoung the Sleep - A Horror gamers perspective 

[h1] Short and Spoilerless [/h1]

Amoung the Sleep is a game that throws you into the perspective of a very small child. From the beginning we are introduced to an exploring on our own before we are accompanied by our best friend Teddy. The story follows a fairly linear progression and this makes it very approchable to gamers of all skill. It does not try to scared you at every corner but rather employs what a child is scared of... the fear of seeing something that you really won't be able to get out of your head. It isn't even the fact that the enemies are there that is frightening but rather the fact that you don't want to ever be caught whereas if we draw a contrast to Outlast, the thrill of that game is by in large due to the threat of being picked up and ripped to shreds. Amoung the sleep plays with deeper ideas and we are introduced to what i decifered to be parental issues and alcohol abuse. 

A truly  intriguing game that you can play in a single sitting within 2-4hrs.
Highly recommended for anyone willing to support such titles - 8.2/10

45302088.review:
[b]Among the Sleep[/b] is a tension filled walking simulator [strike] where you are given a S.P.E.C.I.A.L book from your father and the Tunnel Snakes totally need to be dealt with[/strike] Eh ehgm, where you play as a toddler with a teddy bear that may or may not be a sociopath. (I named him Patches O'hoolihan, due to a patch on his arm.)

This game is on the shorter side. It's very straightforward; not much in the way of exploration. Though, there are collectibles throughout. 

Thematically, you play as a toddler and on the surface I'm sure you can imagine what sorts of horrors might entail from that perspective. However, the game takes on a darker tone. Darker in the way of a real, serious issue. [spoiler]Left intentionally ambiguous as to the exact details of what occurred. It's pretty heavily implied. If you've ever played “Papo & Yo” or “Spate”. Those themes are prevalent here as well.[/spoiler] 

[b][i]THE GIST
Short, but well done tension building walking sim.[/i][/b]

[i]There is a part in the beginning where your Mother is carrying you to your room and shadows are following her. It was the only time I felt honestly uncomfortable. I started to think about being that age, seeing that happen, not being able to convey what I saw while simultaneously not being able to do anything about it myself. Which pretty much surmises the game's undertone.[/i]

[quote]More here — [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28295405/]Station Argus[/url][/quote]

43871863.review:
I really enjoyed this game, it's one of the few horror games I've played that relies mostly on its atmosphere to provide the horror, which I feel is way more powerful than an over-reliance on jump scares because it creates an ongoing feeling of tension, which is far closer to the actual fear you'd have if you were placed in a real life horror situation.
The 'story' (for lack of a better word) is great but hard to talk about without spoilers.
I also think the player character being a toddler works really well with the horror format, because playing as such a vunerable character makes the inherent vunerability of characters in horror games seem completely logical in this case.

I only wish it had been longer (I completed the game in a single sitting) however I want to stress that me wishing it was longer is actually more of an appreciation for a game and wishing I'd got to spend more time with it, rather than a legitimate critism.
That said it's worth considering whether you personally would be happy with roughly 2.5 hours of gameplay for the listed price, I really can't speak objectively on that front because I brought it during a 75% off sale and so am personally quite happy with what I got for the price I paid.

43475476.review:
This game is a short, atmospheric, horror adventure in which you play as a toddler trying to find his mother, along with his appropriately named stuffed bear, [i]Teddy[/i]. It is riddled with subtle clues to the toddler's situation, some foreshadowing, as well as puzzles throughout, all revealing the true meaning behind the shadows and creepy environment you are going through, and often hiding in.

The game does a great job of creating the atmosphere through music, noises, lighting and just overall great environmental effects. The music especially does a great job at creating tension; the game also does a great job at building tension by making normally comforting objects into something eerie.  

I personally loved the concept and the execution as a whole. I enjoyed the environment and the art work a great deal. There were a lot of small well thought out details put into the game which were very charming. (also the museum is a great added feature to be able to see concept art and directions the story never followed.) 

[spoiler]The message behind the game is one that is not always talked about often. It was a unique way to portray how a broken family life (a troubled mother) could be impacting even a toddler in severe ways.[/spoiler]

43258637.review: I'd say it's a bit more first person exploration than outright horror, but that's more to my liking anyway. This game was short, but well done.

43254408.review:
This is as short jaunt in the footed pajamas of a two year old, exploring the wardrobe of their greatest fears. It's a story of a broken family, a kid who is too young to understand, and a freaking creepy teddy bear. Among the Sleep is written very well, and the voice actor for Teddy is comforting and unsettling at the same time. How he managed that, I can't even hazard a guess. 

The plot is fairly predictable, but it's about the journey. This is more of a horror themed walking simulator (i.e., Layers of Fear) rather than a strictly horror game. You can "die," but it's quite easy to get through without ever having failed at your tasks. This is NOT an action adventure game. It's essential that you take your time, explore, enjoy the art and the perspective of being a terrified 2 year old, so that you will find all the beauty and depth that lies in the game. The level designs are fantastic, surrealistic, and appropriate for the mind of a toddler. I loved how many things look like feet or people out of the corner of one's eye. 

I got this game in a bundle, so I can't say if it's worth the full price or not. It's only 3-5 hours long or so, but they are a very good handful of hours. I'd highly recommend this at $10 or under. If you are already familiar with, and comfortable with "walking simulators," then you can't really go wrong at full price either.

41668277.review:
This game has had an incredible amount of hype for it's music, it's premise, it's story, and it's graphics. And as someone going into this looking to be blown away after seeing a few LPs of the intro and trailers on youtube I can tell you it falls short. It falls short of the promises it gives of scares and gameplay and I'm bitterly disappointed.

Cons:
-It is way too short. If I were a better gamer with better reaction times and better spacial reasoning I would have completed it in under 2 hours. For such a powerhouse of promises I'd expect at least in the 4 hour mark for the amount this game cost. 
-There is very little hinting in the way of the ending and it feels like it comes out of nowhere.
-The obstacles aren't very challenging as a puzzle game and mostly little physics things that anyone could figure out.
-As a horror game it's mostly jump scares or distant glimpses that are often missed and you have to rely on a sound cue to know they even happened (this occured 4 times).
-The whole of the game is really linear with very little diversion from the beaten path.
-As a stealth game there's very little threat as they disappear after they do their patrol over whatever trigger caused them to spawn. 
-There are instances that break the immersion that happened frequently where I would climb and the model would clip through the environment and I'd see through the world.
-There are collectables...I'm sorry this is just a personal issue but I really don't think collectables have a place in horror. If your game is truly frightening then it's not worth hanging around to look for extras once you clear a room. It's just confirmation from the creators that they also don't think the sense of dread I should get from this game is present.

Pros: 
- The music and sound design overall is one of the few pieces that are hype worthy.
- If you like jump-scares and spooky noises this is your jam.

41532834.review:
In this game you play as a mentally deficient two year old as he searches for his lost doodles. Throughout the game, due to your mental handicap, you will struggle to open drawers and climb basic objects owing to what must be a previous injury to your head. The developers cleverly made this brain injury a reality for you, the player, through frustratingly unresponsive controls. As you find your doodles, you will be chased by[spoiler]your parents as they attempt to stop you from receiving a second brain injury as you climb shelves and countertops that are dangerously high for anyone under the age of four. As the game progresses, you learn that your selfish desire for your lost doodles has driven your mother to drink herself into a stupor as you wander off into a bright light that claims to be your father. So I guess that makes you Jesus.[/spoiler]

Short and sweet game with a nice story that touches subjects you won't find in other games. It has some good atmosphere and you can tell care and thought was put into its setting.  The controls are awful, even considering the player character is a two year old. If you want to get every achievement, collecting all the collectables is a fucking chore and only serves as busy work after you have wrapped up the story proper. [b]Since there is no "meh" or "wait until it is on sale" option. I'm not going to recommend this game at full price. Wait until it is cheap, pick it up, play the story and appreciate it for what it is then worry about getting all the achievements if you have a strong sense of self-loathing like I do.[/b]

39908673.review:
[h1] Let’s review: Among the Sleep          [/h1]

You are a child, no weapons, no magic, just a little child, and here you must go thru the most darkest of places with only your trusted guardian Teddy, run and hide in this beautiful game that dwelves in the mind of a kid and lets you see the normal things for adults from his perspective. Search for important items and memories to find your mother, but let the monsters catch you!

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

- Horror/Adventure type game, where you must search and solve riddles to escape or collect the item you need.
- The Teddy bear, your guardian serves as close friend and narrator in this game.
- Although no true explanation is given straight away, the game tells you what happened along the way, making you want to know more and more.

[h1] Cons: [/h1]

- Basic controls, from moving and grabbing, but you are a kid!
- The monsters in the game, felt oversimplified, having little presence in the game.
- If you took away the storyline, this would be just running from A to B with little or no challenge. 

[h1] Final Review [/h1]

Among the Sleep, is a step in the right direction, even thou I liked the storyline and whole concept, it felt underused, with so much underlining potential. It certainly stands out in the Horror/Adventure concept genre, I can only give this game a 6 out of 10, making it a recommendation especially if it’s on sale.

39835739.review:
TL;DR

A great concept mired in dull spatial puzzles and lack lustre visual FX. This may be regarded as an "indie" game, but personally I think the number of staff involved in the project, should've yielded a more polished experience. I would've recommended this title had the developers focused on EITHER polishing the gameplay OR the games aesthetics.

///

*** SPOILERS CONTAINED IN REVIEW *** 

Among the Sleep has an interesting concept; a child loses their mother and goes on a quest to find them. The main technique used to convey said child's perspective is very simple, move the camera closer to the ground. The aforementioned technique does successfully make the player feel small in the world, which somewhat adds to the tension. On the other hand, the mechanics used in representing "child-like" movement certainly misses the mark. Yes, the idea of crawling along the ground (giving the player faster movement) is somewhat effective - in combination with the ability to sprint, which should the player do so for too long, ends in a tumble - but personally I think the movement is lacking and frustrating. I should WANT to explore the world around me, not be thinking "FFS this is a chore".

The game's conflict / puzzles consist of interacting with objects in the game world. Again, this should not feel tedious and inconsistent. If you plan to have the player manipulate objects in the environment there are some design elements that you need to consider.

Firstly, don't include a Rotate Object input / function unless you use this effectively in the solution of your puzzles. I never used said feature in the game, but did find the need for the ability to "Push" and "Pull" an object towards me, for better environment navigation.

Secondly, have the objects placement / speed match that of the player camera manipulation. Unforutnately, there were numerous scenarios where I found myself losing control of the object I was trying to interact with. You may say that this is the result of trying to model a child's lack of motor skills with objects, but that feels like a cop out for an unfinished mechanic. If you "wanted" the player to struggle with objects, thus increasing the tension of interacting with an object, then have more breakable / perishing objects that should the player fail their interactions, they have to "restart" the puzzle / interaction.

As far as the game's narrative tone and sense of conflict goes, quite frankly I don't think there is any. If you proceed along the linear environment's series of "fetch quests" without exploring, then the ham fisted reveal of the mother being an alcoholic may feel satisfying and provide some explanation for the events transpiring around you. Personally, I explored the kitchen environment (Chapter 1) and immediately found an abundance of bottles, leading me to think "the family has an alcoholic in it, great! How creative."

The game's aesthetics also leave a lot to be desired. The majority of players around the world have an abundance of graphical power, begging to be used. If this game were to be released in 2006-2010, then maybe I would be more forgiving, but unfortunately that's not the case. It's my understanding that the game was developed at a time when Allegorithmic had released Substance Painter / Designer, with very affordable and reasonable pricing for said software. Given the budget / funding that you had secured, use of a PBR workflow would've substainlly improved the game's aesthetic appeal.

All in all, I'm mostly disappointed in this interactive experience. I would rather not use the term game when describing Among the Sleep, as it simply doesn't include enough variety and conflict to earn said moniker. Alternatively, I would've loved to have been taken on a linear experience, that was a feast for my eyes and made me feel scared. Unfortunately, the developers dabbled in both and came up short.

2 out of 5.

39736629.review:
[h1]Toddler-hood is Creepy as Heck![/h1]

This game's been out a while, but with the enhanced edition, it's worth getting a second look. Or a first look, as the case may be.

Contrary to common categorization, [i]Among the Sleep[/i] is NOT a walking sim! It's a toddling sim. Because you're a toddler.

The primo question: Is it horror? Yes. Not like [i]Saw[/i] or [i]Friday the 13th[/i]. The developers' overarching goal was to generate an atmosphere where the player could legitmately experience fear from the perspective of a 2-year-old. So they tweaked the environment enough to make everyday things become jarring. And, in some cases, not-so-everyday.

Question numero dos: Is it survivor horror? Sorta. Chapter 3 and the Prologue (you're gonna play the prologue as an epilogue when everything else is done because...reasons) have a mysterious figure chasing you. It's reminiscent of that one chapter in [i]The Vanishing of Ethan Carter[/i]. Challenging? Meh. Scary? Oh yeah!

Question the third: Is it worth it? Yep! The game has flaws, no equivocation there, but the ending will touch your heart. You'll feel humbled, wiser, and/or righteously indignant and you may even wonder if anyone's thought to use the game as treatment for a certain type of therapy.

[u]Pros[/u]
-No Fall Damage
-Alternate pajama options if you soil yourself

[u]Cons[/u]
-Clunky interaction with props
-May generate disconcerting flashbacks of wearing diapers

39734904.review:
[h1]Note: Recommended at discounted price[/h1]
HAPPY: People who want to be immersed in a surreal sensory experience from the perspective of a child coping with some serious sleep disturbance. 
DISAPPOINTED: People expecting serious puzzles or horror game mechanics. People expecting a cerebral plot or uncanny twist ending. People looking for replay value or a bug-free experience. People with low-end systems unable to render at max settings.

Here's a mediocre story that follows a predictable arc. The plot leans heavily on the protagonist being an unreliable observer. However, just because we know where the roller coaster stops doesn't mean the ride can't be exciting. By the end, there are enough unanswered questions left to at least spark the imagination in days to follow a play through.

The art and sound work is fabulous. Attention to detail makes the game immersive, and the environments are all uniquely surreal in a way that recalls American McGee's Alice games. The tactile feel of the gameplay, however, is clunky and lackluster. The physics get wonky, the toddler parkour isn't reliable, the AI and directing for event triggers are very rough. Recently became ENHANCED EDITION and looks gorgeous, which is a welcome bit of value from the devs. 

TL;DR: it's a tasty snack, but it's not nutritious. It goes cheap, so get it.

38564638.review:
See my attempt [url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLJ7TY-n4OKVQuQCKmiV8p1lgvxCuuQB6q]here[/url]
TL:DR:  Good game with flaws that sadly ruined my playthrough.  Checkpoints too few and far between, bugs that broke the game.  Recommend if you can acutally get it to work.

Now then.  It started out well-adorable kid has a nice birthday with mommy, plays with a mildly disturbing talking teddy-nice way to do the tutorial, by the way-goes to bed with ONE BITE of cake!  NOOOO!!!!  Cue it was a dark and stormy night, and we're on our way.  The on-edge creepy feeling of being a 2 today year old during a thunderstorm was very nicely done.  I loved the "monster", which I only saw a few times, but it was charmingly child creepy.  I loved the setting-your house but with a dark and scary twist, and some nice impossible architecture.  I adored the magic paitings.  Sound was used very well, and the storm!  I LOVE when a game has good storm effects!  I got about 3/4 of the way through-yes i got stuck, hence my long playtime-and then it just fell apart.  At the very end of the closet level, it just bugs out for me.  I could not get past the trench coat man, no matter what I tried.  It was a disappointing failure in an otherwise enjoyable game.  So, I never got to finish it.  That was the good.  Now the bad.  

Lack of controller support put me off immedaiately.  My hands don't do so well with keyboard controls; they feel unnatural and uncomfortable to me.  Many times I curse the fact that crawl is Crtl, which is right next to the Windows key, and therefore had me hitting it by mistake at the worst times.  There were some notable graphical fails, which had me falling through the floor of the world.  It was too dark, and I had to blast gamma to see anything at some points.  And finally, the checkpoints are too far between.  It was good, could have been great, if not for these issues and the fact I couldn't finish the game.

I highly recommend it for the gameplay and the update to the game, plus that free dlc included.

38038382.review:
[b]Before playing Among the Sleep : have an irrational fear of whatever could be under your bed. After playing Among the Sleep : hide under your bed and have an irrational fear of whatever could be everywhere else.[/b]

After a long inner conflict (I'm not the horror type : too easily frightened) I decided to play Among the Sleep, a scary adventure in which you play as a 2 years old toddler. Despite the fear, I was grabbed by the story and the concept, both making me stay until the end of the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1210927668

There aren't any combats, just exploration and puzzle solving ; however, the world through children's eyes is a frightening place. What a heavy atmosphere : the darkness, the shadows, the monsters, the soundtrack, the closing doors, the falling or moving objects, the creaky floor, etc. - everything is set up to create an intense ambience. I couldn't play more than a chapter at the time and had to play Hello Kitty Online afterwards to release the pressure.

Joke aside, Among the Sleep is without a doubt an innovative and memorable experience that I'll recommend for its story, its imaginative concept, the serious topic, the impact, the strange, the horror and the anxiety. Horror fans be warned : this game might not be spooky and / or challenging enough for you ; better get the game on sales or in a bundle.

I just regret the fact that you can't save whenever you want, because even if the progression is automatically saved at some checkpoints, loading the game made me come back to obsolete previous checkpoints several times, so I felt forced to finish the chapter every time to make sure the progression would be correctly saved.

This is a terrific and very unique game. 

I purchased it when it first came out a couple of years ago and thoroughly enjoyed it. 

When I saw that there was an enchanced version available, I had to give it a go. 

However, about 30 minutes in I failed to see what enchancements had been made. The mother still looks like an extra from the movie Antz and the overall look and feel of the game seemed unchanged to me. 

I still highly recommend the game to anyone who hasn't already had the pleasure of playing it but, if you own or have played the original version I can't reccomend the purchase of this "Enchanced Edition" as I truly couldn't tell the difference.

37853951.review: A short (3-4 hour) but intense experience. A perfect blend of the whimsical and horrific. It really captures the feeling of being a toddler in a giant and confusing world, and has one of the best endings I've seen from not just video games, but books and movies as well.

37820097.review:
This is one of those games you endure rather than necessarily enjoying, and you come out perhaps braver and stronger, perhaps just scarred for life with memories that might haunt you forever...

What's the word, Horror. This does that. 

The first minutes are creepy as hell. It crawls along through the darkness from there, with twists and surprises, depositing you in a place where human spirit triumphed but innocence is lost.

It's clunky as hell sometimes, like trying to locomote as a baby I mean that ain't easy, the default controls are perhaps deliberately wonky and the completely SPOILERS "Museum" and "Prologue" seem to be unlocked from the start, though they should only be examined after the main campaign has been given what-ho.

Recently Remastered with a few tweaks, it's not been polished to Masterpiece level but it's one of those games, like Another World, that can be unforgettable to the right players. Recommended to the strange

37729543.review:

However, I found the actual gamepaly to be quite repetative which made be think ithat some areas could have been cut if there was no budget to make them better... I dont mind if a game short (even if it is really short) as long as it is consistently awsome.

Перевод:

Данная игра, представлена как симулятор ребенка, который переносит тебя в мир совсем юного мальчика. Вместе с медведем Тедди ребенок пытаеться , побороть кошмар, и спасти собственную мать. Игра представлена достаточно увлекательно, нам предстоит собрать предметы, которые переносят нас, в разные промежутки памяти. То как это происходит очень интересно, тебе предстоит сначала собрать некие реликвии, из жизни мальчика, после этого возвращаться в домик, с помощью воздушной системы труб в доме. С помощью предметов собранных тобой нужно перемещаться между локациями, которые могут чаровать своей красотой. Но не все так просто тебе предстоит свершить два главных квеста, а именно избегать внимания злой мамочки монстра  и спасти настоящую мамочку.
 •	Понравился мишка фонарик
 •	Игра слишком короткая чем не доволен хотелось бы продолжения.

36284485.review:
I was given this game as a gift, or received it from backing the Kickstarter -I can't remember which. In any case I certainly don't deny having been predisposed to like it, but I should note that it goes some deeply intense places, and yes, I'm going to use the term "trigger warning." The plot is not only likely to *literally* trigger freaking out (I jumped a lot, which is to be expected and probably desired in such a game), but child abuse and neglect and childhood alcoholism are major themes.

That said, it's *really* well done. I had enormous trouble with adventure games as a kid, and yet this has a lot of point-and-click (in 3d) puzzles that fit the themathics and imagery of the game. Highly recommended,

36172660.review: Although this game presents a very original idea, and the story (from what I have seen) is interesting and immersive to a wide variety of players. This title has one very crippiling flaw, the absolutely game breaking lag. I have tried everything to get this game to run properly but it's futile, this game simply just isn't compatable with most modern rigs, even rigs with teir 1 graphics capabilities. I have tried everything I can to troubleshoot compatability with this title, but it simply seems that Krillbite failed to take new OS and graphics processors into account when developing this amazingly unique game. Hopefully, a future patch will fix the problems associated with running this application but again that hope seems futile as many players have been encountering this issue since the game's release in 2014. If you do want to play this game, I would strongly advise you to purchase it on consoles as you will have a less likely chance of encountering this game breaking glitch.

36154837.review:
Among the Sleep is a childhood nightmare "walking simulator." Akin to "A Machine for Pigs," Among the Sleep has some excellent ambience, and decent puzzles to solve. This is by no means a "bad" game, but if you're expecting some thrilling and terrifying horror...you should look elsewhere. The "monster" doesn't even appear until the second half of the game, and  considering I was able to play through the game in about 3 hours, bumbling all the way (had the gamma bit lower than I should have) you might be able to do it even faster, blind.

If you're looking for a short but sweet game that's creepy but not too scary, then this game is perfect for you!
But if you're looking for true horror, best to leave this one.

I really enjoyed Among the sleep. It's a good horror game. It wasn't the scariest game I've ever played, but it scared me. I liked the way the story was told.

The puzzles are not that hard which was kind of a bummer, could have made the gametime a bit longer without having to push the story to long.
