I got the game on a sale, so I didn't pay full price. I'm satisfied with my purchase.

35472684.review:
This one was a different experience, and a rather impacting ending.

This is a short game, way shorter if you are bolder, where you control a baby and sees the world with your own eyes and imagination, every now and then haunted by a screeching shadow entity. Guided by your Teddy Bear, which felt creepy all the way long, you find drawings that are clues about what the heck is happening, and most of the time, at least for me, you are creeping here and there avoiding the shadow menace, whilst going about creepy places, holding your creepy bear, listening to creepy noises until the very ending.

I would recommend the game only on sale, because it's very short and there's no replay quality about it, unless you have to make achievements or something like that. But the game has an interesting turn of events in the end, which felt different, and makes one think about our daily prejudices, society.

35176385.review:
This was gifted to me by a Twitch viewer and played 'for the lulz'.

I don't normally play horror/jump scare games. They generally don't sit well with me. It's simply not why I play games. That being said, people seem to enjoy watching other people play scary games. Sigh.

Nevertheless, I enjoyed this game. While I never would've purchased it on my own to play it, it was worth the experience. The atmosphere and 'story' was intriguing enough to see me through to the end despite not being a fan of the genre. The perspective of playing as a small child feels clunky as far as actual mechanics goes, but succeeds in what I think they were trying to accomplish. While the 'jumpscares' were no more or less original than any other game in the genre, if you're looking to buy a horror game you're probably expecting that anyway.

Finally, while some reviews claim the story to be 'unoriginal' or 'predictable', I still feel it is told well enough to warrant a playthrough. Just wait for a sale if you're unsure.

The Bear, seemingly the beacon of hope in a horrific world was giving me the wrong feeling from the start and I was constantly expecting him to become the malicious thing he immediately seemed to me from how he is introduced and how he seemingly drags you into the horrid world. Do yourself a favour, don't buy this game, do not waste your time or money. Play Lumber Island instead, it is atmospheric with some good scares and very entertaining gameplay as well as better 'puzzles' than this tripe. 35046066.review:
Pretty neat game. The atmosphere is really good, because the level design is great and you're in fact playing a 2 years old child, crawling through a house at night that makes coats in a closet look like huge scary monsters. Sadly it's never more than "neat". There's a monster in this game, trying to catch you, but it's extremely easy to avoid, not scary at all and really just ridiculous to look at. Getting caught has literally no impact except for a 10 second "game over" screen, then you'll start at the same point again. This is NOT a horror game, it really isn't. But the way Among the Sleep uses its level design makes for an interesting approach to story telling.

Just don't expect an especially creative story or challenging gameplay. The puzzles are ridiculously easy, maybe not even worth being called puzzles. It's more of a walking simulator, to be honest, with extremely bland linear gameplay. Don't play this if you're not a fan of atmospheric games, you'll be bored endlessly.

34580336.review:
Judged solely from a gameplay perspective, Among the Sleep isn’t especially remarkable: a first-person survival horror game with simple puzzle-solving elements (even making use of a similar mouse-click interface found in Frictional titles) and somewhat simplistic monster chases. Where this quirky game really excels is the execution of its unique storyline.

You’re placed in the teeny shoes of a two-year-old toddler who must search for his mother after being thrust into a series of vivid dreamscapes that all encompass some warped vision of childhood memories and fears. Everything in the world seems massive and imposing - even the coats found hanging in wardrobes bear a resemblance to domineering adults in the eyes of a frightened and confused child. This exaggerated verticality isn’t something you’ll likely consciously notice at first, but it’s a subtly effective way of making the world feel hostile and unfamiliar. The Unity-powered visuals won’t win any awards for technical prowess, but the art and sound design do an excellent job at building the atmosphere.

But while the level design does a decent job at establishing the atmosphere, it does a much poorer job of giving it any significant payoff. There are only a handful of monster encounters in the course of the story, and it’s unlikely you’ll find them particularly scary if you’ve played any survival horror games before. Their behaviour is so heavily scripted and lacking in challenge that most people will find sneaking past them to be a cakewalk (In my case, I didn’t end up dying once). There is an argument to be had that making a horror game too difficult can result in something more frustrating than scary. At the same time though, when there’s no tangible threat to the player during these moments, it’s hard for me to really take the monster chases seriously - particularly when I once ran the wrong way and was able to walk right past one without it seeming to notice.

The story however, is something I haven’t seen done before in a video game - [spoiler]the portrayal of an abusive relationship as seen through the eyes of a young child. You eventually learn that the environments aren’t merely spooky dreamscapes, but represent the fears and anxieties of this small lad’s mind as he struggles to comprehend the emotional torment going on around him[/spoiler]. Among the Sleep pulls this off surprisingly well without having to resort to explicit images or gratuitous violence - instead, we’re able to understand this childhood fear through symbolism and subtle environmental cues. It’s a shame that the conclusion feels rather abrupt and ends on a slightly rushed note, but the game’s short three-hour length at least means that the story never feels padded or overstretched.

Taken as a whole, Among the Sleep is a somewhat variable survival horror experience - it’s gameplay, while intuitive enough, doesn’t really do enough to connect the player the the narrative itself, which I suspect might lead some people to label the game as little more than a walking simulator. Despite this, the story Krillbite has conjured up, while not always coherent, is unique and interesting.

[b]TL:DR: If you’re looking for a substantial gameplay experience, then you might be better off with one of Among the Sleep’s many horror contemporaries. If you’re looking for something a little special, then this is still worth picking up on the cheap.[/b]

This was an atmospheric game that is well worth playing. I had a few frustrations with the controls and the saving system, I played on a gaming laptop, with just a touchpad and no mouse. Mostly, the controls were okay, but there were a few places where you have to wind things and it took me a while to work out how to do that on my touchpad (for anyone else having the same trouble: hold down the left touchpad button and then draw circles on the touchpad, rather than the more expected swiping in the direction you want to wind). There were also a couple of times where I needed to throw items, but there was no linked key. I had to come out of the game and edit the controls before I could throw anything.

I was also confused by the saves. Every time I picked up a drawing, it said my game was saving. And if I died, I seemed to go back to set check-points. But if I exited the game part way through a chapter, I didn't re-enter either at my most recently collected drawing or at somewhere that had been a check-point after dying. Instead, I seemed to wind up back at the start of a chapter, which was a bit frustrating. As others have mentioned, this would probably have been best played in a single gaming session, but I had to play in relatively short bursts as there are lots of swaying movements and flickering lights and it did make me feel rather nauseated at times!

However, the game itself looks amazing and is genuinely creepy at times. You quickly learn to make yourself inconspicious but I may have spent rather more time hiding under bookcases than I strictly needed to. I would have been disapppointed with the amount of game that's here if I'd paid full price, but I picked it up for less than £4 and would recommend this game highly for that.

33810425.review:
Adorably spooky [h1]Among the Sleep[/h1] provides a fascinating perspective into an adventure/puzzle game, by incorporating a toddler as the main character.

A child-like imagination is a wonderful thing. There is a big, colorful, full of surprises yet at the same time scary and all-consuming world for a young mind to explore for the first time and the game conveys that feeling in a superb way. Among the Sleep has very little dialogue but manages to create a wonderfully frightening setting for you to play through.

You play as toddler and as you'd expect you'll find no shotguns or laser weapons to defend yourself. Just good old fashioned running and hiding. The world around you is big and scary as it would probably seem to a defenseless child without his parents and yet upon closer inspection you'll realize that appearances can be deceiving as nicely presented in the first moments of the game which will set the tone for what's to come.

From a gameplay perspective the game offers a short 2-3 hour run (including the free 'Prologue' DLC) but has a really nice and open to interpretation story to tell which I will not spoil here. The main focus of the gameplay is basic puzzle solving which range from easy to extremely easy. There's nothing really challenging here which in the context of the game feels like a natural expectation. In fact the hardest thing for me for the entirety of the game were the really awkward controls and handling of the main character, but again you'd not expect a toddler to be able to run and jump like a ninja so even here it fits within the theme of the game.

You are also accompanied by your talking teddy bear which will assist you through your journey. There were a few great moments between the toddler and teddy which make for more character development than I've seen in AAA titles with 10 times the gameplay duration.

Graphically the game is not something I'd praise; nonetheless it succeeds with the simplicity of the Unity engine to create a very fitting atmosphere to get lost into. Ambient sounds and music merge well with the gameplay and what little voice acting is there, is excellently done. I'll truly say that there are several moments in the game where you will feel scared and alone and that's something that is the result of the excellent work the developers did by intertwining several simplistic concepts.

Despite its short duration, lack of replayability (besides getting the collectibles) and how easy it is, Among the Sleep has charisma in its presentation and a fascinating albeit polarizing story for the player to interpret. A solid recommendation if you want to experience a couple of hours of a nicely made adventure/puzzle game.

33526781.review:
[h1][url=store.steampowered.com/app/250620/Among_the_Sleep/]Among the Sleep[/url] presents the unusual perspective of a toddler's fears and impressionable sentiments in the wake of abusive relationships.[/h1]

Muffled conversations between vaguely defined characters reveal early on that all is not well in this household. Soon you'll be on your own to explore a distorted version of this toddler's house and dream world, armed with your new Teddy as sole companion.

The developers obviously have no idea how a 2-year-old sounds like (hint: it's not a baby anymore) and they repeatedly make small realism mistakes that might briefly irk real parents, but controlling such a young character is decidedly refreshing and well done for the most part.

They added some nice touches, such as the inevitable stumbles when running for any length of time, or hugging Teddy for some comfort with the added benefit of producing enough light to partially see in the dark.

Moving chairs to reach higher places normally not accessible to a young child introduce simple puzzles, though interactions could have used more variety as a whole. These physics-based challenges would be infinitely complex for a toddler but are very simple for an adult, so breezing through the game is done with relative ease.

The game is only scary if you let it be. Your decidedly creepy talking Teddy keeps saying we should be quiet but there's absolutely no danger until the latter half of the game, when your toddler finally comes face to face with his nightmare in screeching distortion and static. A lot of tension rises from that moment, when you must rapidly crawl to safety under a table or bed to escape the hazy creature unseen.

Unfortunately, that tension soon dissipates once you realize your character always easily awakens a few meters away when caught, with any danger gone. It only temporarily halts gameplay and diminishes the fun in crawling to safety just in time to hide.

Collect memories as main story progression and optionally drawings for extra achievements. Beware that the game does not track progress of such collectibles, if you are into that sort of thing, nor do they add any value to the story or gameplay.

Progress does not save at all mid-chapter either, despite a very obvious mention of the game being saved at different checkpoints. The game does not inform you that progress will be lost when quitting.

[h1]Positive[/h1]
[list]
[*] Beautiful yet simple environments
[*] Original premise and player character
[*] Tribute to Home Alone in the basement furnace
[*] Free additional Prologue DLC reveals more of the story and feels like a much more refined use of all the game's mechanics rolled into one cohesive package
[/list]

[h1]Negative[/h1]
[list]
[*] Overly sensitive default controls difficult to tweak comfortably
[*] Needless inventory system could have been entirely removed (any object only ever has a single and obvious use)
[*] Completely useless peeking mechanic (decidedly a missed opportunity)
[*] Erratic movement makes reaching certain seemingly easy areas a little awkward
[*] Audio tries too hard with its relentless Halloween mixtape and uneven SFX quality
[*] Frequently stuttering framerate
[*] No save mid-chapter
[/list]

Overall, Among the Sleep is a sympathetic little game with enough good qualities to recommend despite a large amount of noticeable imperfections.

32999126.review:
At first, I thought the teddy bear would be the villain. That would be too easy because he is smaller than you, a two-year-old toddler. You could quickly tear his limbs off. Instead, you befriend him and make him glow like a lantern when hugged. Other mechanics include running, crawling, climbing, throwing items and moving furniture around so you can access door handles. Other than that it is a pure walking simulator. However, it's not a walk in a park. There are enemies and you can die or kill yourself by drowning, falling down a hole. The game takes place partly in a haunted house but mainly in places formed by your imagination where you encounter monsters, solve puzzles and have a goal to collect memories of the times spent with your mother, so that you can reunite with her and escape your twisted toddler mind. The plot gives you hints here and there as to what's going on and you can figure the point (which is quite sad) before the ending but for the most of the time, the game stays very mysterious which helps build the atmosphere. You will indeed be scared of every strange noise and shadow, just like a small child. Now, technically the game is splendid but I encountered several crashes and graphical artefacts but that is because my HW is as old as the hills. I got stuck in the environment several times, sometimes requiring a restart from checkpoint.

7/10

+ atmospheric, imaginative
- short, buggy collision system, the mother is pretty basic (the graphical model)

32189589.review:
This is a tough one to put into the binary of "yes/no" recommendations. It is put together really well. The challenges and obstacles  in your way are thoughtful and excellently designed to get you interacting with the world. I was never frustrated or confused. The level design is masterful in that sense. You are propelled further into this well crafted world where every object has meaning. Krillbite have put a lot of love and care into this experience. 

However, while the concept works on paper, I found Among the Sleep to be a little lacking in its narrative punch. My conclusion is that it is hamstrung by the protagonist being a toddler. Krillbite do a great job of bringing to life the world through a child's eyes. All manner of everyday objects loom large and will make you double take as you see monsters in coatracks and end tables with cloth draped over them. But you're also limited to having exposition be given by your teddy bear companion. You cannot read or talk. At times it feels as though you are being very forcibly spoon-fed the narrative, and it comes off a bit clunky. The concept works as both a fantastic creative constraint, but also a difficult barrier to overcome. 

I'm a great fan of suspense, interactive storytelling, and adventure. Maybe it's unfair to compare this to Frictional Games' Amnesia series and its successor SOMA - but that's precisely where this game sits. The same interaction methods, the same obstacle, narrative, obstacle, narrative beat - the same horror/suspense theming. Among the Sleep's contemporaries have hit some pretty high notes. They explore deep philosophical questions in great detail. Among the Sleep's message, which I won't spoil here, just didn't land with the same weight. 

I don't regret my time with Among the Sleep, but I can't recommend it over other, similar titles. If you haven't played SOMA, it'll knock your socks off. If you have and you loved it, this just won't reach the same level.

This game puts you in the perspective of a 2 year old child...think the old cartoon rugrats. The imagination and creativity of a 2 year old takes scenarios and situations and blows them way out of reality. The scares of this game are sure to give you goosebumps. Best played in a cool dark room with good headphones.

The game starts off with your 2nd birthday and your with your mother and father being separated, she seems to have custody of you and things are a little too much for her to handle so she copes by drinking a lot. With all the hallucinations  it's likely she was kind enough to share....she probably spiked the juice... You have a stuffed animal who can speak to you and help guide you. Creepy lil teddy bear. The perspective of a child wondering a house seen through the eyes and imagination of the 2 year old. To a 2 year, old parents can be seen as monsters to avoid during rough times.  This title was very spooky at times, and often terrifying. This is a great title and I give it a definite recommend.

31741665.review:
This game is dark. And I don't mean the subject matter (which is dark, sure, but not really that important). It's impossible to see where you are going. You have a source of light, but it doesn't really illuminate anything to be useful, and it blocks your vision if you're looking down, which is incredibly frustrating, considering so much of the game is trying to figure out which places are safe to walk. My playthrough was filled with falling down holes that I couldn't see because I couldn't look down or see where I was going.

There are several interesting mechanics. For example, the crawling/walking mechanic could have been neat, but crawling's basically useless, considering you'll need the little light you have to avoid being completely blind, which is another way the darkness of the game ruins something.

I can't really say anything about the level design. Everything felt randomly strewn together but that's because, again, the game is too dark to really get a good feel for the layout of the levels.

There were some nice design decisions. I liked the idea of the house/forest area. If only I could have seen more to fully appreciate it.

31545855.review:
So far I am really not a fan of this game at all.

It is often too dark and I can't see anything, even with brightness way up. I got stuck near the beginning [spoiler]Where I was supposed to extract the teddy from the washer[/spoiler] for like 15 minutes as I somehow missed the icon that said I could open it, and everything else was so dark I thought I had been missing something elsewhere. It is obviously trying to do the "follow the light" thing, which is "proper game design", but they don't do it very well. In the "first level", I had a lot of trouble finding one of the specific [same] items I needed to continue as it was down a "path" that just looked like most of the rest of the empty wooded area.

The novelty of playing as a baby is, while a neat idea, ultimately just another gimmick. It did not add to the atmosphere or "fear" factor at all for me. If they had made a rift version, I might have changed my mind on that, but as they said, it doesn't fit the game movement style.

Ultimately, it's really just a walking simulator with a few intractable objects. No puzzles, or mini games, or even scavenger hunts (which makes something like Gone Home stand out). No thought. Just "look for something that might be a path and see if it has a thing you need". I really felt (and would bet some money) that this was made by game dev students at a college, in which they were told "this is the right way to do a game", and they just tried to follow the standard formulas.

I'll update this when I finish the game (doing a run for achievements so it doesn't negatively add to my game completion rate) but I don't expect it to get any better.

31307965.review:
This is a first-person survival horror game from the perspective of a two-year old toddler. It's quite short (2.5-5 hours) and relatively easy.

If you liked Ammesia: The Dark Descent, you will like this disturbing game.

It provides a very intense, dark atmosphere with relative simple, but nice graphics and great music. Playing as a 2-year old brings a unique touch to the game both in the way you move as well as how you can interact with the environment.

The only downsides are the clunky controls and some glitches in the graphics, the physics and the sound. In addition, the save points are too far away (while the respawn points are okay). So dying is not a problem, but if you plan to play this game in more than one session, I recommend stopping a session right after you've reached a new chapter.

Play this game for experiencing the atmosphere. Don't play it as a challenge or to beat it.

31213309.review:
I loved the concept of Among the Sleep.  How many games have you play through the eyes of a toddler? This is certainly the only one I am aware of.  I can give bonus points for originality here and in a horror title no less, which is no easy thing to do these days.  

Among the Sleep does a terrific job at immersing you into the world because of its engrossing atmosphere and ambiance. I will admit I was pretty spooked at certain points.  The mechanics are reminiscent of Frictional Games' Amnesia and Penumbra titles; you can interact with items in the world but there is zero puzzle solving that you will find in the aforementioned games.  It is more so a matter of finding and interacting with objects that help you progress through the game. 

You cannot fight the few enemies encountered, instead, you must avoid them at all costs and make your way past them.  This characteristic of horror games I have found is either absolutely loved or hated typically.  I personally enjoy it because it puts the player in a helpless state and gives you all the more reason to be scared.  This is, after all, the effect all horror games should invoke.  But there are those who are annoyed or frustrated by this and I can understand that.

Among the Sleep unfortunately suffers from a few issues however.  My biggest problem with it is the technical issues I have experienced.  The amount of stuttering I encountered was surprisingly bothersome.  Considering the very short length of the game (anywhere between 1 and 4 hours depending on your playstyle and if you are hunting for achievements), you would have expected it to be significantly more polished.  The stuttering and major fps drops are distracting and certainly take away from game's immersion.  I could have 150 fps for a moment then suddenly it drops just below 60 and it is awfully noticeable.  My rig also is running on an 6600k, gtx 980, and 16 gb of ram, way above the game's recommended requirements.

The last but smaller problem I had with the game is the save system.  Throughout each chapter, as you play, the game will notify you that it's saving which is all well and good if you die because you will restart from your last save point.  Unfortunately though, if you quit a chapter mid game, you will have to start that chapter from the very beginning.  Not a huge deal given its short length but misleading because when you see the game autosaving, you assume you can just quit and return at the moment of the auto save, not the case here.

All this aside, Among the Sleep is a unique experience and is definitely worth adding to your library.  I would suggest waiting for a nice sale to pick it up though.

31164257.review:
¿Recordáis esos momentos de vuestra infancia en el que el mundo parecía enorme y caótico? ¿Cómo la realidad y la fantasía se desdibujaban en vuestra mente debido a vuestra temprana incapacidad de comprender lo que vivíais a vuestro alrededor? 

Es de eso de lo que trata [b]Among the Sleep[/b].

En este juego nos metemos en el pellejo de un niño de dos años que busca desesperadamente a su madre en una visión rocambolesca y macabra del mundo que le rodea. Siguiendo la estela de juegos como Amnesia o su precursor Penumbra, en Among the Sleep no podemos luchar ni defendernos de los (escasos) enemigos que pululan por el título, sino que sólo podremos huir o escondernos. La sensación de vulnerabilidad se ve aún más acentuada teniendo en cuenta que, al encarnar a un niño muy pequeño, todo nuestro entorno adquiere unas dimensiones colosales, resultando en que tareas tan sencillas como abrir una puerta o recoger un objeto de una estantería se convierten en una odisea. 

El juego pone toda la carne en el asador en su ambientación, digna del mejor Tim Burton, o de la macabra Alicia de American McGee. Nuestra madre ha desaparecido, y nuestro único compañero es un osito de peluche bastante desgastado y viejo, al que podemos abrazar para alumbrar el camino. Los escenarios saben aprovechar muy bien la perspectiva de un niño pequeño, convirtiendo entornos familiares y domésticos en territorios hostiles y apabullantes, y los inquietantes efectos de sonido ponen aún más de su parte para inyectarnos esa dosis de indefensión y vulnerabilidad que atribuimos a la edad del protagonista. Estos escenarios no tardan en mezclarse con entornos irreales y oníricos, donde la lógica se desvanece y la imaginación del niño los transforma en mundos de cuento oscuros donde sus mayores miedos cobran realidad. La perspectiva de un personaje infante se ve reforzada por detalles como que todos los textos del juego son un galimatías sin sentido (con 2 años todavía no sabemos leer), lo que ayuda a crear la atmósfera perfecta que este título requiere. Quizás en algunos momentos los escenarios se sienten repetitivos o desaprovechados, como que la premisa hubiese dado a una mayor explosión de creatividad visual. 

A nivel jugable estamos ante un título sencillo que no reporta un gran reto por lo general. La mayoría consiste en deambular por los escenarios en busca de objetos que recoger y puzzles bastante sencillos que resolver. No es hasta más o menos la mitad del título cuando nos toparemos con el primer y único monstruo que hay en todo el juego (sin contar el del DLC), el cual, pese a su sencillez y a sus mecánicas simplonas y predecibles, consigue arrancarnos muchos escalofríos en cada una de sus apariciones. Yo, en lo personal, lo pasé MUY mal, debido a que me trajo recuerdos traumáticos de mi infancia, donde mi padre tuvo la genial idea de aleccionarme a que me portara bien contándome con pelos y señales el cuento de la perversa Bruja Curuja, lo que provocó en mí un ciclo de pesadillas constantes en los que la susodicha me visitaba todas las noches y me hacía sufrir de lo lindo.

El título es bastante corto, y muchos encontrarán esta escasez de adversarios de los que huir un poco desalentadora para darle la oportunidad a este juego. Pero yo os animo a que le déis una oportunidad. No es hasta el final cuando toda la historia en su conjunto cobra sentido, más aún una vez superado el DLC gratuito [u]Prologue[/u].

SPOILERS DEL FINAL A CONTINUACIÓN.
[spoiler]A medida que avanzamos en la aventura descubrimos dos elementos que aumentan gradualmente su aparición: cajas de ropa y artículos varios, y botellas vacías. Hacia el final nos encontramos una fase que consiste enteramente en esquivar montones de cajas y de botellas, procurando no derribarlas para no hacer ruido y alertar a la malvada bruja sombría que nos acecha. Es entonces cuando tenemos nuestro último encuentro con mamá... y a medida que intentamos avanzar hacia ella, se aleja más y más de nosotros, dejando paso a la perversa bruja.

Despertamos en nuestra habitación, donde podemos oír el llanto de nuestra madre. Allí está, sentada en el suelo de la cocina, con una botella en la mano. Si intentamos recuperar el peluche que ella nos arrebató, nos responde con agresividad, y podemos entrever a la bruja. Nuestros pasos finales nos llevan hasta la puerta de la casa, donde el que intuimos que es nuestro padre nos recoge y nos consuela en un fondo blanco que resulta demasiado neutro para ser un final feliz.

No es hasta que jugamos y superamos el DLC cuando descubrimos la verdad sobre un matrimonio roto, erosionado por el maltrato y por causas que nuestra mente pueril no alcanza a comprender, que poco a poco altera el espacio en el que vivimos hasta hacerlo sofocante e insoportable. Nuestro último reducto de esperanza son nuestros muñecos, que por alguna razón están dispersos por la casa, y que sólo cobran vida cuando manipulamos ciertos objetos que representan aquello que arranca una sonrisa en nuestro niño. El último de ellos cae fuera, al jardín, y nos vemos obligados a seguirlo, en medio de una funesta tormenta de nieve. No podemos evitar sufrir por nuestro pobre protagonista mientras andamos torpemente hacia nuestro fetiche de felicidad... pero antes de poder cogerlo, nuestra madre nos agarra y nos sostiene en brazos, llorando desconsoladamente. "It's too much", son sus últimas palabras.

El juego se convierte entonces en algo más que un simple survival horror onírico. Es una representación de la realidad a través de los ojos de un niño, en este caso de una realidad demasiado terrible y demoledora para lo que una mente tan inocente es capaz de asimilar. En un mundo visto sin la lente de la lógica, son las emociones las que lo rigen, y éstas se retroalimentan de lo que tienen a su alrededor. El niño depende fuertemente de sus padres en sus primeros años de vida, y las emociones que éstos destilen en la casa serán los que el pequeño asimile. ¿Es acaso inesperado que, en un entorno tan duro y azotado por la tragedia como en el que este niño se está criando, el hogar se convierta en un lugar inhóspito y aterrador?[/spoiler]

Among the Sleep es una experiencia breve, pero muy contundente. La sensación de vulnerabilidad es constante, y el final no te deja indiferente. Quizás un poco más de extensión le hubiese sentado bien, pero en mi humilde opinión no necesita mucho más.

31111367.review:
Among the sleep is a great indie horror game about the life of an abused child living with a divorced single mom.

He goes on an adventure in many places in his closet with the help of his teddy bear, but throughout he is haunted and chased by a certain ghost, his entire adventure and journey is an allegory to his life with the torment and abuse he received from his single mother.

The game includes interesting puzzle-solving pieces, stealth sections, exploration, jumpscares, etc. The setting, execution and idea are all unique and great. The ending is very interesting, and the developer has released an FLC, so that's also an amazing plus.

+Great story
+Great visuals
+Good gameplay
-Somewhat questionable optimisation (probably due to a bug rather than actual performance)
-Apparently no MKB support but I could be mistaken, I can only play this with a gamepad.

I have an issue, I love horror...but I am scared poopless by them! Literally terrified...I do not know why I put myself through them. With this being said my review on a horror game may not be accurate representation for most seasoned horror gamers...

I found this game very good however, because you can not fight back. You are a helpless child who can barely walk...and you have to crawl if you wanna move fast. It is dark in most places with flickering lights, which helps generate a nice spooky atmosphere. The controls are fairly simple and easy to get used to, although you will find yourself getting stuck on things at times, and when you open doors that swing towards you it can get awkward as you accidently push it closed again if you are too close, which I am telling you just scares you even more when you are desperate to hide :D

Overally I would rate this game 7/10 for game play, and 9/10 for story...because it has a very sad climax, but really it is left to you to piece things together as you are a 2 year old after all!

Lovely addition of your imagiinery friend...thought the idea of using him as a light when you hug him was very good!

I would reccomend, although only on sale as it is (rightly) quite short...

Oh and there is a bonus chapter called the prologue...will update when I have finished that...not sure when I will be brave enough to do it though aha...

31084382.review:
I found this to be an OK game. Concept of being a toddler was new and interesting. The rest was mostly old news. The scare factor comes mostly from 2 things for most of the game: loud random bg noise, giving the impression you are not alone; and scripted jumpscares. While I thoroughly enjoyed the 1st factor, the 2nd one became boring really fast, to the point where I wouldn’t feel threatened at all. The addition of enemies (which felt mostly scripted too) solved that issue in a way, at least for me.

First off: SAVING MECHANICS LIE TO YOU. You see all those dandy “saving” notifications in the bottom right corner? Yes, they are saving checkpoints. For when you *die*. If you close the game mid chapter and reload, you’re forced to repeat the whole chapter. It isn’t fun, especially on longer chapters where you might want to take a break, and where the checkpoint system makes it look like you’ll be dropped where you left off.

Graphics were ok. Some strange clipping if you actually pay attention but nothing too major. You can use the demo to check them for yourself, I barely noticed a difference.

NPCs push you out of the way (which is awkward when the main NPC is so small). Detection for the “climb up” command is really awkward in the last chapter where you have to walk into slightly higher places, not tall enough to be climbable, but I was unable to simply walk towards the 5cm higher place and get on it. That whole chapter had weird collision to think of it. I couldn’t get under furniture that I could get under in previous chapters.

Sound was nice and scary. A bit overdone, sometimes?

There wasn’t much to the story but then again you’re a toddler, your life isn’t expected to be super complicated anyway. It made sense in the end, wasn’t terrible or anything, but also isn’t going to stick with me.

Overall it was interesting. Not one of my favourite games, probably won’t go back to it after getting the achievements. Would still recommend checking out.

30940233.review:
For me, the unique perspective of [i]Among the Sleep[/i] is what really makes it a great game.

The main distinction between a horror game and a creepy FPS is that the player tends to be mostly defenseless - they can only run and hide, hoping not to get dragged out from underneath the bed by whatever lurks in the dark. I can hardly think of a more vulnerable protagonist than a two-year old child, which makes this aspect incredibly strong here. If you have trouble even walking, trying to hide and run from a threat becomes almost unbearable.

The atmosphere is great, there are quite a few very scary moments, and I loved the minimalist story telling that says so much by telling so little.

On the negative side the game is sometimes very dark, so much so that some places are just pitch black and it's easy to get disoriented/stuck. Also the main threat loses some of its potency once you've seen it a few times and have figured out how to avoid/get away from it. But at that point the story has revealed itself enough to take over as the driving force to find out where things are going.

 If you have a basic grasp on FPS controls/movement the game takes about 2.5 - 3 hours to finish.

All in all I warmly recommend this game, not only to seasoned horror fans, but to anyone looking for an outside-the-box experience from a new perspective.

30908416.review: It is an interesting idea to play as a small child, unable to do most things, with a fantastical view of common events.  Unfortunately, what we have is a muddled, dark, linear and very short game with only the faintest wisps of a story.  It also features some of the most nausea inducing camera-work I have seen in a long while, and a very tight FOV with no adjustment did not help.  The limited checkpoint save system is also an annoyance.   The majority of the game involves walking through a random hodge-podge of closets, basements, and dream-scape forests, linearly collecting objects to open the "gates" to move to the next section.  Then the game is over.  For something that needed to have a compelling and interesting story, Among the Sleep just fell flat.  Not recomended.

29747671.review:
El análisis original puedes encontrarlo en 

https://thepastisnow.net/2017/02/06/among-the-sleep-donde-estas-mama/

El género de terror me gusta mucho en los videojuegos, siempre me atraen el suspense y la atmósfera en la que consiguen envolverme. Este juego llamó mi atención hace tiempo y solo puedo deciros que no pasa desapercibido.

Principalmente porque interpretas a un bebé justo en el día que cumple 2 añitos, tu madre te está haciendo pasar un día genial mostrando mucho amor y afecto. De repente alguien llama a la puerta, no puedes entender bien lo que ocurre a continuación porque eres un bebé, pero tras algo parecido a una discusión, tu madre aparece con un osito de peluche que se convertirá en tu compañero durante toda la aventura. Mamá te deja en tu habitación y sale a atender el teléfono, en ese momento y tras unos minutos de un breve tutorial, el osito se te presenta como Teddy y te dice que hay que buscar un lugar oscuro y decidís meteros en el armario.

Teddy es tu amigo y estará siempre contigo.

Esta historia tiene mucho mas fondo del que puede parecer en un principio…

Cuando abrazas a Teddy, se ilumina.

Nadie podía imaginar que después de un día que estaba marchando tan bien todo fuera a ir tan tenebrosamente mal. Al entrar en  el armario Teddy te dice a modo de tutorial que si tienes miedo puedes abrazarle ya que la oscuridad se ha hecho con el ambiente y todo empieza a ser retorcido y con formas abstractas.

Mamá te saca del armario con una frase muy particular “deja de esconderte de mamá” cosa que junto con lo que vi al principio, me dejó un poco extrañado. Tras este pequeño episodio, mamá te manda a dormir y en este punto es donde realmente empieza tu aventura.

Me gustaría deciros que me vi atraído por el juego porque no había visto nunca nada parecido antes ¡un juego donde interpretas a un bebé! los detalles y la ambientación están muy cuidados, incluso el juego te recomienda ir gateando a todas partes ya que, como todos sabemos, los bebés son mas rápidos gateando que andando además de mas estables claro está. Destaco como detalle que cuando pulsas Esc para ir al menú de pausa el bebé se tapa los ojos para no mirar.

Los chicos de Krillbite Studios lanzaron este proyecto gracias a la financión de varias empresas y a Kickstarter, donde tuvo buena aceptación por parte del público y tuvieron muchos Backers que colaboraron para que esta joya viera la luz finalmente en su versión completa y final en Mayo de 2014


Estos son los controles que necesitaremos durante el juego, un ejemplo de que una buena historia no necesita tener complejos movimientos.

Llegados a este punto tengo que avisaros, si no habéis jugado el juego y queréis sorprenderos por vosotros mismos, no sigáis leyendo, ya que abordaré temas que pueden ser considerado Spoilers y no quiero reventar a nadie esta experiencia.

Como os comentaba, después de que esa noche Mamá te dejase en la cuna, escaparás de ella y después de salvar a Teddy de ahogarse en la lavadora, la buscaréis juntos por todas partes. Tanto es así que llegaréis a una especie de mundo paralelo terrorífico donde hay una habitación con unos objetos que os dejarán continuar en la búsqueda de nuestra mami.

Recuerdos felices es lo que abrirá esta puerta que nos impide ver a nuestra madre.

A lo largo del juego iremos pasando por diferentes zonas perfectamente reconocibles, pero todas ellas con un aspecto bastante tétrico, donde tendremos que resolver unos puzzles bastante fáciles.

Tirarnos por un tobogán será la manera de pasar a otra zona.

No obstante la crítica del juego ha sido bastante buena, los usuarios han sabido valorar el encanto que tiene el juego pese a su facilidad y a lo corto que es, ya que no dura mas de 3 horas, eso si, es un proyecto mas que interesante con una historia oculta dentro de la propia historia del juego que iremos descubriendo nosotros y no el bebé a medida que avanzamos el juego.

En este parque no querrías que se hiciera de noche.
Han colocado una serie de dibujos hecho por el niño que funcionan a modo de coleccionable para los logros y que junto a la frase que no me sonó muy bien de la madre que os comenté antes, me fuí dando cuenta de que en esta familia hay problemas, el hecho que finalmente hizo que me diera cuenta fue la aparición de muchas botellas de alcohol a lo largo del juego.

Y es que ese parecer ser el fondo del juego, los enemigos que nos encontramos no son más que la madre de nuestro protagonista tratando de encontrarle para hacerle daño de una manera u otra y que el ve a través de figuras distorsionadas en lugares terroríficos haciéndote escapar de ellos una y otra vez.

Este monstruo en camisón intenta darte caza en varias ocasiones.
Los recuerdos felices que hay que encontrar el juego para poder continuar siempre están en sitios con ambientes cálidos y acogedores, el sitio donde un crío puede pasar un buen rato en compañía de algún ser querido.

Fijaos en el detalle de la sabana cubriendo el castillo de madera.
Y es que los creadores del juego han cuidado cada detalle de manera minuciosa para nuestro deleite y consiguen que la inmersión en el juego sea muy buena, tanto es así que cuando descubres lo que está ocurriendo en realidad, un sentimiento extraño te recorre el cuerpo, y ese hecho es el que me ha llevado a plasmarlo en el blog, porque considero que va mas allá de lo que un juego normalmente te hace sentir.

Mamá no quiere que la molestemos ahora.

Tanto es así que muchas escenas me dieron mucha tristeza, como cuando te estás acercando a tu madre pero ella no tiene tiempo para ti, prefiere dedicarlo a otra cosa y una y otra vez te esquiva y se pierde en la oscuridad.

Cuando por fin encuentras a Mamá vemos una escena muy dura, está en el suelo de la cocina, bebida, probablemente sintiéndose culpable porque en un forcejeo ha roto a nuestro amigo Teddy y lo tiene en una mano, suena la puerta y es tu padre, que se interesa por el osito y te dice que puede arreglarlo.

Llorando y sentada en el suelo de la cocina encuentras a Mamá.

Si os gustan los juegos diferentes os recomiendo Among the sleep encarecidamente, está disponible para Steam (Windows e IOs), PS4 y Xbox One, yo lo jugué en la versión Steam.

¿Y tú? ¿Te abrazaste a un osito de peluche cuando tenías miedo por las noches?

¡¡¡Nos vemos pronto!!!

29590299.review:
Rarely will I come across a game that throws you into such a dramatically different perspective. Among The Sleep is a refreshing change to the usual games we all have. Not only does this one throw you into the world of a 2 year old, it shows you just how a child may view the world and the life around him in a very unique way. 

This game plays it's horror cards perfectly as it slowly reveals the child's life in a very dark and disturbing way. You start off in a world full of colour and brightness - how a child's view should be - but this quickly changes to the darkness that a child should never have to experience. 

There are simple challenges that compliment how a child may solve it and this in no way makes the game silly or frustrating. Everything works in perfect unison. Even the environment itself as you navigate really makes you feel so small in the big wide world you woddle around in. Speaking of woddling, the developers really captured the movements/sounds/actions of a 2 year old child. 

Unfortunately there are some issues in this game. You may find a few bugs and glitches as you progress, even to the point where you get stuck and cannot move. I was able to wiggle myself out of any areas I got glitched/stuck into. Be aware the saving function in the game does NOT save your location, only what you've collected and the chapter you're up to. If you exit out of the game you will start back at the beginning of the chapter. 

Nearing the end of this game I really craved familiarity and pretty colours and brightness. Having delved into this poor child's dark life for so long I couldn't wait to get out of it and see what I saw at the beginning. Overall a brilliant game in its portrayal, message, story and feeling. It is a short game but honestly take your time and really explore and enjoy.

29458716.review:
I'm not gonna lie, I only bought this game because it was supposed to be a first person ''horror'' game that puts you in the position of a toddler in a living nightmare. 

Personally, I wouldn't say it's a horror game, I'd rather use the word... spooky. Yes, there are a couple of jump-scares down the road, but that's it. It doesn't play with your anxierty like Outlast: Whistleblower does. 

When I first started Among the Sleep, I didn't like it that much, but I continued playing it anyway. It wasn't until the middle of the game (the forest part) that I started getting into it. 

What's brilliant about this game is that you don't know if the toddler is just having a nightmare or he's actually living it! You suddenly find yourself in a twisted reality while you're looking for your mom, who is nowhere to be seen. You don't know if something took her or fs she's still alive. Also, you have a creepy talking bear guiding you to your death. I actually didn't expect that ending, it's an interesting mature twist I didn't see coming.  It gives it a whole different meaning to the game, and makes you want to play it all over again to get all the references/hints you didn't at first (but that's just me, you might not want to play this game twice). I wanted more to the story, a more conclusive ending, but it was okay I guess. 

That's why I recommend this game. I love misleading storylines. It's a very short game, but it's worth it if you don't mind solving puzzles and avoiding shadowy figures. Also, the atmosphere is kind of creepy, which I love.

I'll rate it 8/10 because I didn't expect the ending, and I screamed like a baby twice.

But that one time is creepy and memorable. Worth picking up if you want an "experience" more so than a game.

29407801.review:
A Creepy and Captivating Journey:

Prepare yourself for an unsettling and unforgettable experience as Among the Sleep: Enhanced Edition takes you on a thrilling adventure from the perspective of a young child. With its stunning graphics, chilling atmosphere, and heart-pounding sound design, this game delivers a unique and immersive horror experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Brace yourself for a journey that explores the fears of childhood and leaves a lasting impact.

Immersive Horror and Heartbreaking Endings:
Among the Sleep: Enhanced Edition not only offers a visually beautiful game, but it also delivers an atmospheric soundscape that perfectly complements the eerie gameplay. As the game progresses, the fear intensifies, building suspense that can send shivers down your spine. The ending, in particular, is a shocking twist that left me broken-hearted. It's a testament to the emotional impact that this game can achieve.

Tips for Survival:
As you delve further into the game, you'll quickly realize the importance of certain survival tips. Never turning around after reaching a certain point in the game becomes a crucial rule to follow, as you may find something lurking in the shadows. Additionally, staying away from water and resisting the temptation to jump into dark pits are key to avoiding untimely demise. These suspenseful moments and survival challenges contribute to the overall sense of anxiety and relief as you progress through the game.

Playing Through a Child's Eyes:
Among the Sleep: Enhanced Edition stands out with its innovative perspective, allowing players to experience the world through the eyes of a two-year-old child. This unique approach offers a captivating insight into how children perceive their surroundings and how everything can affect them. The game begins innocently enough in the kitchen but quickly transitions to the child's bedroom, where things take a haunting turn. The graphics are superb, and exploring new environments is a trippy and mesmerizing experience.

Impressive Atmosphere and Music:
With its haunting atmosphere and eerie soundtrack, Among the Sleep: Enhanced Edition excels at immersing players in a tense and foreboding atmosphere. The combination of ambient sounds and chilling melodies adds depth to the game's unsettling nature. From start to finish, the game maintains an impressive level of atmospheric immersion that leaves a lasting impression.

A Short but Impactful Experience:
Among the Sleep: Enhanced Edition delivers an impressive adventure, albeit a relatively short one. Completing the game in approximately three hours might leave some players yearning for more. However, the game's atmospheric brilliance and emotional impact make it a worthwhile purchase. Consider waiting for a sale if you are concerned about the game's brevity. Nonetheless, the game's unique perspective and unforgettable moments make it a standout experience in the horror genre.

Museum Section:
Upon completing the game, be sure to explore the museum section, where you can delve deeper into the production phases, characters, story, and designs. This additional content provides insights into the meticulous thought and care that went into creating the game, enriching the overall experience.

Conclusion:
Among the Sleep: Enhanced Edition is an exceptional horror game that takes players on a chilling journey through the eyes of a young child. Its impressive atmosphere, captivating graphics, and emotional storytelling make it a standout in the genre. Despite its relatively short length, the game's ability to immerse players in its unsettling world leaves a lasting impression. Prepare for a creepy and unforgettable adventure that will appeal to horror enthusiasts seeking a unique and thought-provoking gaming experience.

29334471.review:
It's a good game, despite my not recommeding it, but $15 USD for a 2 hour experience is a little steep. I beat the entire game in about two hours, and that's with getting lost twice. If you can get it on sale, I would highly recommend it, as the story is worth experiencing. Don't ruin this one by watching a Let's Play.

    It does a good job being suspenceful, but after the first 20 or so minutes, I didn't really feel any danger anymore, and all those sound effects just started to give me a headache. By the time I finally saw the enemy walk past my hiding spot, I lost all suspense. Once I started to peice together the narritive, I spent the latter part of the game more sad than afraid, which I guess is what the developers were aiming for.

   Screeching and jumpscares aside, the puzzles were actually pretty entertaining, albeit easy. Your biggest problem is going to be seeing where you're going. Like I mentioned previously, I got lost twice because of how pitch black the game gets at times. The game gives you a teddy bear that casts a little illumination, but it blocks half the screen, and completely obscures it if you happen to look down.

   All things considered, the game is absolutely brilliant, but the price tag is what keeps me from recommending it.

29212263.review:
I backed this game on Kickstarter. If you buy this game, look for my name in the credits!

If you like horror games, this certainly isn't the scariest game I've played. What I like about this game, that most other horror games do wrong, is that there is mostly atmospheric horror on display. This isn't Outlast, where you need to run, hide, fail, and do it again. There aren't any jump scares (well, there's one, but even great horror films succumb to this trope). Most horror games have a lame gameplay loop that often feels like you're simply waiting for the scary bits to come to light. It's impossible to enjoy a horror game if the fear raised is higher than the players will to continue/enjoyment of the story. Among the Sleep is more like your classic Haunted Mansion ride at a carnival; thrilling but not spooky.

The main draw to this game (at least on the surface) is that you play as a toddler. The scale of the world really makes you feel small as you climb atop boxes, drawers, and more to navigate through the worlds. The emphasis on verticality (everything being bigger than you) gives the game a grand feel for such a linear game. The gameplay loop usually has you fetching certain items in the world in order to proceed forward in the story. The story, while vague, is absolutely dark. 

Sound design is the tops. While the lighting and visual design immerse you in the world, the sound is what raises your hair on ends.

I'd defintely recommend this game if you're looking for a fresh perspective (literally) on the horror genre.

29112648.review:
Do you like being scared? Are you tired of horror games that are nothing but jump scares? This could very well be the game for you! I, personally don't scare easily. I am jumpy, and jump scares generally don't do much besides, well, make me jump. No real fear, or adrenaline there. While playing this game, I found myself experience the closest thing to terror that I have ever felt. Chills raced up and down my spine, as my heart rate increased. My movement became less intentional, and more based on reflex, and panic began to take over. 
It's like that dream where you're being chased by something, but you can't see what, and you try to scream but nothing happens, so do the only thing you can do: Run. If this kind of situation scares you, and you enjoy fear that isn't caused by real-life stress, then I would highly recommend you play this game. 
Pros: Interesting puzzles, eerie atmosphere, terrifying antagonist, and real-life problems that are artistically displayed.
Cons: OK graphics (not good, but not bad), and only about 2 hours long. 
Overall, if you like horror, then this is a good game to pick up on sale. I would not buy it full price, but then again I wouldn't buy most games at full price.

29090607.review:
This is a really interesting exploration of childhood trauma in a couple of phases:

Initially you are exploring the house and new areas, solving simple puzzles with no particular peril - and to be honest, all that really kept me going were the cleverly designed and interesting areas to explore (put me in mind of the Void for sort of eerie). It then sort of evolves into an Amnesia style avoid the monster, with the identity and nature of the monster becoming clearer and clearer. It's not a very good 'jump scare' game (though I think it tries really really hard to be one) but I still enjoyed it once I got going, and at the end. It certainly made me feel and think. 

I bought it on sale and that feels fair... I completed it in about 2 hours (having to redo an entire area because of annoying save system though...). If you're interested in the above, I recommend. I think reading the negative reviews, people perhaps missed the point of the game and the type of horror it represents.

29051145.review:
This was a really fun-albiet short-game.  Very atmospheric and creepy; nothing says "defenseless" like being a baby!  Your only defense is hiding, and all you can do is crawl, or walk-tottering-for a brief period of time.  There are fairly simple puzzles that make things interesting.  The effect for when you're in trouble is very effective, and only serves to heighten the intensity.  The ending/twist is dark, but it's a solid story.  

It's a simple and straightforward game; I casually completed it in less than four hours, but it could probably be done in an hour or two, honestly.  For such a short game, I still think it's worth a play, but probably not something to purchase at full price.  The gameplay is fun and unique, the perspective is something I've never encountered before, and it really provides a unique gameplay experience.

28903963.review:
Nice, original game. I particularly liked the unusual point of view of a 2 year old toddler, who views the world from 70-ish cm high, moves faster when crawling, and sometimes stumbles when he runs.

I think many of the negative reviews fall into 3 categories:

28776417.review:
Another in the long line of indie horror games that never gets going, has an interesting concept that's quickly abandoned with left-field developments, all filled out with a clichéd and predictable plot.

For the horror aspect, well it's best to say: even I wasn't scared by this game. I don't play many horror games, I'm easily scared by their shenanigans, but this one never really tried. It was certainly unsettling, but that's only down to you and how long it takes you to realise you can run around and make as much noise as you like when no demons come out to get you.

The concept seemed to be that you're roaming a hunted house or being attacked by demons, but with the killer twist that you're just a baby. This concept is explored for all of 20 minutes, after which you enter alternate worlds (the classic MC Escher-inspired linear platforming, toddler style). It doesn't help that you'll likely guess the ending and major plot points in the first 10 minutes. The characters say or do a couple of things at the start which appear to be hinting and foreshadowing, only for it to turn out they were just saying random crap you shouldn't have analysed.

This feels like a 3-hour concept video or game a developer would show publishers to get them to invest and publish a hypothetical full game. It's tempting to recommend this just for the potential it has even though it never used it. Instead it's another game that's best right at the start, then they go "I guess we better put some generic gameplay crap in there so it's a game" and it's done.

28774864.review:
Bought it on sale, but honestly it wasn't really worth the time or money I spent. Not scary at all, not creepy at all and they used no method to force the player to actually care about what happens. You basically just run around just to fall down and crawl and then stand up again all the time. Hardly any game mechanics to speak of, it's just one of those games you can play in around two hours, but if you could actually walk without falling down all the time and move a bit smoother, it would take around 30minutes to run through this game(yeah, I know it's meant to be like this, you're a baby after all, just putting it out there that it's short with almost no content). I like to look around and find items or funny things, but there is hardly anything of that either, just a few childrens paintings to pick up. Extremely easy, not even once did I have to stop and think "what should I do to proceed?", everything was obvious and you just picked up everything you needed on the way forward. The only good thing is that I didn't notice any real bugs, it flows on fairly well. But no real story to speak of whatsoever.

If you're really, really, really, REALLY bored and can get this on a sale and you have nothing else to do whatsoever, give this a try and it might help you burn 2-3 hours. I guess it gives what it says it does, you're a baby with super problem solving powers(for a toddler) crawling through a house while seeing illusions created by an infants mind, and I guess it could be considered somewhat creepy, but it's not scary in any way, every time a monster showed up I just ignored it and went on my merry way, when the monsters finally started chasing after you, everything you had to do was hide under a table or something, and usually you didn't even have to care even then as you could just crawl to your goal without minding the "monster", as it hardly aimed at you anyway, while disappearing in just a few seconds. 

I respect the idea of this game, but I just found it really boring in the end, there is absolutely nothing to keep you hooked and care what happens, as there is really nothing much that happens anyway, way too linear, you just walk through everything and solve a few ridiculously simple puzzles that are so obvious that a toddler could realize what to do instantly. Do yourself a favour and find something else to play, please, anything is better than this, read a book, watch a movie, play another game, this is absolutely not worth your money nor your time, unless you're into linear games with a screwed up atmosphere and no story where you just mindlessly charge through. Even if you get it for free, just play something else and let this game rot in your library, it's way slower than it should have been with the content given, just a waste of time. I have a feeling that most of the people that upvoted this is either one of those people that are "neutral" and thinks it's neither good nor extremely bad and therefore went for thumbs up, or the guys that are total pansies and get scared when they hear cracking in their house, or the people that upvoted it for being "acceptable for the price" or maybe those that didn't like it but thought that it was better than some other games. If this was a free game, I might upvote it due to similar reasons, but even 1 dollar/euro is too much for this.

Among the sleep is an indie horror game from both publisher & developer Krillbite Studio, based on exploration. I am usually not a fan of "horror". I don't llike scary movies and I thought the same would go for games, but I was wrong! This is my first experience with a game tagged as "horror" and I was pleasantly surprised by the storyline. So, let me get into what I liked about the game.

PROS:
- unique perspective (as the two-year-old) 
- you really aren't sure what the truth is until you finish the game. 
- great "worlds" that you explore to find pieces of a puzzle that are childlike and at the same time creepy
- not enough to severely scare you, in my opinion (this might be a con for some, but for me it was good as my very first horror game), but there are some startling/creepy moments
- the subject matter is deep, which is refreshing, and the ending is surprising
- music and visuals let you know when you are in danger [spoiler] be careful, you can be caught by the creepy swamp lady [/spoiler]

CONS:
- The only con I could think of was that I really wanted the game to be longer! It only took a couple of hours. I mean, the length was good with the storyline, but I just wanted more! I'd be interested to see if they make more games like this from a child's perspective.

OVERALL:
9/10 (minus one point because of the game length)

This is a good starter game if you are new to the genre of horror and aren't sure if you will enjoy it. With this game, you will!

I don't really remember anything particular from my life before the age of 5-6. Not even moments. So it was a surprise for me, how deep impression the game left me with after few hours.

You play as a 2 year old child, who just had his birthday with mom and a nice cake. You also got a crippy looking Teddy bear. Honestly those eyes... (but he is your friend, so it will be OK ;)

The story starts at night... and there is no light. I don't really want to tell anything about the story.

I don't think we had ever played as a 2 year old. And you have to think like that. You have to crawl and climb on things, the entire perspective is different from being an adult. Honestly the whole game is spooky, and chilling without going into real horror territory. Most of the things indeed can be freightening for a 2 year old. The darkness, the little lights and sounds. The sound design is amazing in this game. The puzzles are mainly simple, but the story is not. After playing a game I thought about how glad I am that I had a normal childhood, with great parents.

Mom, I miss you so much...

Finally got around to it, and while it's taking a slightly different turn than I expected - dipping more into surreal dreamlike locations than the house itself - I'm enjoying it.

The mother's character model was initially a bit off-putting, likely because of how close to her face you tend to be as she carries you through the house, but the rest of the game is beautiful; the house, while fairly typical, looms up around you from your low vantage point, and as you get deeper into surreality, things just keeping getting more gorgeous - and creepy.

There are some odd POV clipping issues, and occasional vocal prompts that don't seem to be relevent (mainly in the beginning as you're told to be quiet - often I'm expecting a stealth-type gameplay where there really isn't a need for it) but overall the game is enjoyable.

26587213.review:
This game most definately deserves a thumbs up.  Its a superb example of a game designed to keep you feeling nervous througout.  The ominous atmosphere is built up carefully over time and uses some excellent imagery to not only bring the story along but also uses the same imagery to warp and distort your view of the word and helps to keep that forbiding atmosphere going.

The way it gives you the view a toddler would have and has small puzzles that very much make you have to think about how a child might acheive it is very cleaver too.  None of the puzzles are hugely challenging but thats okay as really its the atmosphere and the progression through the creepy environment which is really the point of the game.  

Although the game is short it is tight gameplay and I would much prefer a game which is a few hours long but is consistently entertaining for those few hours than have a game which puts in a load of grind just to build up time.  The story is fairly predicatable especially around half way through the game but again, as the story progresses at a nice pace and the game is fairly short this isnt really a problem.  In any case the lead up to that conclusion and the final scene are very well done and while you will have been largely expecting it, its a perfectly timed and very imaginative way of bringing it about.

I would say make sure you explore the nooks and crannys as you go as there are pictures on the walls which help to give the story more context as well.  

Finally for the Linux users I can confirm that this game ran superbly well on my machine.  Its a fairly modest gaming rig and even so the game ran flawlessly.

Personally i would say this was worth the full price being asked and I feel very happy I got to play this game.

26549265.review:
A heavily atmospheric and dream-like game from the unusual perspective of a toddler. The elements of saturated colors, artistically created environments, and lush soundtrack are well harmonized for a unique experience. If you're tired of stereotypical horror games, this is something fresh.

PROS
* The visual design is striking. The bright colors and dark shadows play over strangely distorted landscapes. The child's perspective makes even common objects like swings or coats huge and menacing. This is a visual experience that will not soon be forgotten.
* The atmosphere is enhanced by the soundscape. There are bumps in the night, rumbling drones, and a haunting melody being hummed far off.
* Without spoiling anything, the subject matter is interesting and well paced.
* The voice acting of the teddy bear is another high point, being playful and surreal without becoming corny.
* This is a very imaginative experience. It felt like reading a storybook, in a similar vein as the movie The Babadook.

CONS
* The game is extremely linear. It almost felt like a straight line going through each area.
* When the monsters are introduced, it detracts greatly from the experience for me. The nightmarish environment lets your imagination run wild, so when the game becomes a hide-and-seek horror trope, the experience suffers.
* The monsters become constant by the end. Less really would have been more, both for scares and for letting the environment keep the spotlight.
* There's no story. There is a *situation* which you come to understand throughout the game. I feel that if the game developers were going to tackle this subject, there really should have been more depth given to both the "villain" and to the situation. Instead, the treatment feels shallow and even insensitive.

26542823.review: ♥♥♥♥ this game. Seriously. I've played through it and the prologue about 3 times each and still scare the hell out of myself. 10/10 for getting me attached and wanting more. Pro tip: Don't trust Teddy!

26532843.review: I tried playing while drunk and noped the fuck out. 10/10 would shit myself again.

26530225.review:
Really smart game with incredible art and a simple, effective playing style. Stays true to being a baby (you can't read any of the labels and signs, for example), which is critical to how it all comes together at the end.

The game isn't too long. I finished it in six hours, but it has such an engaging visual style that becomes progressively nightmarish after starting out like a normal day in the life of a kid that you might end up just exploring, looking around and interacting with the environment.

This style works on multiple levels. The clues all lead to something (no spoilers) but the game developers allow the art, ambient sound and surroundings to serve as the major storytelling device so that you're not beat over the head with what's going on but you never feel like it's random or haphazard.

I bought this on sale, but that means I got a deal. It would have been worth the non-sale asking price.

Yes, you can die.
